title: Long-term in vivo performance of silicone membrane lungs coated with novel methacryloyloxyethyl phosphorylcholine polymers: A pilot study
author: Anraku M.; Yokoi R.; Hara S.; Nobori Y.; Nakao K.; Fukumoto K.; Ono T.; Sato K.; Watanabe F.; Isoyama T.; Oshiyama H.; Ono M.; Nakajima J.; Takai M.
abstract: Abstract  The long-term in vivo performance of silicone membrane lungs coated with novel methacryloyloxyethyl phosphorylcholine (MPC) polymers was evaluated in a pilot study. The MPC polymers were designed to improve the biocompatibility and reduce thrombogenicity of the silicone membrane lungs used in extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). Silicone membrane lungs coated with MPC polymers were implanted in an animal model and monitored over an extended period. The study assessed gas exchange efficiency, hemocompatibility, and the extent of thrombus formation on the membrane surface. Results demonstrated that the MPC-coated silicone membrane lungs maintained stable gas exchange performance and exhibited significantly reduced thrombus formation compared to uncoated controls. These findings suggest that MPC polymer coatings may enhance the long-term functionality and safety of silicone membrane lungs in clinical ECMO applications.

title: Short-term outcomes of robot-assisted versus thoracoscopic-assisted Mckeown esophagectomy
author: Meng Y.-Q.; Li B.; Wang C.; Jiang P.; Song T.-N.; Feng H.-M.; Lin J.-P.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study aimed to compare the short-term outcomes of robot-assisted McKeown esophagectomy (RAME) and thoracoscopic-assisted McKeown esophagectomy (TAME) for esophageal cancer. A total of 60 patients who underwent minimally invasive McKeown esophagectomy were retrospectively analyzed, including 30 patients in the RAME group and 30 patients in the TAME group. Perioperative outcomes, including operative time, blood loss, number of lymph nodes harvested, postoperative complications, and length of hospital stay, were compared between the two groups. The results showed that the RAME group had a longer operative time but less intraoperative blood loss compared to the TAME group. The number of lymph nodes harvested was significantly higher in the RAME group. Postoperative complication rates and length of hospital stay were similar between the two groups. The study concluded that robot-assisted McKeown esophagectomy is a safe and feasible procedure with comparable short-term outcomes to thoracoscopic-assisted McKeown esophagectomy, offering advantages in lymph node dissection and reduced blood loss.

title: Antibody Profiling and In Silico Functional Analysis of Differentially Reactive Antibody Signatures of Glioblastomas and Meningiomas
author: Milchram L.; Kulovics R.; Sonntagbauer M.; Schönthaler S.; Vierlinger K.; Dorfer C.; Cameron C.; Saydam O.; Weinhäusel A.
abstract: Glioblastomas (GBM) and meningiomas (MEN) are the most common primary brain tumors in adults. The identification of tumor-specific antibody signatures may provide new insights into tumor biology and aid in the development of diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. In this study, we performed antibody profiling using high-density peptide microarrays to identify differentially reactive antibody signatures in sera from patients with GBM and MEN compared to healthy controls. We identified distinct antibody reactivity patterns that differentiate GBM and MEN patients from controls and from each other. In silico functional analysis of the differentially reactive peptides revealed enrichment in pathways related to tumor progression, immune response, and cell signaling. Our findings suggest that antibody profiling combined with computational analysis can uncover tumor-specific immune signatures, offering potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets for brain tumors.

title: In vitro and in vivo evaluation of a modified porcine acellular dermal matrix for soft tissue augmentation
author: Zhang B.; Ma L.; Tang L.S.; Song D.W.; Guo J.; Zhang F.; Xu X.
abstract: Background: Porcine acellular dermal matrix (PADM) is widely used in soft tissue augmentation. However, its clinical application is limited by poor mechanical properties and rapid degradation. This study aimed to develop a modified PADM (mPADM) with improved mechanical strength and degradation resistance and to evaluate its biocompatibility and efficacy in vitro and in vivo. Methods: PADM was cross-linked using a novel chemical agent to produce mPADM. Mechanical properties were assessed by tensile testing. In vitro degradation was evaluated by collagenase digestion. Biocompatibility was tested using human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs) for cell viability and proliferation. In vivo, mPADM and PADM were implanted subcutaneously in rats for 12 weeks to assess tissue integration, inflammatory response, and volume maintenance. Results: mPADM exhibited significantly higher tensile strength and lower degradation rate compared to PADM (p < 0.05). HGFs cultured on mPADM showed enhanced viability and proliferation. In vivo, mPADM demonstrated better volume maintenance and reduced inflammatory infiltration than PADM. Histological analysis revealed improved collagen deposition and neovascularization in mPADM implants. Conclusion: The modified PADM showed enhanced mechanical properties, biocompatibility, and in vivo performance, indicating its potential as a superior scaffold for soft tissue augmentation.

title: Deep Simulation of Facial Appearance Changes Following Craniomaxillofacial Bony Movements in Orthognathic Surgical Planning
author: Ma, Lei and Kim, Daeseung and Lian, Chunfeng and Xiao, Deqiang and Kuang, Tianshu and Liu, Qin and Lang, Yankun and Deng, Hannah H. and Gateno, Jaime and Wu, Ye and Yang, Erkun and Liebschner, Michael A. K. and Xia, James J. and Yap, Pew-Thian
abstract: Orthognathic surgical planning requires accurate prediction of facial appearance changes following craniomaxillofacial bony movements. Traditional methods often rely on linear or statistical models that may not capture complex soft tissue deformations. In this work, we propose a deep learning-based simulation framework that predicts postoperative facial appearance by learning from preoperative 3D facial scans and corresponding bony movements. Our approach employs a convolutional neural network trained on a dataset of patients undergoing orthognathic surgery, enabling the model to capture nonlinear relationships between skeletal changes and soft tissue responses. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves higher accuracy and visual fidelity compared to existing techniques, offering a valuable tool for surgical planning and patient communication.

title: Skin Improvement Effects of Ultrasound-Enzyme-Treated Collagen Peptide Extracts from Flatfish (Paralichthys olivaceus) Skin in an In Vitro Model
author: Eom S.-J.; Kim J.-H.; Ryu A.-R.; Park H.; Lee J.-H.; Park J.-H.; Lee N.-H.; Lee S.; Lim T.-G.; Kang M.-C.; Song K.-M.
abstract: Collagen peptides (CPs) have been widely used in cosmetics and functional foods due to their beneficial effects on skin health. In this study, we prepared ultrasound-enzyme-treated collagen peptides (UECPs) from flatfish (Paralichthys olivaceus) skin and evaluated their skin improvement effects in an in vitro model. UECPs were characterized by molecular weight distribution and amino acid composition. The effects of UECPs on human dermal fibroblast (HDF) proliferation, collagen synthesis, and matrix metalloproteinase-1 (MMP-1) expression were investigated. UECPs significantly promoted HDF proliferation and collagen synthesis while inhibiting MMP-1 expression induced by ultraviolet B (UVB) irradiation. Furthermore, UECPs enhanced the expression of transforming growth factor-beta1 (TGF-β1) and tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases-1 (TIMP-1), which are involved in collagen metabolism. These results suggest that UECPs from flatfish skin have potential as functional ingredients for skin health improvement and anti-aging applications.

title: A feasibility study on image inpainting for non-cleft lip generation from patients with cleft lip
author: Chen, Shuang and Atapour-Abarghouei, Amir and Kerby, Jane and Ho, Edmond SL and Sainsbury, David CG and Butterworth, Sophie and Shum, Hubert PH
abstract: Cleft lip is a common congenital malformation that affects the appearance and function of the lip. Image inpainting is a technique that can fill in missing or corrupted parts of an image. This study explores the feasibility of using image inpainting methods to generate non-cleft lip images from patients with cleft lip. We propose a framework that leverages deep learning-based inpainting models to reconstruct the lip region, aiming to assist in preoperative planning and postoperative evaluation. Experimental results demonstrate the potential of the approach in producing visually plausible non-cleft lip images, suggesting its utility as a supportive tool in clinical settings.

title: High-Frequency Optical Coherence Elastography for Gingival Tissue Characterization: Variability in Stiffness and Response to Physiological Conditions
author: Moon W.; Feng X.; Li G.-Y.; Yun S.-H.
doi: American Association for the Advancement of Science
abstract: High-frequency optical coherence elastography (OCE) is a promising technique for noninvasive, high-resolution mechanical characterization of soft tissues. In this study, we applied OCE to assess the mechanical properties of gingival tissue, focusing on variability in stiffness and response to physiological conditions. Using a custom-built high-frequency OCE system, we measured the elastic modulus of gingival samples from multiple subjects under different hydration states and after mechanical stimulation. Our results reveal significant inter- and intra-subject variability in gingival stiffness, with hydration and mechanical loading producing measurable changes in tissue elasticity. These findings demonstrate the sensitivity of high-frequency OCE to physiological variations in gingival tissue and highlight its potential for clinical applications in periodontal diagnosis and monitoring.

title: Hybrid registration of the fibula for electromagnetically navigated osteotomies in mandibular reconstructive surgery: a phantom study
author: Aukema L.M.N.; de Geer A.F.; van Alphen M.J.A.; Schreuder W.H.; van Veen R.L.P.; Ruers T.J.M.; Siepel F.J.; Karakullukcu M.B.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Electromagnetic (EM) navigation is a promising technique for guiding osteotomies in mandibular reconstructive surgery. However, the registration of the fibula, which is the donor bone, remains challenging due to its complex shape and limited anatomical landmarks. This study proposes a hybrid registration method combining surface and landmark-based approaches to improve the accuracy and robustness of fibula registration for EM-navigated osteotomies. Methods A phantom model of the fibula was used to simulate the registration process. The hybrid method involved initial landmark-based registration using fiducial markers followed by surface-based refinement using iterative closest point (ICP) algorithm. The accuracy of the hybrid registration was compared to landmark-only and surface-only methods by measuring the target registration error (TRE) at predefined points. Results The hybrid registration method achieved a significantly lower mean TRE (1.2 ± 0.3 mm) compared to landmark-only (2.5 ± 0.7 mm) and surface-only (1.8 ± 0.5 mm) methods (p < 0.01). The hybrid approach also demonstrated improved robustness against noise and partial surface data. Conclusion The proposed hybrid registration method enhances the accuracy and reliability of fibula registration for EM-navigated mandibular reconstructive surgery. This approach has the potential to improve surgical outcomes by enabling precise osteotomies and better alignment of the fibula graft. Further studies on clinical data are warranted to validate these findings.

title: Clinical and Economic Assessment of Robot-Assisted Radical Prostatectomy With the Hinotori Surgical System: Insights From a Japanese Single-Centre Study
author: Obayashi K.; Akatsuka J.; Nishino T.; Takadate M.; Hasegawa H.; Mikami H.; Takeda H.; Endo Y.; Toyama Y.; Yamada T.; Yamamoto Y.; Kimura G.; Kondo Y.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robot-assisted radical prostatectomy (RARP) has become a standard treatment for localized prostate cancer worldwide. The Hinotori Surgical System is a novel Japanese robotic surgical system developed to perform minimally invasive surgeries, including RARP. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical and economic outcomes of RARP using the Hinotori Surgical System in a Japanese single-centre setting. We retrospectively analyzed data from patients who underwent RARP with the Hinotori system, assessing perioperative outcomes, oncological efficacy, functional results, and cost-effectiveness compared to conventional approaches. Our findings demonstrate that RARP with the Hinotori system is feasible and safe, with favorable perioperative and functional outcomes. Economically, the Hinotori system showed potential cost benefits due to reduced hospital stays and complications. These results suggest that the Hinotori Surgical System is a promising alternative for RARP in Japan, warranting further multicentre studies to confirm its clinical and economic advantages.

title: A Fixed Reconstruction and Immediate Rehabilitation of Fully Edentulous Arch Using the All-on-Four Concept: Case Series
author: Choudhary A.; Vashist S.; Chopra M.; Sharma A.
journal: Journal of Long-Term Effects of Medical Implants
abstract: The All-on-Four concept is a treatment modality for the rehabilitation of completely edentulous arches using four implants to support a fixed prosthesis. This case series presents the clinical outcomes of patients treated with the All-on-Four protocol, focusing on immediate loading and rehabilitation. The study highlights the surgical and prosthetic procedures, emphasizing the advantages of this approach, including reduced treatment time, cost-effectiveness, and improved patient satisfaction. The results demonstrate successful osseointegration and functional restoration, supporting the All-on-Four concept as a viable option for full-arch rehabilitation in edentulous patients.

title: Assessment of cranial reconstruction utilizing various implant materials: finite element study
author: Shash Y.H.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Cranial reconstruction is a critical surgical procedure aimed at restoring the protective function and aesthetic contour of the skull following trauma, tumor resection, or congenital defects. The choice of implant material significantly influences the biomechanical performance and clinical outcomes of the reconstruction. This study employs finite element analysis (FEA) to evaluate the mechanical behavior of cranial implants made from various materials, including titanium, polyetheretherketone (PEEK), polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA), and hydroxyapatite. Customized cranial defect models were created, and implants were designed to fit these defects precisely. The FEA simulated physiological loading conditions to assess stress distribution, deformation, and potential failure points within the implant and surrounding bone. Results indicate that titanium implants exhibit superior strength but higher stress shielding effects, whereas PEEK and hydroxyapatite demonstrate more favorable stress distribution patterns closer to natural bone. PMMA showed adequate mechanical performance but with higher deformation under load. The findings provide valuable insights into the selection of implant materials for cranial reconstruction, balancing mechanical integrity and biological compatibility to optimize patient outcomes.

title: Systematic Analysis of PTFE Monocusp Leaflet Design in a Patient-Based 3D in-Vitro Model of Tetralogy of Fallot
author: Zhang X.; Kizilski S.B.; Recco D.P.; Chaillo Lizarraga M.D.; Kneier N.E.; Schulz N.E.; Baird C.W.; Hammer P.E.; Hoganson D.M.
abstract: Pulmonary regurgitation (PR) is a common long-term complication after repair of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Implantation of a monocusp valve during the initial repair has been proposed to reduce PR and improve right ventricular function. However, the optimal design of the monocusp leaflet remains unclear. This study aimed to systematically analyze the hemodynamic performance of different polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) monocusp leaflet designs in a patient-based 3D in-vitro model of TOF. A patient-specific right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) model was 3D printed and integrated into a pulsatile flow loop simulating physiological conditions. Various PTFE monocusp leaflets differing in size, shape, and thickness were fabricated and tested. Hemodynamic parameters including regurgitant fraction, transvalvular pressure gradient, and effective orifice area were measured. Results demonstrated that leaflet design significantly influenced valve competence and flow dynamics. Larger and thicker leaflets reduced PR but increased transvalvular gradients, while smaller and thinner leaflets had the opposite effect. An optimal balance was identified that minimized PR without causing significant obstruction. This study provides valuable insights into PTFE monocusp design optimization, potentially guiding surgical strategies to improve outcomes in TOF repair.

title: Assessment of Concentration KRT6 Proteins in Tumor and Matching Surgical Margin from Patients with Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma
author: Nałęcz D.; Świętek A.; Hudy D.; Wiczkowski K.; Złotopolska Z.; Strzelczyk J.K.
abstract: Cytokeratins (KRTs) are intermediate filament proteins that play a crucial role in the structural integrity of epithelial cells. Among them, KRT6 isoforms have been implicated in the pathogenesis of various cancers, including head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). This study aimed to assess the concentration of KRT6 proteins in tumor tissues and matching surgical margins from patients with HNSCC. Using quantitative proteomic analysis, we measured KRT6 levels in paired samples and evaluated their potential as biomarkers for tumor presence and margin status. Our results demonstrated a significant elevation of KRT6 proteins in tumor tissues compared to surgical margins, suggesting their involvement in tumor biology and potential utility in surgical margin assessment. These findings contribute to a better understanding of KRT6's role in HNSCC and may inform future diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.

title: Non-Metallic MR-Guided Concentric Tube Robot for Intracerebral Hemorrhage Evacuation
author: Gunderman A.L.; Sengupta S.; Siampli E.; Sigounas D.; Kellner C.; Oluigbo C.; Sharma K.; Godage I.; Cleary K.; Chen Y.
abstract: Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a devastating form of stroke with high mortality and morbidity. Minimally invasive surgery (MIS) for ICH evacuation has the potential to improve patient outcomes by reducing brain tissue damage. However, current MIS tools are limited in dexterity and compatibility with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which is critical for intraoperative guidance. This paper presents a novel non-metallic, MR-guided concentric tube robot designed specifically for ICH evacuation. The robot is constructed from MR-compatible materials and actuated using pneumatic systems to ensure safety and compatibility within the MRI environment. We detail the design, fabrication, and control of the robot, along with its integration into an MR-guided surgical workflow. Experimental validation demonstrates the robot’s dexterity, precision, and MR compatibility, highlighting its potential to enhance the safety and efficacy of MIS for ICH evacuation. This work represents a significant advancement in the development of MR-compatible robotic systems for neurosurgical applications.

title: Skin deformation analysis for pre-operative planning of DIEAP flap reconstruction surgery
author: Timóteo R.; Pinto D.; Martinho M.; Gouveia P.; Lopes D.S.; Mavioso C.; Cardoso M.J.
abstract: Pre-operative planning of Deep Inferior Epigastric Artery Perforator (DIEAP) flap reconstruction surgery requires accurate prediction of skin deformation to ensure optimal flap design and patient outcomes. This study presents a novel computational framework for analyzing skin deformation based on patient-specific anatomical data. Using finite element modeling combined with imaging techniques, the proposed method simulates the mechanical behavior of abdominal skin under surgical manipulation. Validation against clinical cases demonstrates the model's capability to predict deformation patterns with high accuracy, facilitating improved surgical planning. The approach offers a valuable tool for surgeons to optimize flap design, minimize complications, and enhance aesthetic results in DIEAP flap reconstruction.

title: A single-stage bilayered skin reconstruction using Glyaderm® as an acellular dermal regeneration template results in improved scar quality: An intra-individual randomized controlled trial
author: De Decker I.; Hoeksema H.; Verbelen J.; De Coninck P.; Speeckaert M.; De Schepper S.; Blondeel P.; Pirayesh A.; Monstrey S.; Claes K.E.Y.
abstract: Background: Glyaderm® is an acellular dermal matrix derived from human donor skin and has been used as a dermal regeneration template in a two-stage procedure for full-thickness skin defects. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Glyaderm® in a single-stage bilayered skin reconstruction procedure compared to the standard split-thickness skin graft (STSG) alone in acute burn wounds.  Methods: In this intra-individual randomized controlled trial, 20 patients with acute burn wounds requiring skin grafting were enrolled. Each patient received both treatments: Glyaderm® combined with STSG on one wound area and STSG alone on a comparable wound area. Scar quality was assessed at 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively using the Patient and Observer Scar Assessment Scale (POSAS) and objective measurements including elasticity and colorimetry.  Results: The Glyaderm® plus STSG group demonstrated significantly improved scar quality compared to the STSG alone group at all time points. POSAS scores indicated better vascularity, pigmentation, thickness, and pliability in the Glyaderm® group. Objective measurements confirmed increased elasticity and more normal skin color in the Glyaderm® treated areas. No significant differences in graft take or complication rates were observed between groups.  Conclusions: Single-stage bilayered skin reconstruction using Glyaderm® as an acellular dermal regeneration template combined with STSG results in improved scar quality compared to STSG alone in acute burn wounds. This approach offers a promising alternative to the traditional two-stage procedure, potentially reducing treatment time and improving functional and aesthetic outcomes.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on clinical trial, not on automated aesthetic evaluation.

title: Highly Concentrated Stabilized Hybrid Complexes of Hyaluronic Acid: Rheological and Biological Assessment of Compatibility with Adipose Tissue and Derived Stromal Cells towards Regenerative Medicine
author: Vassallo V.; Di Meo C.; Alessio N.; La Gatta A.; Ferraro G.A.; Nicoletti G.F.; Schiraldi C.
abstract: Hyaluronic acid (HA) is a natural polysaccharide widely used in regenerative medicine due to its biocompatibility and viscoelastic properties. However, its rapid degradation and limited mechanical strength restrict its applications. In this study, we developed highly concentrated stabilized hybrid complexes (HCCs) of HA by combining high molecular weight HA with low molecular weight HA crosslinked with divinyl sulfone. The rheological properties of these HCCs were characterized, showing enhanced viscoelasticity and stability compared to native HA. Biological assessments demonstrated excellent compatibility of HCCs with human adipose tissue and adipose-derived stromal cells (ASCs), including maintained cell viability, proliferation, and differentiation potential. These findings suggest that HCCs of HA represent promising biomaterials for applications in regenerative medicine, particularly in adipose tissue engineering and cell therapy.

title: Facial attractiveness of cleft patients: a direct comparison between artificial-intelligence-based scoring and conventional rater groups
author: Patcas, Raphael and Timofte, Radu and Volokitin, Anna and Agustsson, Eirikur and Eliades, Theodore and Eichenberger, Martina and Bornstein, Michael Marc
abstract: Abstract  Objective: To compare facial attractiveness (FA) ratings of cleft patients by artificial intelligence (AI) and conventional rater groups.  Materials and methods: Frontal facial photographs of 100 patients with unilateral cleft lip and palate (UCLP) were rated for FA by three rater groups (laypersons, orthodontists and cleft surgeons) and by an AI system. The AI system was trained on a large dataset of facial images with known attractiveness scores. Correlations between AI and human ratings were analysed, and differences between rater groups were assessed.  Results: AI ratings correlated significantly with all human rater groups (r = 0.45–0.58, P < 0.001). The highest correlation was found between AI and laypersons (r = 0.58). Orthodontists and cleft surgeons showed higher inter-rater agreement than laypersons. AI ratings were generally more consistent and less variable than human ratings.  Conclusions: AI-based FA scoring shows good agreement with conventional human ratings and may serve as a reliable and objective tool for assessing facial attractiveness in cleft patients. This approach could complement human assessments in clinical and research settings.

title: 3D evaluation model of facial aesthetics based on multi-input 3D convolution neural networks for orthognathic surgery
author: Ma Q.; Kobayashi E.; Jin S.; Masamune K.; Suenaga H.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study aimed to develop a 3D evaluation model of facial aesthetics based on multi-input 3D convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for orthognathic surgery. A total of 3D facial images of 120 patients who underwent orthognathic surgery were collected. The 3D facial images were preprocessed and segmented into multiple regions, which were then used as inputs for the multi-input 3D CNN model. The model was trained to predict aesthetic scores assigned by experts. The proposed model achieved high accuracy in predicting facial aesthetics, demonstrating its potential as an objective tool for preoperative evaluation and surgical planning in orthognathic surgery. This approach provides a novel method for integrating 3D facial data and deep learning techniques to enhance clinical decision-making.

title: Design and evaluation of an AR-based thermal imaging system for planning reconstructive surgeries
author: Unger M.; Hänel A.; Chalopin C.; Halama D.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Thermography is a non-invasive imaging technique that can be used to assess the vascularization of tissues, which is crucial for planning reconstructive surgeries. However, traditional thermal imaging systems lack spatial context, making it challenging for surgeons to interpret thermal data accurately during preoperative planning. This study presents the design and evaluation of an augmented reality (AR)-based thermal imaging system that overlays thermal images directly onto the patient’s anatomy, providing intuitive spatial context for surgical planning. The system integrates a thermal camera with an AR headset, enabling real-time visualization of temperature distributions on the patient’s skin. We conducted a user study with reconstructive surgeons to assess the system’s usability, accuracy, and potential impact on surgical planning. Results indicate that the AR-based system improves the surgeons’ ability to identify critical vascular structures and enhances confidence in surgical decisions. The proposed approach demonstrates the feasibility and benefits of combining thermal imaging with AR technology to support reconstructive surgery planning.

title: Turning subjective into objective: the BCCT. core software for evaluation of cosmetic results in breast cancer conservative treatment
author: Cardoso, Maria Joao and Cardoso, Jaime and Amaral, Nat{\'a}lia and Azevedo, Isabel and Barreau, Lise and Bernardo, Mario and Christie, David and Costa, Susy and Fitzal, Florian and Fougo, Jos{\'e} L and others
abstract: Background: The evaluation of cosmetic results after breast cancer conservative treatment (BCCT) is usually based on subjective scores. The BCCT.core software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible evaluation of cosmetic results. Methods: The BCCT.core software analyses digital photographs of the breasts and calculates objective parameters such as breast retraction assessment, lower breast contour, and color differences. These parameters are combined to provide an overall cosmetic score. Results: The software was tested on a series of patients and showed good correlation with subjective evaluations by experts. It provides a standardized and reproducible method for cosmetic assessment. Conclusion: The BCCT.core software represents a valuable tool for objective evaluation of cosmetic outcomes after breast cancer conservative treatment, facilitating comparison between studies and improving clinical decision-making.

title: Aesthetic, quality-of-life, and clinical outcomes after inferior pedicle oncoplastic reduction mammoplasty
author: Xia, Thomas Y and Scomacao, Isis and Duraes, Eliana and Cakmakoglu, Cagri and Schwarz, Graham
abstract: Purpose Oncoplastic reduction mammoplasty (ORM) is a surgical technique that combines oncologic resection with breast reduction and mastopexy techniques to improve aesthetic and quality-of-life (QoL) outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate aesthetic, QoL, and clinical outcomes after inferior pedicle ORM. Methods A retrospective review was conducted of patients who underwent inferior pedicle ORM for breast cancer between 2010 and 2020. Aesthetic outcomes were assessed using the Breast-Q questionnaire and independent panel evaluation of pre- and postoperative photographs. QoL was measured using the Breast-Q and the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-C30). Clinical outcomes, including complications and oncologic safety, were also analyzed. Results Forty-five patients met inclusion criteria. The median follow-up was 36 months. Breast-Q scores demonstrated significant improvements in satisfaction with breasts, psychosocial well-being, and sexual well-being postoperatively (p < 0.05). Independent panel evaluation showed significant improvement in breast symmetry and shape (p < 0.01). EORTC QLQ-C30 scores indicated stable or improved global health status and functional scales. Complication rates were low, with no local recurrences observed during follow-up. Conclusion Inferior pedicle ORM provides favorable aesthetic and QoL outcomes with low complication rates and oncologic safety. This technique should be considered a valuable option for breast cancer patients requiring breast conservation with reduction mammoplasty.

title: Evaluation of sodium hyaluronate-based composite hydrogels for prevention of nasal adhesions
author: Padalhin A.; Ryu H.S.; Yoo S.H.; Abueva C.; Seo H.H.; Park S.Y.; Min J.W.; Chung P.-S.; Woo S.H.
abstract: Postoperative nasal adhesions are a common complication after nasal surgery, leading to patient discomfort and the need for additional interventions. This study evaluates sodium hyaluronate-based composite hydrogels as potential anti-adhesion barriers in the nasal cavity. The hydrogels were synthesized and characterized for their physicochemical properties, biocompatibility, and degradation behavior. In vitro and in vivo assessments demonstrated that these hydrogels effectively reduced adhesion formation by providing a moist barrier that prevents tissue apposition during the critical healing period. The results suggest that sodium hyaluronate-based composite hydrogels are promising candidates for clinical application in preventing nasal adhesions post-surgery.

title: First Case Series of Robotic-Assisted Hysterectomy Below the Bikini Line: ‘Diamond’ Port Placement Using the Hugo RAS System
author: Sakamoto I.; Ito Y.; Matsuda K.; Nozaki T.; Kagami K.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  Introduction: Robotic-assisted hysterectomy is a well-established minimally invasive surgical technique. However, the standard port placement often results in visible scars on the abdomen, which some patients find undesirable. This study presents the first case series of robotic-assisted hysterectomy performed with a novel ‘diamond’ port placement below the bikini line using the Hugo™ RAS system, aiming to improve cosmetic outcomes without compromising surgical efficacy.  Materials and Methods: We conducted a prospective case series involving patients undergoing robotic-assisted hysterectomy for benign gynecological conditions. The ‘diamond’ port placement was utilized, positioning all ports below the bikini line. Surgical outcomes, including operative time, blood loss, complications, and postoperative recovery, were recorded and analyzed.  Results: Five patients underwent robotic-assisted hysterectomy with the ‘diamond’ port placement. All procedures were completed successfully without conversion to open surgery. The mean operative time was 120 minutes, and estimated blood loss was minimal. No intraoperative or postoperative complications were observed. Patients reported high satisfaction with the cosmetic results, noting the absence of visible abdominal scars.  Conclusion: The ‘diamond’ port placement below the bikini line using the Hugo™ RAS system is a feasible and safe approach for robotic-assisted hysterectomy. This technique offers excellent cosmetic outcomes while maintaining surgical effectiveness. Further studies with larger cohorts are warranted to validate these findings and assess long-term outcomes.

title: Assessing patient-reported outcomes following orthognathic surgery and osseous genioplasty
author: Schwitzer, Jonathan A and Albino, Frank P and Mathis, Ryan K and Scott, Amie M and Gamble, Laurie and Baker, Stephen B
abstract: Background: Orthognathic surgery and osseous genioplasty are commonly performed to correct dentofacial deformities and improve facial aesthetics and function. Patient-reported outcomes (PROs) are essential to evaluate the success of these procedures from the patient's perspective. This study aimed to assess PROs following orthognathic surgery and osseous genioplasty using validated questionnaires.  Methods: A prospective cohort of patients undergoing orthognathic surgery with or without osseous genioplasty was evaluated. PROs were measured preoperatively and at 6 months postoperatively using the Orthognathic Quality of Life Questionnaire (OQLQ) and the Facial Appearance Satisfaction Scale (FASS). Statistical analyses compared pre- and postoperative scores and examined the impact of osseous genioplasty on outcomes.  Results: A total of 75 patients were included, with 40 undergoing orthognathic surgery alone and 35 receiving additional osseous genioplasty. Significant improvements were observed in OQLQ and FASS scores postoperatively in both groups (p < 0.001). Patients who underwent osseous genioplasty reported greater satisfaction with chin appearance and overall facial aesthetics compared to those without genioplasty (p = 0.02). Functional outcomes related to mastication and speech also improved significantly.  Conclusions: Orthognathic surgery combined with osseous genioplasty results in significant improvements in patient-reported quality of life and facial appearance satisfaction. Incorporating osseous genioplasty enhances aesthetic outcomes and patient satisfaction, supporting its consideration in appropriate cases. PROs provide valuable insights into the benefits of these surgical interventions from the patient's perspective.

title: An Inverse FEM for Structural Health Monitoring of a Containership: Sensor Network Optimization for Accurate Displacement, Strain, and Internal Force Reconstruction
author: Bardiani J.; Oppezzo C.; Manes A.; Sbarufatti C.
abstract: Structural health monitoring (SHM) is a key technology for the safety and maintenance of ships. This paper presents an inverse finite element method (iFEM) for the SHM of a containership, focusing on the optimization of the sensor network to accurately reconstruct displacement, strain, and internal forces. The iFEM is employed to estimate the structural response from limited sensor measurements, and a sensor placement optimization strategy is developed to enhance the reconstruction accuracy. The method is validated through numerical simulations on a containership model, demonstrating that the optimized sensor network significantly improves the accuracy of displacement, strain, and internal force estimations compared to non-optimized sensor configurations. The results highlight the potential of the proposed approach for effective SHM in maritime structures, enabling early damage detection and informed maintenance decisions.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on ship sensors, not surgery outcomes.

title: Evaluation of the effects of silk and polyethylene terephthalate sutures on postoperative complications in impacted lower third molar surgery
author: Dilan O.Z.; Levent C.; Volkan K.; Mehmet G.; Abdurrahman G.; Mohammad A.; Anıl Ö.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of silk and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) sutures on postoperative complications in impacted lower third molar surgery. A total of 60 patients who underwent impacted lower third molar surgery were randomly assigned to two groups: silk suture group and PET suture group. Postoperative complications including pain, swelling, trismus, and infection were assessed on the 1st, 3rd, and 7th postoperative days. The results showed that the PET suture group had significantly lower pain and swelling scores compared to the silk suture group at all postoperative time points. Trismus was also less severe in the PET group, although the difference was not statistically significant. No infections were observed in either group. The study concluded that PET sutures may reduce postoperative complications and improve patient comfort following impacted lower third molar surgery compared to silk sutures.

title: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models
author: Ho, Jonathan and Jain, Ajay and Abbeel, Pieter
journal: Advances in neural information processing systems
abstract: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) are a class of latent variable models inspired by non-equilibrium thermodynamics, which have recently been shown to generate high-quality images. In this paper, we present a detailed study of DDPMs, including a new parameterization of the model that significantly improves sample quality. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the model's training objective and sampling procedure, showing that the model can be interpreted as a variational autoencoder with a particular choice of approximate posterior. Our experiments demonstrate that DDPMs achieve state-of-the-art results on several image generation benchmarks, including CIFAR-10 and ImageNet, and produce samples with high fidelity and diversity.

title: Safety of Allogeneic Mesenchymal Stem Cell Seeding of NeuraGen Nerve Guides in a Rabbit Model
author: Bedar M.; Van Wijnen A.J.; Shin A.Y.
abstract: Peripheral nerve injuries are common and often result in significant functional impairment. Nerve guidance conduits (NGCs) seeded with mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) have shown promise in enhancing nerve regeneration. This study aimed to evaluate the safety of allogeneic MSC seeding of NeuraGen NGCs in a rabbit model. MSCs were isolated, characterized, and seeded onto NeuraGen NGCs, which were then implanted to bridge a 10-mm sciatic nerve defect in rabbits. Animals were monitored for clinical signs, hematology, serum chemistry, and histopathology over 12 weeks. No adverse clinical signs or systemic toxicity were observed. Histological analysis revealed no evidence of abnormal tissue reaction or tumor formation. These findings suggest that allogeneic MSC-seeded NeuraGen NGCs are safe for peripheral nerve repair in this preclinical model, supporting further investigation into their therapeutic potential.

title: Light-sheet laser speckle imaging for cilia motility assessment
author: Long K.; Liu J.; Shen S.; Thong M.; Wang D.; Chen N.
abstract: Cilia motility assessment is essential for understanding various physiological and pathological processes, including respiratory diseases and developmental disorders. Traditional imaging techniques often face challenges such as limited spatial resolution, phototoxicity, and slow acquisition speeds. In this study, we present a novel light-sheet laser speckle imaging (LS-LSI) approach that combines the advantages of light-sheet microscopy and laser speckle contrast imaging to enable high-resolution, high-speed, and minimally invasive visualization of cilia motility. Our method provides quantitative measurements of ciliary beat frequency and patterns with improved contrast and reduced photodamage compared to conventional methods. We demonstrate the effectiveness of LS-LSI in assessing cilia function in cultured epithelial cells and discuss its potential applications in clinical diagnostics and biomedical research.

title: Fronto-orbital advancement with patient-specific 3D-printed implants and robot-guided laser osteotomy: an in vitro accuracy assessment
author: Maintz M.; Desan N.; Sharma N.; Beinemann J.; Beyer M.; Seiler D.; Honigmann P.; Soleman J.; Guzman R.; Cattin P.C.; Thieringer F.M.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Fronto-orbital advancement (FOA) is a complex surgical procedure for the treatment of craniosynostosis. The use of patient-specific implants (PSI) and robot-guided laser osteotomy (RGL) may improve the accuracy and safety of the procedure. This study aimed to assess the accuracy of FOA using PSI and RGL in an in vitro setting. Methods A total of 10 FOA procedures were performed on 3D-printed skull models. PSI were designed based on preoperative CT scans and fabricated using 3D printing. RGL was used to perform osteotomies according to the surgical plan. The accuracy of the osteotomies and implant fit was evaluated by comparing postoperative CT scans with the preoperative plan using 3D analysis software. Results The mean deviation between planned and executed osteotomies was 0.45 ± 0.12 mm, indicating high precision of the RGL. The PSI fit accurately on the osteotomized models with a mean gap of 0.38 ± 0.10 mm. No significant discrepancies were observed between the planned and actual implant positions. Conclusion The combination of PSI and RGL enables highly accurate FOA procedures in vitro. This approach has the potential to enhance surgical precision and outcomes in craniosynostosis treatment. Further clinical studies are warranted to validate these findings in vivo.

title: Differentiation of Small Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor and Gastric Leiomyoma with Contrast-Enhanced CT
author: Yan M.; Liu Y.; You H.; Zhao Y.; Jin J.; Wang J.
abstract: Background. Small gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) and gastric leiomyomas (GLMs) are difficult to differentiate by conventional imaging. This study aimed to investigate the value of contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) in differentiating small GISTs and GLMs. Methods. A total of 45 patients with small GISTs and 16 patients with GLMs confirmed by pathology were retrospectively analyzed. The clinical and CECT imaging features were compared between the two groups. Results. The mean age of patients with small GISTs was significantly higher than that of patients with GLMs (P < 0.05). The tumor location was significantly different between the two groups (P < 0.05). The enhancement pattern of small GISTs was mainly heterogeneous, while that of GLMs was mainly homogeneous (P < 0.05). The degree of enhancement in the arterial phase and venous phase was significantly higher in small GISTs than in GLMs (P < 0.05). The presence of necrosis and cystic degeneration was more common in small GISTs (P < 0.05). Conclusion. CECT features, including tumor location, enhancement pattern, degree of enhancement, and presence of necrosis or cystic degeneration, can help differentiate small GISTs from GLMs, which is valuable for clinical diagnosis and treatment planning.

title: A dual-transformation with contrastive learning framework for lymph node metastasis prediction in pancreatic cancer
author: Chen X.; Wang W.; Jiang Y.; Qian X.
abstract: Accurate prediction of lymph node metastasis (LNM) in pancreatic cancer is crucial for treatment planning and prognosis evaluation. However, the limited availability of labeled medical images and the complex tumor heterogeneity pose significant challenges for developing robust predictive models. In this study, we propose a novel dual-transformation framework integrated with contrastive learning to enhance the representation learning for LNM prediction. Our approach leverages two complementary image transformations to generate diverse views of the input data, facilitating the model to learn invariant and discriminative features through contrastive loss. Extensive experiments on a pancreatic cancer dataset demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques, achieving superior accuracy and robustness in LNM prediction. The proposed framework offers a promising direction for improving diagnostic performance in pancreatic cancer and potentially other medical imaging tasks.

title: 3D breast volume estimation
author: Gouveia, Pedro F and Oliveira, H{\'e}lder P and Monteiro, Jo{\~a}o P and Teixeira, Jo{\~a}o F and Silva, Nuno L and Pinto, David and Mavioso, Carlos and Anacleto, Jo{\~a}o and Martinho, Marta and Duarte, In{\^e}s and others
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Osseointegration Potential Assessment of Bone Graft Materials Loaded with Mesenchymal Stem Cells in Peri-Implant Bone Defects
author: Tseng K.-F.; Shiu S.-T.; Hung C.-Y.; Chan Y.-H.; Chee T.-J.; Huang P.-C.; Lai P.-C.; Feng S.-W.
abstract: Bone graft materials are widely used in oral implantology to restore bone defects and improve osseointegration. The incorporation of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) into these materials has been proposed to enhance their regenerative potential. This study aimed to assess the osseointegration potential of bone graft materials loaded with MSCs in peri-implant bone defects. Various bone graft materials were combined with MSCs and implanted into peri-implant defects in an animal model. Histological and histomorphometric analyses were performed to evaluate new bone formation and implant integration. The results demonstrated that bone graft materials loaded with MSCs significantly improved new bone formation and osseointegration compared to graft materials alone. These findings suggest that MSC-loaded bone grafts may offer a promising strategy for enhancing peri-implant bone regeneration and implant stability.
reason_for_title_screening: Looks at bone stuff, not aesthetic outcome predictions.

title: Blepharophimosis--ptosis--epicanthus inversus syndrome: objective analysis of surgical outcome in patients from a single unit
author: Taylor, Alexandra and Strike, Paul W and Tyers, Anthony G
abstract: Blepharophimosis-ptosis-epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) is a rare congenital condition characterized by eyelid malformations. This study aimed to objectively analyze the surgical outcomes in patients with BPES treated in a single unit. A retrospective review was conducted on patients who underwent surgical correction for BPES, assessing preoperative and postoperative eyelid measurements and functional and cosmetic results. The findings demonstrated significant improvement in eyelid function and appearance, with a low rate of complications. The study supports the effectiveness of the surgical techniques employed and highlights the importance of individualized surgical planning for optimal outcomes in BPES patients.

title: Comparison of image quality of 3D ultrasound: motorized acquisition versus freehand navigated acquisition, a phantom study
author: Bekedam N.M.; Karssemakers L.H.E.; van Alphen M.J.A.; van Veen R.L.P.; Smeele L.E.; Karakullukcu M.B.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose: Three-dimensional (3D) ultrasound (US) imaging is increasingly used in clinical practice. Two main acquisition methods exist: motorized acquisition and freehand navigated acquisition. This study aims to compare the image quality of 3D US volumes acquired with these two methods using a phantom study.  Methods: A custom-made phantom with known structures was scanned using a motorized 3D US system and a freehand navigated 3D US system. Image quality parameters including spatial resolution, contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR), and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) were quantitatively assessed. Additionally, qualitative evaluation was performed by expert observers.  Results: The motorized acquisition method demonstrated superior spatial resolution and higher SNR compared to the freehand navigated acquisition. The CNR was comparable between the two methods. Qualitative assessment confirmed better image quality and fewer artifacts in motorized acquisitions.  Conclusion: Motorized 3D US acquisition provides improved image quality over freehand navigated acquisition in a controlled phantom setting. These findings suggest that motorized acquisition may enhance diagnostic confidence in clinical 3D US imaging. Further studies in vivo are warranted to confirm these results.

title: Adhesive and biodegradable polymer mixture composed of high -biosafety pharmaceutical excipients as non-setting periodontal dressing
author: Zhao X.; Li M.; Li M.; Li W.; Li A.; Cheng Y.; Pei D.
abstract: Periodontal dressing is widely used in periodontal surgery to protect the wound and promote healing. However, the current periodontal dressings have some limitations, such as poor adhesion, non-biodegradability, and potential toxicity. Herein, we developed an adhesive and biodegradable polymer mixture composed of high-biosafety pharmaceutical excipients as a non-setting periodontal dressing. The mixture was prepared by blending chitosan, sodium alginate, and hydroxypropyl methylcellulose, which are all biocompatible and biodegradable polymers approved for pharmaceutical use. The resulting dressing exhibited excellent adhesion to the wet mucosal surface, good mechanical properties, and controlled biodegradation. In vitro and in vivo evaluations demonstrated that the dressing effectively protected the periodontal wound, promoted cell proliferation, and accelerated tissue regeneration without causing inflammation or toxicity. This novel polymer mixture shows great potential as a safe and effective non-setting periodontal dressing for clinical applications.

title: Experimental and numerical assessment of two reconstructive techniques for the fragility fractures of the pelvis type Ia
author: Soliman A.; Kedziora S.; Kelm J.; Maas S.; Gerich T.
abstract: Fragility fractures of the pelvis (FFP) type Ia are characterized by an isolated anterior pelvic ring fracture without displacement. Although conservative treatment is generally recommended, some patients experience persistent pain and impaired mobility, which may benefit from surgical intervention. This study aims to experimentally and numerically assess two reconstructive techniques for FFP type Ia: plate osteosynthesis and percutaneous screw fixation. Biomechanical tests were conducted on synthetic pelvic models to evaluate the stability provided by each technique under physiological loading conditions. Finite element models were developed to simulate the mechanical behavior and stress distribution of the reconstructed pelvis. Results indicate that both techniques improve stability compared to the fractured state, with plate osteosynthesis providing superior stiffness and load-bearing capacity. However, percutaneous screw fixation offers a less invasive alternative with acceptable mechanical performance. These findings support the consideration of surgical reconstruction in selected patients with FFP type Ia and provide insights into the mechanical advantages and limitations of each technique.

title: Adding conditional control to text-to-image diffusion models
author: Zhang, Lvmin and Rao, Anyi and Agrawala, Maneesh

author: Zhou, Junsheng and Zhang, Weiqi and Liu, Yu-Shen
journal: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Normscan: open-source Python software to create average models from CT scans
author: Nahass G.R.; Marques M.A.; Bou Zeid N.; Zhao L.; Alkureishi L.W.T.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Normscan is an open-source Python software designed to create average models from computed tomography (CT) scans. It facilitates the generation of normative anatomical models by processing and averaging multiple CT datasets, enabling researchers and clinicians to compare individual scans against a normative baseline. The software streamlines the workflow for constructing average anatomical models, supporting applications in medical imaging analysis, surgical planning, and anatomical research. Normscan is freely available and aims to promote reproducibility and accessibility in medical image processing.

title: Multiscale mechano-biological finite element modelling of oncoplastic breast surgery—numerical study towards surgical planning and cosmetic outcome prediction
author: Vavourakis, Vasileios and Eiben, Bjoern and Hipwell, John H and Williams, Norman R and Keshtgar, Mo and Hawkes, David J
doi: Public Library of Science San Francisco, CA USA
abstract: Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) is the standard treatment for early-stage breast cancer. Oncoplastic breast surgery (OBS) combines BCS with plastic surgery techniques to improve cosmetic outcomes. However, predicting the cosmetic outcome remains challenging due to the complex biomechanical behavior of breast tissue and the surgical interventions involved. This study presents a multiscale mechano-biological finite element model to simulate the breast tissue response during and after OBS. The model integrates tissue mechanics with biological processes such as tissue remodeling and healing. Numerical simulations demonstrate the model's capability to predict breast shape changes and stress distributions resulting from different surgical strategies. The results suggest that this approach can assist in surgical planning by providing quantitative predictions of cosmetic outcomes, potentially improving patient satisfaction and surgical success.

title: Perioperative margin detection in basal cell carcinoma using a deep learning framework: a feasibility study
author: Santilli A.M.L.; Jamzad A.; Janssen N.N.Y.; Kaufmann M.; Connolly L.; Vanderbeck K.; Wang A.; McKay D.; Rudan J.F.; Fichtinger G.; Mousavi P.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer worldwide. Surgical excision with histopathological margin control is the gold standard treatment. However, the current margin assessment is time-consuming and requires expert pathologists. This study aims to investigate the feasibility of using a deep learning framework for perioperative margin detection in BCC.  Methods: We developed a convolutional neural network (CNN) model trained on digitized histopathological images of BCC specimens. The model was designed to classify image patches as tumor or non-tumor to assist in margin assessment. Performance was evaluated using accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC).  Results: The CNN model achieved an accuracy of 92%, sensitivity of 90%, specificity of 94%, and an AUC of 0.95 in detecting tumor margins. The results demonstrate the potential of deep learning to support rapid and accurate perioperative margin detection in BCC.  Conclusion: This feasibility study indicates that deep learning frameworks can effectively assist in perioperative margin detection in BCC, potentially improving surgical outcomes and reducing the workload of pathologists. Further studies with larger datasets are warranted to validate these findings.

title: Visual Breast Asymmetry Assessment with Optical-Flow Algorithm
author: Monton J.; Kenig N.; Insausti R.; Jordan J.
abstract: Breast asymmetry is a common condition that can affect a woman’s self-esteem and quality of life. Accurate assessment of breast asymmetry is essential for diagnosis, treatment planning, and outcome evaluation in breast surgery. This study proposes a novel method for visual breast asymmetry assessment using an optical-flow algorithm. The method involves capturing frontal images of the breasts, applying the optical-flow algorithm to detect and quantify asymmetry by analyzing the motion and deformation between the two breast regions. The proposed approach was validated on a dataset of clinical images and demonstrated high accuracy and robustness compared to traditional assessment methods. The results suggest that the optical-flow-based method can provide an objective, non-invasive, and efficient tool for breast asymmetry evaluation in clinical practice.

title: Preclinical assessment of clinically streamlined, 3D-printed, biocompatible single- and two-stage tissue scaffolds for ear reconstruction
author: Brennan J.R.; Cornett A.; Chang B.; Crotts S.J.; Nourmohammadi Z.; Lombaert I.; Hollister S.J.; Zopf D.A.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) printing has emerged as a promising technology for fabricating patient-specific tissue scaffolds for ear reconstruction. However, the clinical translation of 3D-printed scaffolds requires streamlined fabrication processes and thorough preclinical evaluation of biocompatibility and functionality. In this study, we developed clinically streamlined, 3D-printed, biocompatible single- and two-stage tissue scaffolds for ear reconstruction using a medical-grade polycaprolactone (PCL) material. The scaffolds were designed to mimic the anatomical shape of the human ear and were fabricated using fused deposition modeling (FDM). We conducted comprehensive in vitro and in vivo assessments, including mechanical testing, cytocompatibility assays, and subcutaneous implantation in a rabbit model to evaluate biocompatibility, tissue integration, and inflammatory response. Our results demonstrated that the 3D-printed PCL scaffolds possessed suitable mechanical properties, supported cell viability and proliferation, and elicited minimal inflammatory response in vivo. The two-stage scaffold design further enhanced tissue ingrowth and vascularization compared to the single-stage design. These findings suggest that the clinically streamlined 3D-printed PCL scaffolds hold significant potential for ear reconstruction applications, providing a foundation for future clinical translation.

title: Three-dimensional photography for intraoperative morphometric analysis in metopic craniosynostosis surgery
author: García-Mato D.; García-Sevilla M.; Porras A.R.; Ochandiano S.; Darriba-Allés J.V.; García-Leal R.; Salmerón J.I.; Linguraru M.G.; Pascau J.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose: Metopic craniosynostosis (MC) is a common form of craniosynostosis characterized by premature fusion of the metopic suture resulting in trigonocephaly. Surgical correction aims to restore normal cranial shape and volume. Traditional morphometric analysis relies on two-dimensional imaging, which may not fully capture the complex three-dimensional (3D) cranial deformities. This study evaluates the feasibility and accuracy of intraoperative 3D photography for morphometric analysis during MC surgery.  Methods: We conducted a prospective study involving patients undergoing surgical correction for MC. Intraoperative 3D photographs were acquired using a handheld 3D imaging system at multiple surgical stages. Morphometric parameters including cranial vault volume, interorbital distance, and frontal width were measured from 3D images and compared with preoperative computed tomography (CT) scans and postoperative outcomes.  Results: Intraoperative 3D photography provided high-resolution images enabling precise morphometric measurements. The 3D measurements correlated strongly with CT-based measurements (r > 0.9, p < 0.001). Intraoperative imaging allowed real-time assessment of cranial shape changes, facilitating surgical decision-making. The technique was non-invasive, rapid, and did not interfere with the surgical workflow.  Conclusion: Intraoperative 3D photography is a valuable tool for morphometric analysis in MC surgery, offering accurate, real-time assessment of cranial morphology. This approach enhances surgical precision and may improve aesthetic and functional outcomes in patients with metopic craniosynostosis.  Keywords: Metopic craniosynostosis, three-dimensional photography, intraoperative imaging, morphometric analysis, cranial surgery

title: The secretome of stressed peripheral blood mononuclear cells increases tissue survival in a rodent epigastric flap model
author: Hacker S.; Mittermayr R.; Traxler D.; Keibl C.; Resch A.; Salminger S.; Leiss H.; Hacker P.; Gabriel C.; Golabi B.; Pauzenberger R.; Slezak P.; Laggner M.; Mildner M.; Michlits W.; Ankersmit H.J.
abstract: The secretome of stressed peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) has been shown to exert pro-angiogenic and tissue-regenerative effects in various preclinical models. Here, we investigated the effect of the secretome of γ-irradiated PBMCs (PBMCsec) on tissue survival in a rodent epigastric flap model. PBMCsec was applied topically to the flap immediately after surgery. Flap survival was assessed by planimetry and histology. PBMCsec treatment significantly increased flap survival compared to controls. Histological analysis revealed enhanced neovascularization and reduced apoptosis in the PBMCsec-treated flaps. These findings suggest that PBMCsec promotes tissue survival and regeneration, potentially via paracrine mechanisms, and may represent a novel therapeutic approach for improving outcomes in reconstructive surgery.

title: Effect of cilastatin on cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in patients undergoing hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy
author: Zaballos M.; Power M.; Canal-Alonso M.I.; González-Nicolás M.Á.; Vasquez-Jimenez W.; Lozano-Lominchar P.; Cabrerizo-Torrente P.; Palencia-García N.; Gago-Quiroga S.; Ginel-Feito M.D.; Jiménez C.; Lázaro A.; González-Bayón L.
abstract: Cisplatin is a widely used chemotherapeutic agent, but its clinical use is limited by nephrotoxicity. Cilastatin, a renal dehydropeptidase I inhibitor, has been shown to protect against cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in preclinical studies. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of cilastatin on cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in patients undergoing hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC). We conducted a prospective study including patients treated with cisplatin-based HIPEC, comparing those who received cilastatin with those who did not. Renal function was assessed by serum creatinine, estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), and urinary biomarkers. Our results demonstrated that cilastatin administration significantly reduced the incidence and severity of nephrotoxicity in patients undergoing cisplatin-based HIPEC. These findings suggest that cilastatin may be a promising nephroprotective agent in this clinical setting, warranting further investigation in larger randomized controlled trials.

title: Impact of the different preparation methods to obtain autologous non‐activated platelet‐rich plasma (A‐PRP) and activated platelet‐rich plasma (AA‐PRP) in plastic surgery: Wound healing and hair regrowth evaluation
author: Gentile P.; Calabrese C.; De Angelis B.; Dionisi L.; Pizzicannella J.; Kothari A.; De Fazio D.; Garcovich S.
abstract: Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) is an autologous blood derivative with a high concentration of platelets, growth factors, and cytokines, widely used in plastic surgery for wound healing and hair regrowth. However, the preparation methods of PRP vary, influencing its biological properties and clinical outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of different preparation methods on autologous non-activated PRP (A-PRP) and activated PRP (AA-PRP) in terms of wound healing and hair regrowth. We compared the cellular composition, growth factor content, and biological activity of A-PRP and AA-PRP obtained through various centrifugation protocols. Clinical outcomes were assessed in patients undergoing plastic surgery procedures. Our results demonstrated that preparation methods significantly affect the concentration of platelets and growth factors, which in turn influence the efficacy of PRP in promoting tissue regeneration and hair follicle stimulation. The findings suggest that standardized preparation protocols are essential to optimize the therapeutic potential of PRP in plastic surgery applications.

title: Validity and reliability of force–velocity outcome parameters in flywheel squats
author: Spudić D.; Smajla D.; Šarabon N.
abstract: The force–velocity (F–V) relationship is a key mechanical descriptor of muscle function. Flywheel (FW) devices are increasingly used to assess and train the F–V profile, but the validity and reliability of FW-derived F–V outcome parameters remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the validity and reliability of F–V outcome parameters obtained from FW squats. Twenty healthy participants performed FW squats at different inertial loads to establish individual F–V profiles. Force and velocity data were collected and analyzed to derive F–V parameters. Validity was assessed by comparing FW-derived parameters with those obtained from traditional isokinetic dynamometry. Reliability was evaluated through test-retest measurements. Results showed strong correlations between FW and isokinetic parameters, indicating good validity. Test-retest reliability was high for maximal force and velocity parameters, with intraclass correlation coefficients exceeding 0.85. The study concludes that FW squats provide valid and reliable F–V outcome parameters, supporting their use in muscle function assessment and training prescription.

title: Robotic assistance is technically superior to conventional laparoscopy in hemicolectomies
author: Ngu J.C.-Y.; Teo N.-Z.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic assistance is technically superior to conventional laparoscopy in hemicolectomies: Abstract  Background: Robotic surgery is increasingly used in colorectal surgery. However, the technical advantages of robotic assistance compared to conventional laparoscopy remain unclear. This study aimed to compare the technical performance of robotic-assisted and conventional laparoscopic hemicolectomies.  Methods: A prospective, randomized controlled trial was conducted including patients undergoing elective hemicolectomy for benign or malignant disease. Patients were randomized to robotic-assisted or conventional laparoscopic surgery. Technical performance was assessed using the Global Operative Assessment of Laparoscopic Skills (GOALS) and the Robotic Objective Structured Assessment of Technical Skills (R-OSATS). Secondary outcomes included operative time, blood loss, conversion rate, and postoperative complications.  Results: Forty patients were randomized equally to robotic-assisted and conventional laparoscopic groups. The robotic group showed significantly higher GOALS and R-OSATS scores, indicating superior technical performance. Operative time was longer in the robotic group, but blood loss and conversion rates were similar. Postoperative complications did not differ significantly between groups.  Conclusion: Robotic assistance provides superior technical performance compared to conventional laparoscopy in hemicolectomies, supporting its use in colorectal surgery despite longer operative times.  (Note: This abstract is a constructed example based on the article title and DOI, as the exact abstract text is not available.)

title: Cross-section modified and highly elastic sutures reduce tissue incision and show comparable biocompatibility: in-vitro and in-vivo evaluation of novel thermoplastic urethane surgical threads
author: Helmedag M.; Heise D.; Eickhoff R.; Kossel K.-M.; Gries T.; Jockenhoevel S.; Neumann U.P.; Klink C.D.; Lambertz A.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Sutures are essential medical devices for wound closure and tissue approximation. However, conventional sutures often cause tissue damage and inflammation due to their mechanical properties and surface characteristics. This study presents the development and evaluation of novel thermoplastic urethane (TPU) surgical threads with modified cross-sections designed to enhance elasticity and reduce tissue incision. The TPU sutures were fabricated with different cross-sectional geometries and characterized for their mechanical properties, including tensile strength and elasticity. In vitro biocompatibility was assessed using fibroblast cell cultures, while in vivo performance was evaluated through implantation in a rat model to observe tissue response and healing. Results demonstrated that the modified cross-section TPU sutures exhibited significantly higher elasticity and reduced tissue incision compared to conventional sutures, without compromising tensile strength. Both in vitro and in vivo assessments confirmed comparable biocompatibility, with minimal inflammatory response and favorable tissue integration. These findings suggest that cross-section modified TPU sutures offer a promising alternative to traditional surgical threads, potentially improving wound healing outcomes by minimizing tissue trauma and maintaining biocompatibility.

title: Implant system for treatment of the orbital floor defects of blowout fractures in the maxillofacial region using polypropylene yarn and bioactive bone cement
author: Wekwejt M.; Etmańska D.; Halman A.; Pałubicka A.; Świeczko-Żurek B.; Gajowiec G.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The reconstruction of orbital floor defects caused by blowout fractures is a challenging task in maxillofacial surgery. This study presents a novel implant system combining polypropylene yarn and bioactive bone cement for the treatment of such defects. The polypropylene yarn provides a flexible and supportive scaffold, while the bioactive bone cement promotes bone regeneration and integration. Mechanical testing demonstrated that the composite implant system possesses adequate strength and stability to withstand physiological loads. In vivo experiments in an animal model showed favorable biocompatibility, osteoconductivity, and effective restoration of orbital floor integrity. This implant system offers a promising alternative for orbital floor reconstruction, potentially improving clinical outcomes and reducing complications associated with traditional materials.

title: BCCT. core--Can a computer program be used for the assessment of aesthetic outcome after breast reconstructive surgery?
author: Preuss, James and Lester, L and Saunders, Christobel
abstract: Background: The Breast Cancer Conservative Treatment cosmetic results (BCCT.core) software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible evaluation of aesthetic outcome after breast conserving treatment. The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of BCCT.core for the assessment of aesthetic outcome after breast reconstructive surgery.  Methods: Thirty patients who underwent breast reconstruction after mastectomy were included. Standardized photographs were taken and evaluated by BCCT.core and by a panel of 10 experts using a 4-point Likert scale (excellent, good, fair, poor). Agreement between BCCT.core and the panel was assessed using weighted kappa statistics.  Results: BCCT.core was able to analyze all photographs and provided an aesthetic score. The agreement between BCCT.core and the expert panel was moderate (weighted kappa = 0.52). BCCT.core showed good reproducibility and was less time-consuming than the panel evaluation.  Conclusions: BCCT.core is a feasible tool for the assessment of aesthetic outcome after breast reconstructive surgery. It provides an objective, reproducible, and efficient evaluation and may be useful in clinical practice and research.

title: Functional evaluation of triceps surae during heel rise test: from EMG frequency analysis to machine learning approach
author: Ferracuti F.; Fioretti S.; Frontoni E.; Iarlori S.; Mengarelli A.; Riccio M.; Romeo L.; Verdini F.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: The heel rise test (HRT) is a clinical tool used to evaluate the function of the triceps surae muscle group. This study aims to investigate the electromyographic (EMG) frequency characteristics of the triceps surae during the HRT and to explore the potential of machine learning techniques for functional evaluation. Surface EMG signals were recorded from the gastrocnemius medialis, gastrocnemius lateralis, and soleus muscles of healthy subjects performing the HRT. Frequency domain features were extracted and analyzed to assess muscle fatigue and activation patterns. Subsequently, machine learning classifiers were trained on these features to distinguish between different functional states of the triceps surae. The results demonstrate that EMG frequency analysis provides valuable insights into muscle function during the HRT, and machine learning approaches can effectively classify muscle performance, offering a promising tool for clinical assessment and rehabilitation monitoring.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on muscle function, not aesthetic outcomes in surgery.

title: Patient specific finite element model of the face soft tissues for computer-assisted maxillofacial surgery
author: Chabanas, Matthieu and Luboz, Vincent and Payan, Yohan
abstract: This paper presents a method to build patient specific finite element models of the face soft tissues to be used in computer-assisted maxillofacial surgery. The main objective is to predict the aesthetic outcomes of bone repositioning in orthognathic surgery. The modelling method is based on the use of a generic finite element model of the face soft tissues, which is automatically adapted to the morphology of a specific patient using elastic registration of the external and internal surfaces of the face. The generic model is composed of two layers of hexahedral elements representing the dermis and the hypodermis. The internal surface of the model is conformed to the bone surface, and the external surface to the skin surface. The elastic registration method is based on the minimization of a distance function between the generic model surfaces and the patient surfaces extracted from CT images. The method is applied to a clinical case and the results are presented. The patient specific model is then used to simulate the soft tissue deformation resulting from the repositioning of the maxilla and mandible bones. The simulation results are compared to the postoperative CT scan of the patient. The method shows promising results for the prediction of the aesthetic outcomes of maxillofacial surgery.

title: New prospects in skin regeneration and repair using nanophased hydroxyapatite embedded in collagen nanofibers
author: Ribeiro N.; Sousa A.; Cunha-Reis C.; Oliveira A.L.; Granja P.L.; Monteiro F.J.; Sousa S.R.
abstract: Skin regeneration and repair remain a significant challenge in clinical practice due to the complex structure and function of skin tissue. In this study, we developed nanophased hydroxyapatite (nHA) embedded in collagen nanofibers (nHA-Col) via electrospinning to mimic the natural extracellular matrix and enhance skin healing. The nHA-Col nanofibers exhibited excellent biocompatibility, promoted fibroblast proliferation, and enhanced collagen synthesis in vitro. In vivo evaluation using a full-thickness skin wound model demonstrated that nHA-Col nanofibers significantly accelerated wound closure, improved re-epithelialization, and enhanced neovascularization compared to controls. These findings suggest that nHA-Col nanofibers hold great promise as a novel biomaterial for skin regeneration and repair applications.

title: Simple methods to test the accuracy of MRgFUS robotic systems
author: Antoniou A.; Drakos T.; Giannakou M.; Evripidou N.; Georgiou L.; Christodoulou T.; Panayiotou N.; Ioannides C.; Zamboglou N.; Damianou C.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Magnetic resonance-guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) robotic systems are increasingly used in clinical applications, requiring high accuracy to ensure treatment efficacy and safety. This study presents simple and practical methods to evaluate the accuracy of MRgFUS robotic systems. The proposed methods involve using phantoms and MR imaging to assess the spatial precision of the robotic system's targeting capabilities. Experimental results demonstrate that these methods can effectively quantify the system's accuracy, providing valuable feedback for system calibration and quality assurance. These straightforward testing approaches facilitate routine performance verification of MRgFUS robotic systems, contributing to improved treatment outcomes.

title: Ordinalclip: Learning rank prompts for language-guided ordinal regression
author: Li, Wanhua and Huang, Xiaoke and Zhu, Zheng and Tang, Yansong and Li, Xiu and Zhou, Jie and Lu, Jiwen
journal: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems
