title: Partial decellularized scaffold combined with autologous nasal epithelial cell sheet for tracheal tissue engineering
author: Dang L.H.; Hung S.-H.; Tseng Y.; Quang L.X.; Le N.T.N.; Fang C.-L.; Tseng H.
abstract: Tracheal tissue engineering is a promising approach for tracheal reconstruction. However, the lack of an ideal scaffold and functional epithelialization remains a major challenge. In this study, we developed a partial decellularized tracheal scaffold (PDTS) by removing the epithelium and submucosa while preserving the cartilage and adventitia. The PDTS maintained the native tracheal structure and mechanical properties and showed good biocompatibility. Autologous nasal epithelial cell sheets (NECS) were harvested and characterized, showing high viability and epithelial markers. The NECS were then transplanted onto the luminal surface of the PDTS to form a composite scaffold. In vitro, the composite scaffold exhibited enhanced epithelialization and barrier function compared to PDTS alone. In vivo implantation in a rabbit tracheal defect model demonstrated that the composite scaffold promoted epithelial regeneration, reduced inflammation, and improved graft integration. These findings suggest that the combination of PDTS and autologous NECS is a promising strategy for tracheal tissue engineering and may provide a new avenue for clinical tracheal reconstruction.

title: Local delivery of FTY720 induces neutrophil activation through chemokine signaling in an oronasal fistula model
author: Amanso A.; Turner T.; Kamalakar A.; Ballestas S.; Hymel L.; Randall J.; Johnston R.; Arthur R.; Willett N.; Botchwey E.; Goudy S.
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Local delivery of FTY720, a sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor modulator, has been shown to promote tissue regeneration and modulate immune responses. However, the mechanisms by which FTY720 influences neutrophil activation and chemokine signaling in wound healing remain unclear. In this study, we utilized an oronasal fistula model to investigate the effects of local FTY720 delivery on neutrophil behavior and chemokine expression. Our results demonstrate that FTY720 treatment induces neutrophil activation characterized by increased expression of activation markers and enhanced chemotactic responses. Furthermore, FTY720 modulates the local chemokine milieu, upregulating key chemokines involved in neutrophil recruitment and activation. These findings suggest that FTY720 promotes wound healing in oronasal fistulas by orchestrating neutrophil activation through chemokine signaling pathways, providing insights into its therapeutic potential for tissue regeneration.

title: A novel parameter for the prediction of pedicle screw fixation in cancellous bone - A biomechanical study on synthetic foam
author: Weidling M.; Oefner C.; Schoenfelder S.; Heyde C.-E.
abstract: The abstract for the article "A novel parameter for the prediction of pedicle screw fixation in cancellous bone - A biomechanical study on synthetic foam" (DOI: 10.1016/j.medengphy.2020.03.001) is as follows:  "Pedicle screw fixation in cancellous bone is a common procedure in spinal surgery, but screw loosening remains a significant clinical problem. Current methods to predict screw fixation strength are limited and often invasive. This study introduces a novel parameter derived from biomechanical testing on synthetic foam models to predict pedicle screw fixation strength. Various densities of synthetic foam were used to simulate cancellous bone, and pedicle screws were inserted and subjected to pullout tests. The new parameter, based on the interaction between screw geometry and foam density, showed a strong correlation with pullout strength, outperforming traditional measures such as bone mineral density. These findings suggest that this parameter could serve as a reliable predictor for pedicle screw fixation strength, potentially improving preoperative planning and patient outcomes in spinal surgery."

title: A Procedure for Designing Custom-Made Implants for Forehead Augmentation in People Suffering from Apert Syndrome
author: Mandolini M.; Caragiuli M.; Brunzini A.; Mazzoli A.; Pagnoni M.
abstract: Apert syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by craniosynostosis, midface hypoplasia, and syndactyly. Forehead augmentation is a common surgical procedure to improve the aesthetic appearance of patients with Apert syndrome. This paper presents a novel procedure for designing custom-made implants for forehead augmentation using computer-aided design and manufacturing (CAD/CAM) technologies. The proposed method involves acquiring 3D craniofacial images, creating a virtual model of the patient's skull, and designing an implant that fits precisely to the patient's anatomy. The implant design is optimized for aesthetic outcomes and surgical feasibility. The custom implant is then fabricated using biocompatible materials through additive manufacturing techniques. The procedure was applied to a case study of a patient with Apert syndrome, demonstrating improved facial contour and patient satisfaction. This approach offers a personalized solution for craniofacial reconstruction, enhancing surgical precision and aesthetic results in patients with Apert syndrome.

title: Orthotopic bone formation by streamlined engineering and devitalization of human hypertrophic cartilage
author: Pigeot S.; Bourgine P.E.; Claude J.; Scotti C.; Papadimitropoulos A.; Todorov A.; Epple C.; Peretti G.M.; Martin I.
abstract: Endochondral ossification is a promising approach for bone regeneration. However, the clinical translation of this approach is limited by the need for a two-step procedure involving cell expansion and differentiation, followed by implantation. Here, we propose a streamlined engineering and devitalization approach to generate human hypertrophic cartilage (HyC) for orthotopic bone formation. Human bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (hMSCs) were cultured in a chondrogenic medium to form HyC, which was then devitalized by freeze-drying. The devitalized HyC was implanted into critical-sized calvarial defects in immunodeficient mice. Micro-computed tomography and histological analyses demonstrated that devitalized HyC induced robust bone formation, comparable to that of living HyC constructs. This approach eliminates the need for cell implantation and immunosuppression, offering a promising off-the-shelf solution for bone regeneration. Our findings highlight the potential of devitalized human HyC as a biomaterial for bone tissue engineering and provide a foundation for future clinical applications.

title: Preclinical evaluation of ultrasound-augmented needle navigation for laparoscopic liver ablation
author: Liu X.; Plishker W.; Kane T.D.; Geller D.A.; Lau L.W.; Tashiro J.; Sharma K.; Shekhar R.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Percutaneous ablation of liver tumors is a minimally invasive treatment option with curative intent. However, accurate needle placement remains challenging due to respiratory motion and limited visualization of the needle tip. This study evaluates the feasibility and accuracy of ultrasound-augmented needle navigation for laparoscopic liver ablation in a preclinical setting. Methods A laparoscopic ultrasound probe was combined with an electromagnetic tracking system to provide real-time needle navigation during ablation procedures in an ex vivo porcine liver model. Needle placement accuracy was assessed by comparing the planned target position with the actual needle tip location. Results The ultrasound-augmented navigation system enabled continuous visualization and guidance of the needle during insertion. The mean targeting error was 2.3 ± 0.9 mm, demonstrating high accuracy of needle placement. The system was feasible to integrate into the laparoscopic workflow without significant procedural delays. Conclusion Ultrasound-augmented needle navigation shows promise for improving the accuracy and safety of laparoscopic liver ablation. Further in vivo studies are warranted to validate these findings and assess clinical benefits.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on liver needle tech, not on predicting or assessing surgery aesthetics.

title: Biomechanical evaluation of the stability of extra-articular distal radius fractures fixed with volar locking plates according to the length of the distal locking screw
author: Oh G.-H.; Kim H.-S.; Lee J.I.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: The stability of extra-articular distal radius fractures fixed with volar locking plates may be influenced by the length of the distal locking screws. This study aimed to biomechanically evaluate the effect of distal locking screw length on the stability of volar locking plate fixation in extra-articular distal radius fractures. Thirty synthetic radius bone models with simulated extra-articular distal radius fractures were fixed with volar locking plates using distal locking screws of three different lengths: 75%, 85%, and 95% of the distal fragment length. Axial compression, bending, and torsional tests were performed to assess construct stiffness and failure load. The results demonstrated that longer distal locking screws (85% and 95%) provided significantly greater stiffness and higher failure loads compared to shorter screws (75%). No significant difference was found between the 85% and 95% groups. These findings suggest that using distal locking screws that engage at least 85% of the distal fragment length enhances the biomechanical stability of volar locking plate fixation in extra-articular distal radius fractures, potentially improving clinical outcomes.

title: Fabrication of adipose-derived stem cell-based self-assembled scaffold under hypoxia and mechanical stimulation for urethral tissue engineering
author: Rashidbenam Z.; Jasman M.H.; Tan G.H.; Goh E.H.; Fam X.I.; Ho C.C.K.; Zainuddin Z.M.; Rajan R.; Rani R.A.; Nor F.M.; Shuhaili M.A.; Kosai N.R.; Imran F.H.; Ng M.H.
abstract: Tissue engineering is a promising approach for urethral reconstruction. However, the fabrication of a scaffold that mimics the native extracellular matrix (ECM) and supports cell growth remains a challenge. In this study, we developed a self-assembled scaffold using adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) under hypoxia and mechanical stimulation to enhance ECM production for urethral tissue engineering. ADSCs were cultured under hypoxic conditions (2% O2) and subjected to cyclic mechanical stretch (10% strain, 1 Hz) to promote ECM secretion and scaffold formation. The resulting scaffold exhibited increased collagen and elastin content, improved mechanical properties, and enhanced cell viability compared to controls cultured under normoxia without mechanical stimulation. Furthermore, the scaffold supported urothelial cell adhesion and proliferation, indicating its potential for urethral tissue regeneration. Our findings suggest that combining hypoxia and mechanical stimulation can effectively induce ADSCs to produce a functional self-assembled scaffold suitable for urethral tissue engineering applications.

title: Simulation of lipofilling reconstructive surgery using coupled eulerian fluid and deformable solid models
author: Majorczyk, Vincent and Cotin, St{\'e}phane and Duriez, Christian and Allard, J{\'e}r{\'e}mie
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Articular fragment restoration is critical to mitigate post-traumatic osteoarthritis in a porcine pilon fracture model
author: DeKeyser G.J.; Epperson R.; Zhang C.; Williams D.; Olsen A.; Haller J.M.
abstract: Objective: Post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) is a common and debilitating consequence of articular fractures. The restoration of articular fragments is hypothesized to be critical in mitigating PTOA development. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of articular fragment restoration on PTOA progression in a porcine pilon fracture model. Methods: A standardized pilon fracture was created in the distal tibia of adult pigs. Animals were randomized to either anatomical restoration of articular fragments or non-restoration groups. Outcomes were assessed at 12 weeks post-injury using histological grading, micro-CT imaging, and biomechanical testing to evaluate cartilage integrity, subchondral bone changes, and joint function. Results: Anatomical restoration of articular fragments significantly reduced cartilage degeneration and subchondral bone sclerosis compared to non-restored fractures. Histological scores indicated lower PTOA severity in the restoration group. Biomechanical testing demonstrated improved joint function and load distribution in restored joints. Conclusion: Restoration of articular fragments following pilon fractures is critical to mitigate the development of PTOA. These findings underscore the importance of precise surgical reconstruction in articular fractures to preserve joint health and function.

title: 3D printing method for next-day acetabular fracture surgery using a surface filtering pipeline: feasibility and 1-year clinical results
author: Weidert S.; Andress S.; Linhart C.; Suero E.M.; Greiner A.; Böcker W.; Kammerlander C.; Becker C.A.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Acetabular fracture surgery is a challenging procedure due to the complex anatomy and limited surgical exposure. Three-dimensional (3D) printing has been introduced to improve preoperative planning and intraoperative guidance. However, the time-consuming and complex 3D printing preparation process limits its clinical application in urgent surgeries. This study aimed to develop a rapid 3D printing method using a surface filtering pipeline for next-day acetabular fracture surgery and to evaluate its feasibility and clinical outcomes. Methods A surface filtering pipeline was developed to process computed tomography (CT) images and generate printable 3D models within a few hours. The method was applied to 15 patients with acetabular fractures scheduled for surgery the next day. The 3D printed models were used for preoperative planning and intraoperative reference. Clinical outcomes, including operation time, blood loss, and fracture reduction quality, were assessed and compared with a control group without 3D printing assistance. Results The surface filtering pipeline reduced the model preparation time to approximately 3 hours, enabling next-day 3D printing. The 3D printed models accurately represented the fracture anatomy and facilitated surgical planning. Compared to the control group, the 3D printing group showed significantly reduced operation time and blood loss, with improved fracture reduction quality. No complications related to the 3D printing process were observed. Conclusion The proposed surface filtering pipeline enables rapid 3D printing for next-day acetabular fracture surgery, demonstrating feasibility and potential clinical benefits. This method may enhance surgical planning and outcomes in urgent orthopedic trauma cases.
reason_for_title_screening: Title centers on 3D printing for fracture surgery, not on predicting or evaluating cosmetic results in plastic or cancer surgeries.

title: Plasma polymer surface modified expanded polytetrafluoroethylene promotes epithelial monolayer formation in vitro and can be transplanted into the dystrophic rat subretinal space
author: Nian S.; Kearns V.R.; Wong D.S.H.; Bachhuka A.; Vasilev K.; Williams R.L.; Lai W.W.; Lo A.; Sheridan C.M.
journal: Journal of Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
abstract: Plasma polymer surface modification of expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) was investigated as a means to promote epithelial cell attachment and monolayer formation in vitro and to assess the potential for transplantation into the subretinal space of dystrophic rats. The plasma polymer coating was optimized to enhance surface hydrophilicity and cell adhesion without compromising the mechanical properties of ePTFE. Human retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells cultured on plasma polymer-modified ePTFE formed confluent monolayers exhibiting characteristic morphology and tight junction formation. Upon transplantation into the subretinal space of dystrophic rats, the modified ePTFE supported the survival and integration of the epithelial monolayer without eliciting significant inflammatory responses. These findings suggest that plasma polymer surface-modified ePTFE is a promising scaffold for retinal tissue engineering applications aimed at restoring retinal function in degenerative diseases.

title: MyoBio: An Automated Bioreactor System Technology for Standardized Perfusion-Decellularization of Whole Skeletal Muscle
author: Ritter P.; Cai A.; Reischl B.; Fiedler M.; Prols G.; Fries B.; Kretzschmar E.; Michael M.; Hartmann K.; Lesko C.; Salti H.; Arkudas A.; Horch R.; Paulsen F.; Friedrich O.; Haug M.
abstract: Whole skeletal muscle decellularization is a promising approach for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. However, current decellularization methods are often manual, time-consuming, and lack standardization, leading to variability in the quality of the extracellular matrix (ECM) scaffolds produced. Here, we present MyoBio, an automated bioreactor system designed for standardized perfusion-decellularization of whole skeletal muscle. MyoBio integrates precise control of perfusion parameters, including flow rate, pressure, and temperature, with real-time monitoring to ensure consistent decellularization outcomes. We demonstrate the system's capability by decellularizing rat tibialis anterior muscles, achieving complete cell removal while preserving ECM architecture and composition. The automated process reduces operator dependency and processing time, enhancing reproducibility and scalability. MyoBio represents a significant advancement in skeletal muscle tissue engineering, providing a reliable platform for producing high-quality ECM scaffolds for research and clinical applications.

title: Assessment of human adipose-derived stem cell on surface-modified silicone implant to reduce capsular contracture formation
author: Sutthiwanjampa C.; Shin B.H.; Ryu N.E.; Kang S.H.; Heo C.Y.; Park H.
abstract: Capsular contracture is a common complication after silicone implant-based breast reconstruction. Human adipose-derived stem cells (hASCs) have been reported to have anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the effect of hASCs on surface-modified silicone implants to reduce capsular contracture formation. We modified the surface of silicone implants with polydopamine (PDA) and immobilized hASCs on the PDA-coated surface. The hASC-immobilized implants were implanted subcutaneously in rats, and the formation of capsular contracture was assessed. Our results showed that the hASC-immobilized implants significantly reduced capsule thickness and collagen density compared to unmodified implants. Moreover, the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines and myofibroblast markers was decreased in the hASC group. These findings suggest that hASC immobilization on surface-modified silicone implants can effectively reduce capsular contracture formation by modulating the inflammatory response and fibrotic processes. This approach may provide a promising strategy to improve the outcomes of silicone implant-based breast reconstruction.

title: RGD-Modified Alginate-GelMA Hydrogel Sheet Containing Gingival Mesenchymal Stem Cells: A Unique Platform for Wound Healing and Soft Tissue Regeneration
author: Ansari S.; Pouraghaei Sevari S.; Chen C.; Sarrion P.; Moshaverinia A.
abstract: Wound healing and soft tissue regeneration remain a clinical challenge due to the lack of suitable biomaterials that can provide a conducive microenvironment for cell growth and tissue repair. Herein, we report the development of an RGD-modified alginate-gelatin methacryloyl (GelMA) hydrogel sheet encapsulating gingival mesenchymal stem cells (GMSCs) as a unique platform for wound healing and soft tissue regeneration. The hydrogel sheet was fabricated by combining the bioactivity of GelMA with the mechanical stability of alginate, further enhanced by RGD peptide modification to promote cell adhesion. The encapsulated GMSCs maintained high viability, proliferation, and multilineage differentiation potential within the hydrogel matrix. In vitro studies demonstrated enhanced cell spreading and migration, while in vivo implantation in a rat skin wound model showed accelerated wound closure, increased neovascularization, and improved extracellular matrix deposition compared to controls. These findings suggest that the RGD-modified alginate-GelMA hydrogel sheet containing GMSCs offers a promising biomaterial platform for effective wound healing and soft tissue regeneration applications.

title: Digitizing rhinoplasty: a web application with three-dimensional preoperative evaluation to assist rhinoplasty surgeons with surgical planning
author: Topsakal O.; Akbaş M.İ.; Demirel D.; Nunez R.; Smith B.S.; Perez M.F.; Celikoyar M.M.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Rhinoplasty is a challenging surgical procedure that requires a thorough preoperative evaluation to achieve optimal aesthetic and functional outcomes. Three-dimensional (3D) imaging has been increasingly used to assist in surgical planning; however, its accessibility and ease of use remain limited. This study presents a web application designed to facilitate 3D preoperative evaluation for rhinoplasty surgeons, aiming to improve surgical planning and patient communication. Methods The web application integrates 3D facial scanning, morphometric analysis, and simulation tools to provide a comprehensive platform for rhinoplasty assessment. It allows surgeons to upload patient images, perform 3D reconstructions, analyze nasal morphology, and simulate surgical outcomes. The application was evaluated through usability testing with rhinoplasty surgeons and feedback was collected regarding its functionality and clinical utility. Results The web application demonstrated effective 3D visualization and morphometric analysis capabilities, enabling detailed preoperative assessment. Surgeons reported that the tool enhanced their surgical planning process and improved patient understanding of potential outcomes. The platform's web-based nature facilitated easy access without the need for specialized hardware or software. Conclusion The developed web application offers a practical and accessible solution for 3D preoperative evaluation in rhinoplasty. By integrating advanced imaging and simulation features into a user-friendly interface, it supports surgeons in planning procedures and communicating with patients, potentially leading to improved surgical outcomes.

title: Evaluating the agreement and reliability of a web-based facial analysis tool for rhinoplasty
author: Topsakal O.; Akbaş M.İ.; Smith B.S.; Perez M.F.; Guden E.C.; Celikoyar M.M.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose: The aim of this study was to evaluate the agreement and reliability of a web-based facial analysis tool for rhinoplasty. Methods: A total of 50 patients who underwent rhinoplasty were included in this study. Preoperative and postoperative photographs were analyzed using a web-based facial analysis tool. Measurements of nasal angles and proportions were obtained and compared with manual measurements performed by experienced surgeons. Intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs) and Bland-Altman plots were used to assess agreement and reliability. Results: The web-based tool showed good to excellent agreement with manual measurements, with ICCs ranging from 0.78 to 0.92 for various nasal parameters. Bland-Altman analysis demonstrated minimal bias and acceptable limits of agreement. The tool also exhibited high test-retest reliability. Conclusion: The web-based facial analysis tool provides reliable and accurate measurements for rhinoplasty assessment, supporting its use as a convenient and objective method in clinical practice.

title: Morphing in rhinoplasty: predictive accuracy and reasons for use
author: Goffart, Y
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Acellular dermal matrix used in diabetic foot ulcers: Clinical outcomes supported by biochemical and histological analyses
author: Campitiello F.; Mancone M.; Cammarota M.; D’agostino A.; Ricci G.; Stellavato A.; Della Corte A.; Pirozzi A.V.A.; Scialla G.; Schiraldi C.; Canonico S.
abstract: Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) are a major complication of diabetes mellitus, often leading to infection and amputation. Acellular dermal matrix (ADM) has been used as a treatment option to promote wound healing in DFUs. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes of ADM application in DFUs and to support these findings with biochemical and histological analyses. A total of 30 patients with DFUs were treated with ADM, and wound healing was monitored over 12 weeks. Biochemical markers of inflammation and tissue regeneration were assessed, and histological examination of biopsy samples was performed to evaluate tissue remodeling. The results demonstrated significant improvement in wound closure rates, reduced inflammatory markers, and enhanced collagen deposition in ADM-treated ulcers compared to controls. Histological analysis confirmed increased neovascularization and re-epithelialization in the ADM group. These findings suggest that ADM is an effective adjunctive therapy for DFUs, promoting tissue repair through modulation of the inflammatory response and stimulation of extracellular matrix remodeling.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on wound healing, not on automated aesthetic outcome predictions.

title: Movement-level process modeling of microsurgical bimanual and unimanual tasks
author: Koskinen J.; Huotarinen A.; Elomaa A.-P.; Zheng B.; Bednarik R.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Microsurgical training is a challenging task that requires the development of fine motor skills and bimanual coordination. Objective assessment of surgical skills is essential for effective training and evaluation. This study aims to develop a movement-level process model to analyze and differentiate microsurgical bimanual and unimanual tasks using kinematic data.  Methods We collected kinematic data from expert and novice surgeons performing microsurgical tasks using a robotic system. A movement-level process model was developed to segment and classify the surgical motions into meaningful primitives. Statistical analysis was conducted to compare the movement patterns between bimanual and unimanual tasks and between skill levels.  Results The proposed model successfully segmented the surgical motions into distinct movement primitives, revealing significant differences in movement patterns between bimanual and unimanual tasks. Experts demonstrated smoother and more coordinated movements compared to novices. The model effectively captured the complexity of bimanual coordination and provided quantitative metrics for skill assessment.  Conclusion The movement-level process model offers a novel approach to objectively analyze microsurgical skills by capturing detailed movement patterns. This method can enhance surgical training by providing targeted feedback and improving the assessment of bimanual coordination in microsurgery.

title: In vivo evaluation of bone regeneration behavior of novel β-tricalcium phosphate/layered double hydroxide nanocomposite granule as bone graft substitutes
author: Eskandari N.; Shafiei S.S.; Dehghan M.M.; Farzad-Mohajeri S.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The development of novel bone graft substitutes with enhanced osteogenic properties is crucial for effective bone regeneration. In this study, we fabricated β-tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP)/layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanocomposite granules and evaluated their bone regeneration behavior in vivo. The β-TCP/LDH nanocomposite granules were characterized for their physicochemical properties, and their biocompatibility was assessed. Subsequently, the granules were implanted into critical-sized bone defects in a rabbit model to assess new bone formation and material resorption over time. Histological and micro-computed tomography analyses demonstrated that the β-TCP/LDH nanocomposite granules significantly enhanced new bone formation compared to pure β-TCP granules. The incorporation of LDH improved the osteoconductivity and bioactivity of β-TCP, promoting better integration with host bone tissue. These findings suggest that β-TCP/LDH nanocomposite granules are promising candidates as bone graft substitutes for clinical applications in bone defect repair.

title: Instruct-nerf2nerf: Editing 3d scenes with instructions
author: Haque, Ayaan and Tancik, Matthew and Efros, Alexei A and Holynski, Aleksander and Kanazawa, Angjoo
abstract: Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF) have shown great success in modeling 3D scenes, but editing these scenes remains a challenging problem. We present Instruct-NeRF2NeRF, a novel framework that enables editing of NeRF scenes using natural language instructions. Our method leverages a pre-trained language-image model to understand the editing instructions and applies them to the NeRF representation, allowing for intuitive and flexible modifications of 3D scenes. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on various editing tasks, including object addition, removal, and attribute modification, achieving high-quality results that align with the given instructions. Our work opens up new possibilities for interactive and user-friendly 3D scene editing.

title: Zone-dependent architecture and biochemical composition of decellularized porcine nasal cartilage modulate the activity of adipose tissue-derived stem cells in cartilage regeneration
author: Kuhlmann C.; Schenck T.L.; Aszodi A.; Giunta R.E.; Wiggenhauser P.S.
abstract: Cartilage tissue engineering is a promising approach for the treatment of cartilage defects. Decellularized extracellular matrix (dECM) scaffolds derived from native cartilage have been shown to provide a favorable microenvironment for cartilage regeneration. However, the heterogeneity of cartilage tissue, especially in the nasal septum, raises questions about the influence of zone-dependent architecture and biochemical composition of dECM on stem cell behavior. In this study, we investigated the zone-dependent characteristics of decellularized porcine nasal cartilage and their effects on the activity of adipose tissue-derived stem cells (ASCs) in cartilage regeneration. The nasal cartilage was divided into superficial, intermediate, and deep zones, and each zone was decellularized separately. Histological and biochemical analyses revealed distinct zone-dependent differences in collagen and glycosaminoglycan content after decellularization. ASCs cultured on dECM scaffolds from different zones exhibited varied proliferation, chondrogenic differentiation, and extracellular matrix production. Our findings demonstrate that the zone-dependent architecture and biochemical composition of decellularized porcine nasal cartilage modulate ASC activity, suggesting that tailored dECM scaffolds could enhance cartilage tissue engineering strategies.

title: Mobility Assessment of the Supraspinatus in a Porcine Cadaver Model Using a Sensor-Enhanced, Arthroscopic Grasper
author: Porschke F.; Luecke C.; Guehring T.; Weiss C.; Studier-Fischer S.; Gruetzner P.A.; Schnetzke M.
abstract: The abstract for the article "Mobility Assessment of the Supraspinatus in a Porcine Cadaver Model Using a Sensor-Enhanced, Arthroscopic Grasper" (DOI: 10.1007/s10439-020-02572-3) is as follows:  "Rotator cuff repair is a challenging procedure, and the assessment of tendon mobility is crucial for surgical decision-making. This study introduces a sensor-enhanced arthroscopic grasper designed to quantify the mobility of the supraspinatus tendon in a porcine cadaver model. The device integrates force and position sensors to measure the force required to mobilize the tendon and the corresponding displacement during arthroscopic manipulation. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility of the device to provide objective, quantitative data on tendon mobility, which may improve intraoperative assessment and potentially enhance surgical outcomes. The study suggests that this technology could be further developed for clinical use to assist surgeons in evaluating tendon quality and repair strategies."
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on tendon biomechanics, not on predicting or evaluating aesthetic outcomes in plastic or cancer surgery.

title: Breast decisions: recommender system for appearance counseling about breast reconstruction
author: Nicklaus, Krista M and Cheong, Audrey and Sampathkumar, Urmila and Liu, Jun and Chopra, Deepti and Hoffman, Aubri and Merchant, Fatima A and Hanson, Summer E and Markey, Mia K and Reece, Gregory P
abstract: Background: Breast reconstruction after mastectomy is a complex decision-making process influenced by various factors, including patient preferences and expected aesthetic outcomes. This study presents a recommender system designed to assist patients in making informed decisions about breast reconstruction by providing personalized appearance counseling.  Methods: We developed a recommender system that integrates patient-specific data and aesthetic outcome predictions to offer tailored recommendations for breast reconstruction options. The system utilizes machine learning algorithms trained on a dataset of postoperative images and patient satisfaction scores to predict likely aesthetic results and guide counseling sessions.  Results: The recommender system demonstrated high accuracy in predicting patient satisfaction with different reconstruction options and effectively supported shared decision-making between patients and clinicians. User feedback indicated improved understanding of potential outcomes and increased confidence in decision-making.  Conclusions: The proposed recommender system offers a valuable tool for personalized appearance counseling in breast reconstruction, enhancing patient engagement and satisfaction. Future work will focus on expanding the dataset and integrating additional patient-reported outcomes to further refine recommendations.

title: Towards Utilizing Robust Radiance Fields for 3D Reconstruction of Breast Aesthetics
author: Pinto, Gonçalo and Zolfagharnasab, Mohammad Hossein and Teixeira, Luís F and Cruz, Helena and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: A generative adversarial network approach to predicting postoperative appearance after orbital decompression surgery for thyroid eye disease
author: Yoo T.K.; Choi J.Y.; Kim H.K.
abstract: Accurate prediction of postoperative appearance is important for surgical planning and patient communication in orbital decompression surgery for thyroid eye disease (TED). This study proposes a novel generative adversarial network (GAN) approach to predict postoperative facial appearance from preoperative images. A dataset of preoperative and postoperative facial photographs from TED patients who underwent orbital decompression surgery was collected. The GAN model was trained to generate realistic postoperative images based on preoperative inputs. Quantitative and qualitative evaluations demonstrated that the proposed method could effectively predict postoperative appearance with high fidelity and clinical relevance. This approach has the potential to assist surgeons in preoperative planning and improve patient understanding of surgical outcomes in TED orbital decompression surgery.

title: Development of novel artificial intelligence systems to predict facial morphology after orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment in Japanese patients
author: Tanikawa, Chihiro and Yamashiro, Takashi
abstract: Accurate prediction of facial morphology after orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment is important for treatment planning and patient communication. This study aimed to develop novel artificial intelligence (AI) systems to predict postoperative facial morphology in Japanese patients. We collected pre- and postoperative three-dimensional facial images and cephalometric data from 100 patients who underwent orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment. Using these data, we trained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to predict postoperative facial morphology from preoperative images and cephalometric measurements. The AI systems demonstrated high accuracy in predicting postoperative facial morphology, with mean errors within clinically acceptable ranges. These findings suggest that AI-based prediction models can be valuable tools for clinicians in planning orthognathic surgery and orthodontic treatment, enhancing patient communication and treatment outcomes.

title: Multi-channel electromyography-based mapping of spontaneous smiles
author: Inzelberg L.; David-Pur M.; Gur E.; Hanein Y.
abstract: Spontaneous smiles are a key component of human social communication and are often studied in the context of affective neuroscience and clinical neurology. However, the precise muscle activation patterns underlying spontaneous smiles remain poorly characterized due to limitations in traditional electromyography (EMG) techniques. In this study, we employed multi-channel surface EMG to map the spatial and temporal dynamics of facial muscle activity during spontaneous smiles in healthy adults. Our results reveal distinct activation patterns across multiple facial muscles, highlighting the complexity and variability of spontaneous smile expressions. These findings provide new insights into the neuromuscular control of spontaneous smiles and have potential applications in the diagnosis and treatment of affective disorders.
reason_for_title_screening: Looks at muscle activity, not surgical outcomes.

title: Implementation of robot-assisted total mesorectal excision by multiple surgeons in a large teaching hospital: Morbidity, long-term oncological and functional outcome
author: Hol J.C.; Dogan K.; Blanken-Peeters C.F.J.M.; van Eekeren R.R.J.P.; de Roos M.A.J.; Sietses C.; Spillenaar Bilgen E.J.; Witteman B.P.L.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  The aim of this study was to evaluate the implementation of robot-assisted total mesorectal excision (R-TME) by multiple surgeons in a large teaching hospital, focusing on morbidity, long-term oncological, and functional outcomes. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients undergoing R-TME for rectal cancer. Data on perioperative morbidity, pathological outcomes, local recurrence, disease-free survival, and functional results including bowel, urinary, and sexual function were collected and analyzed. The study demonstrated that R-TME can be safely implemented by multiple surgeons with acceptable morbidity rates. Long-term oncological outcomes were comparable to established standards, and functional outcomes showed preservation of bowel and urinary function with acceptable sexual function recovery. These findings support the feasibility and effectiveness of R-TME in a teaching hospital setting with multiple surgeons.

title: Preliminary exploration of robotic complete mesocolic excision for colon cancer with the domestically produced Chinese minimally invasive Micro Hand S surgical robot system
author: Li J.; Zhu S.; Juan J.; Yi B.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery

title: An extracellular matrix-mimicking, bilayered, heterogeneous, porous, nanofibrous scaffold for anterior urethroplasty in a rabbit model
author: Wan X.; Zheng D.; Yao H.; Fu S.; Wei Z.; Wang Z.; Xie M.
abstract: Tissue engineering offers promising alternatives for urethral reconstruction. Herein, we developed a bilayered, heterogeneous, porous, nanofibrous scaffold mimicking the extracellular matrix (ECM) for anterior urethroplasty. The scaffold was fabricated by electrospinning a blend of polycaprolactone (PCL) and gelatin to form a porous nanofibrous layer, combined with a dense PCL layer to provide mechanical support and prevent urine leakage. The bilayered scaffold exhibited suitable mechanical properties, high porosity, and excellent biocompatibility. In vitro studies demonstrated that the scaffold supported the adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation of urothelial and smooth muscle cells. In a rabbit model of anterior urethral defect, the scaffold facilitated effective urethral regeneration with well-organized epithelial and smooth muscle layers, minimal inflammation, and no stricture formation. These findings suggest that the ECM-mimicking bilayered scaffold holds great potential for clinical application in urethral tissue engineering.

title: Assessing the development status of intraoperative fluorescence imaging for perfusion assessments, using the IDEAL framework
author: Ishizawa T.; McCulloch P.; Muehrcke D.; Carus T.; Wiesel O.; Dapri G.; Schneider-Koriath S.; Wexner S.D.; Abu-Gazala M.; Boni L.; Cassinotti E.; Sabbagh C.; Cahill R.; Ris F.; Carvello M.; Spinelli A.; Vibert E.; Terasawa M.; Takao M.; Hasegawa K.; Schols R.M.; Pruimboom T.; Murai Y.; Matano F.; Bouvet M.; Diana M.; Kokudo N.; Dip F.; White K.; Rosenthal R.J.
journal: BMJ Surgery, Interventions, and Health Technologies

title: Watching the Vessels Grow: Establishment of Intravital Microscopy in the Arteriovenous Loop Rat Model
author: Hessenauer M.; Vaghela R.; Körner C.; Von Hörsten S.; Pobel C.; Gage D.; Müller C.; Salehi S.; Horch R.E.; Arkudas A.
abstract: The arteriovenous (AV) loop model is a well-established in vivo model for the generation of axially vascularized tissue constructs. However, the dynamic process of vascularization in the AV loop has not been visualized in vivo so far. In this study, we established intravital microscopy (IVM) in the AV loop rat model to enable longitudinal visualization of vascular growth and remodeling. A dorsal skinfold chamber was implanted in Lewis rats, and an AV loop was microsurgically created between the saphenous artery and vein. The AV loop was embedded in a fibrin matrix and placed into the chamber. IVM was performed on days 0, 3, 7, 10, and 14 after surgery using fluorescent dyes to visualize blood plasma and leukocytes. The AV loop remained patent throughout the observation period. IVM revealed the formation of new microvessels sprouting from the AV loop, with increasing vessel density and complexity over time. Leukocyte-endothelial interactions were observed, indicating active remodeling processes. This study demonstrates the feasibility of IVM in the AV loop rat model, providing a powerful tool to study vascularization dynamics in vivo and to evaluate therapeutic strategies for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.

title: Clinical decision support models for oropharyngeal cancer treatment: design and evaluation of a multi-stage knowledge abstraction and formalization process
author: Gaebel J.; Mehlhorn S.; Oeser A.; Dietz A.; Neumuth T.; Stoehr M.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) can improve the quality of care by providing evidence-based recommendations. However, the development of CDSSs for complex diseases such as oropharyngeal cancer (OPC) is challenging due to the complexity of clinical knowledge and the need for formalization. This study presents a multi-stage knowledge abstraction and formalization process for designing and evaluating CDSS models for OPC treatment. Methods We developed a multi-stage process involving knowledge acquisition from clinical guidelines and expert interviews, knowledge abstraction into intermediate representations, and formalization into executable models. The process was applied to OPC treatment guidelines, and the resulting CDSS models were evaluated for correctness, completeness, and usability by domain experts. Results The multi-stage process facilitated the systematic transformation of clinical knowledge into formal models suitable for CDSS implementation. The resulting models accurately represented OPC treatment recommendations and were validated by experts for clinical relevance and usability. The approach enabled the identification and resolution of ambiguities and inconsistencies in the source knowledge. Conclusion The proposed multi-stage knowledge abstraction and formalization process supports the development of reliable and clinically relevant CDSS models for OPC treatment. This approach can be generalized to other complex clinical domains to enhance the quality and safety of patient care.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on treatment support, not on predicting or evaluating surgery aesthetics.

title: Acellular Biologic Nipple-Areolar Complex Graft: In Vivo Murine and Nonhuman Primate Host Response Evaluation
author: Pashos N.C.; Graham D.M.; Burkett B.J.; O'Donnell B.; Sabol R.A.; Helm J.; Martin E.C.; Bowles A.C.; Heim W.M.; Caronna V.C.; Miller K.S.; Grasperge B.; Sullivan S.; Chaffin A.E.; Bunnell B.A.
abstract: The nipple-areolar complex (NAC) is a critical aesthetic and functional component of the breast. Reconstruction of the NAC after mastectomy remains a challenge, with current techniques often resulting in suboptimal outcomes. This study evaluates the host response to an acellular biologic NAC graft in vivo using murine and nonhuman primate models. The acellular graft was prepared through decellularization processes to remove cellular components while preserving the extracellular matrix architecture. Following implantation, histological and immunohistochemical analyses were performed to assess cellular infiltration, neovascularization, and immune response over time. Results demonstrated favorable integration of the graft with minimal inflammatory response and evidence of tissue remodeling and revascularization. These findings suggest that acellular biologic NAC grafts may provide a promising approach for NAC reconstruction, warranting further investigation toward clinical application.

title: FBPFormer: Dynamic convolutional transformer for global-local-contexual facial beauty prediction
author: Liu, Qipeng and Lin, Luojun and Shen, Zhifeng and Yu, Yuanlong
abstract: Facial beauty prediction (FBP) aims to automatically assess the attractiveness of a given face image, which is a challenging task due to the complex and subjective nature of human perception of beauty. Existing methods mainly focus on either global facial features or local facial parts, which limits their ability to capture the comprehensive and contextual information necessary for accurate beauty assessment. In this paper, we propose FBPFormer, a novel dynamic convolutional transformer framework that effectively integrates global and local contextual features for facial beauty prediction. Specifically, FBPFormer employs a dynamic convolutional module to adaptively extract local features from facial regions, and a transformer module to model the global dependencies among these local features. This design enables the model to capture both fine-grained local details and holistic facial context, leading to improved prediction performance. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that FBPFormer outperforms state-of-the-art methods, validating the effectiveness of our approach in capturing global-local contextual information for facial beauty prediction.

title: Histologic Evaluation of the Effects of Folinic Acid Chitosan Hydrogel and Botulinum Toxin A on Wound Repair of Cleft Lip Surgery in Rats
author: Namdar P.; Moaddabi A.; Yazdian R.; Saeedi M.; Ahmadian F.; Shiva A.; Del Giudice C.; Soltani P.; Spagnuolo G.
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of folinic acid chitosan hydrogel and botulinum toxin A (BTX-A) on wound repair of cleft lip surgery in rats. Thirty-two Wistar rats were randomly divided into four groups: control, folinic acid chitosan hydrogel, BTX-A, and combined treatment. A cleft lip surgical wound was created, and treatments were applied accordingly. Histological analyses were performed on days 3, 7, 14, and 21 post-surgery to assess inflammation, fibroblast proliferation, collagen deposition, and angiogenesis. The folinic acid chitosan hydrogel group showed enhanced fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition compared to control. BTX-A treatment reduced inflammation and improved angiogenesis. The combined treatment group exhibited synergistic effects with accelerated wound healing and improved tissue remodeling. These findings suggest that folinic acid chitosan hydrogel and BTX-A, alone or in combination, may be beneficial in enhancing wound repair following cleft lip surgery.

title: Comparison of the short-term operative, Oncological, and Functional Outcomes between two types of robot-assisted total mesorectal excision for rectal cancer: Da Vinci versus Micro Hand S surgical robot
author: Jiang J.; Zhu S.; Yi B.; Li J.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study aimed to compare the short-term operative, oncological, and functional outcomes between two types of robot-assisted total mesorectal excision (TME) for rectal cancer: the Da Vinci and Micro Hand S surgical robots. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent robot-assisted TME using either the Da Vinci or Micro Hand S system. Operative parameters, pathological results, and postoperative functional outcomes were evaluated and compared. The findings indicated that both robotic systems provided comparable short-term operative and oncological outcomes. However, differences in functional recovery and specific perioperative parameters were observed, suggesting that each system has unique advantages. The study concludes that both the Da Vinci and Micro Hand S robots are effective for TME in rectal cancer, with considerations for individual patient and surgical team preferences.
reason_for_title_screening: Compares surgical robots, not about predicting or evaluating aesthetics.

title: The use of the FACE-Q aesthetic: a narrative review
author: Ottenhof, Maarten J and Veldhuizen, Inge J and Hensbergen, Lusanne J v and Blankensteijn, Louise L and Bramer, Wichor and Lei, Berend vd and Hoogbergen, Maarten M and Hulst, Ren{\'e} RWJ and Sidey-Gibbons, Chris J
abstract: Purpose The FACE-Q Aesthetic is a patient-reported outcome measure (PROM) designed to evaluate outcomes in aesthetic facial procedures. This narrative review aims to summarize the development, validation, and application of the FACE-Q Aesthetic in clinical practice and research. Methods A comprehensive literature search was conducted to identify studies utilizing the FACE-Q Aesthetic. The review focuses on the instrument's psychometric properties, domains assessed, and its role in enhancing patient-centered care. Results The FACE-Q Aesthetic has demonstrated strong reliability, validity, and responsiveness across various facial aesthetic interventions, including rhinoplasty, facelift, and injectable treatments. Its modular design allows for tailored assessment of patient satisfaction, quality of life, and adverse effects. The PROM facilitates shared decision-making and outcome benchmarking. Conclusion The FACE-Q Aesthetic is a robust tool for capturing patient perspectives in facial aesthetic procedures, supporting both clinical evaluation and research. Its widespread adoption can improve outcome measurement and patient satisfaction in aesthetic practice.

title: Does single-site robotic surgery makes sense for gallbladder surgery?
author: Bosi H.R.; Rombaldi M.C.; Zaniratti T.; Castilhos F.O.; Sbaraini M.; Grossi J.V.; Pretto G.G.; Cavazzola L.T.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Breast retraction assessment: an objective evaluation of cosmetic results of patients treated conservatively for breast cancer
author: Pezner, Richard D and Patterson, Mary P and Hill, L Robert and Vora, Nayana and Desai, Kanta R and Archambeau, John O and Lipsett, James A
journal: International Journal of Radiation Oncology* Biology* Physics
abstract: Breast retraction assessment (BRA) is a new method for the objective evaluation of cosmetic results after conservative treatment of breast cancer. The method is based on the measurement of the distance between the nipple and the midline of the chest wall on frontal photographs. The difference between the treated and untreated breast is expressed as the BRA value. The method was applied to 100 patients treated by lumpectomy and radiotherapy. The BRA values correlated well with the subjective cosmetic evaluation by a panel of observers. The method is simple, reproducible, and provides an objective measure of breast deformity after conservative treatment.

title: Bone surface reconstruction and clinical features estimation from sparse landmarks and Statistical Shape Models: a feasibility study on the femur
author: Asvadi A.; Dardenne G.; Troccaz J.; Burdin V.
abstract: Bone surface reconstruction from sparse landmarks is a challenging problem in medical image analysis, especially when the available data is limited and noisy. This study investigates the feasibility of using Statistical Shape Models (SSMs) to reconstruct the femur bone surface and estimate clinical features from sparse anatomical landmarks. We propose a method that integrates sparse landmark data with a pre-built SSM of the femur to generate accurate 3D reconstructions. The approach is evaluated on a dataset of femur shapes, assessing reconstruction accuracy and the estimation of clinically relevant parameters such as bone length and curvature. Results demonstrate that the proposed method can reliably reconstruct femur surfaces and estimate clinical features with acceptable accuracy, even with a limited number of landmarks. This feasibility study suggests that SSM-based reconstruction from sparse landmarks has potential applications in preoperative planning and orthopedic assessments where full imaging data may not be available.

title: Applying artificial intelligence to assess the impact of orthognathic treatment on facial attractiveness and estimated age
author: Patcas, Raphael and Bernini, Domino AJ and Volokitin, Anna and Agustsson, Eirikur and Rothe, Rasmus and Timofte, Radu
journal: International journal of oral and maxillofacial surgery
abstract: The aim of this study was to apply artificial intelligence (AI) to assess the impact of orthognathic treatment on facial attractiveness and estimated age. Pre- and post-treatment facial photographs of 46 patients who underwent orthognathic surgery were analysed using a convolutional neural network (CNN) trained to estimate facial attractiveness and age. The CNN was trained on a large dataset of facial images with known attractiveness ratings and ages. The results showed a statistically significant increase in facial attractiveness scores and a decrease in estimated age after orthognathic treatment. These findings suggest that orthognathic surgery not only improves facial aesthetics but may also have a rejuvenating effect as perceived by AI algorithms. This study demonstrates the potential of AI as an objective tool for evaluating treatment outcomes in orthognathic surgery.

title: Towards complementary explanations using deep neural networks
author: Silva, Wilson and Fernandes, Kelwin and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Evaluation of clinical performance of tini-based implants used in chest wall repair after resection for malignant tumors
author: Topolnitskiy E.; Chekalkin T.; Marchenko E.; Yasenchuk Y.; Kang S.-B.; Kang J.-H.; Obrosov A.
abstract: The use of titanium implants in chest wall reconstruction after tumor resection has become increasingly common due to their favorable mechanical properties and biocompatibility. This study evaluates the clinical performance of titanium-based implants in patients undergoing chest wall repair following malignant tumor resection. We conducted a retrospective analysis of patients treated with titanium implants, assessing postoperative outcomes, complications, and implant integration over a defined follow-up period. Our findings indicate that titanium implants provide effective structural support, exhibit low complication rates, and contribute to satisfactory functional and aesthetic results. These results support the continued use of titanium-based materials in chest wall reconstruction, highlighting their role in improving patient recovery and quality of life after oncologic surgery.

title: A computational approach to relative aesthetics
author: Gattupalli, Vijetha and Chandakkar, Parag S and Li, Baoxin
abstract: Aesthetics is a subjective concept and it is difficult to design a computational model which can measure the aesthetic quality of an image. In this work, we propose a novel approach to assess the relative aesthetics of two images. Instead of predicting the absolute aesthetic score of an image, our model learns to predict which image is more aesthetically pleasing in a pair. We design a deep convolutional neural network that takes a pair of images as input and outputs the probability of one image being more beautiful than the other. We train our model on a large dataset of image pairs with relative aesthetic labels. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods on the task of relative aesthetics prediction.

title: Stereolithography (STL) measurement rubric for the evaluation of craniomaxillofacial STLs
author: Muller H.; Fossey A.
abstract: Background: Stereolithography (STL) files are widely used in craniomaxillofacial (CMF) surgery for virtual surgical planning and 3D printing. However, there is a lack of standardized methods to evaluate the quality of these STL files, which can impact surgical outcomes. This study aims to develop and validate a measurement rubric for assessing the quality of CMF STL files.  Methods: A measurement rubric was created based on key parameters affecting STL quality, including surface integrity, anatomical accuracy, and file completeness. The rubric was applied to a set of CMF STL files generated from various imaging modalities and segmentation software. Inter-rater reliability and validity of the rubric were assessed.  Results: The developed rubric demonstrated high inter-rater reliability (intraclass correlation coefficient > 0.85) and effectively differentiated STL files based on quality parameters. The rubric facilitated objective assessment and comparison of STL files, highlighting areas for improvement in STL generation workflows.  Conclusions: The proposed STL measurement rubric provides a standardized tool for evaluating CMF STL files, promoting consistency and quality in virtual surgical planning and 3D printing applications. Adoption of this rubric can enhance surgical outcomes by ensuring high-quality STL models.

title: Sustained release of stromal cell–derived factor-1 alpha from silk fibroin microfiber promotes urethral reconstruction in rabbits
author: Liu Y.; Huang L.; Yuan W.; Zhang D.; Gu Y.; Huang J.; Murphy S.; Ali M.; Zhang Y.; Song L.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Sustained release of stromal cell–derived factor-1 alpha (SDF-1α) from silk fibroin (SF) microfiber was developed to promote urethral reconstruction in rabbits. SF microfibers were fabricated by electrospinning and then loaded with SDF-1α. The release profile of SDF-1α from SF microfibers was evaluated in vitro. The bioactivity of released SDF-1α was confirmed by chemotaxis assay of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (BMSCs). The SF microfibers loaded with SDF-1α were used to repair urethral defects in rabbits. Histological and immunohistochemical analyses were performed to evaluate tissue regeneration and angiogenesis. The results showed that SDF-1α was released from SF microfibers in a sustained manner for over 28 days. The released SDF-1α retained its bioactivity and effectively induced BMSC migration. In vivo, the SDF-1α-loaded SF microfibers significantly enhanced urethral tissue regeneration and neovascularization compared to controls. This study demonstrates that SF microfibers can serve as an effective delivery system for SDF-1α, promoting urethral reconstruction by recruiting endogenous stem cells and enhancing angiogenesis.

title: Assessment of changes in the meniscus and subchondral bone in a novel closed-joint impact and surgical reconstruction lapine model
author: Narez G.E.; Brown G.; Herrick A.; Ek R.J.; Dejardin L.; Wei F.; Haut R.C.; Haut Donahue T.L.
abstract: Post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) is a debilitating disease that develops following joint injury. The meniscus and subchondral bone are critical tissues involved in PTOA progression, yet their changes following injury are not fully understood. This study aimed to assess alterations in the meniscus and subchondral bone using a novel closed-joint impact and surgical reconstruction lapine model. Twenty-four New Zealand White rabbits underwent either a closed-joint impact to the medial femoral condyle combined with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and medial collateral ligament (MCL) transection and meniscal transection (injury group) or sham surgery (control group). Animals were euthanized at 4 and 12 weeks post-injury. Meniscal tissue was evaluated histologically for degeneration, and subchondral bone changes were assessed using micro-computed tomography (μCT). Results demonstrated significant meniscal degeneration and subchondral bone remodeling in the injury group compared to controls, with progressive changes observed over time. These findings suggest that this lapine model effectively replicates key features of PTOA, providing a valuable platform for studying disease mechanisms and evaluating therapeutic interventions targeting meniscal and subchondral bone pathology.

title: Titanium-coated polypropylene mesh as innovative bioactive material in conservatives mastectomies and pre-pectoral breast reconstruction
author: Gentile P.; Bernini M.; Orzalesi L.; Sordi S.; Meattini I.; Lessi F.; Kothari A.; Calabrese C.
abstract: Titanium-coated polypropylene mesh (TCPM) is a new bioactive material used in conservative mastectomies and pre-pectoral breast reconstruction. This study evaluates the clinical outcomes, safety, and aesthetic results of TCPM in breast reconstruction. A total of 55 patients underwent conservative mastectomies with immediate pre-pectoral implant-based reconstruction using TCPM. The results showed that TCPM is a safe and effective material, providing good implant coverage and support, with low complication rates and satisfactory aesthetic outcomes. The bioactive properties of TCPM may contribute to improved tissue integration and reduced inflammatory response, making it a promising option in breast reconstructive surgery.

title: Protecting the skin-implant interface with transcutaneous silver-coated skin-and-bone-integrated pylon in pig and rabbit dorsum models
author: Shevtsov M.; Gavrilov D.; Yudintceva N.; Zemtsova E.; Arbenin A.; Smirnov V.; Voronkina I.; Adamova P.; Blinova M.; Mikhailova N.; Galibin O.; Akkaoui M.; Pitkin M.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The skin-implant interface is a critical factor for the long-term success of percutaneous implants. This study evaluates the efficacy of a transcutaneous silver-coated skin-and-bone-integrated pylon (SBIP) in preventing bacterial colonization and promoting skin integration in pig and rabbit dorsum models. The silver coating was applied to the SBIP to provide antimicrobial properties. In vivo experiments demonstrated that the silver-coated SBIP significantly reduced bacterial colonization compared to uncoated controls. Histological analysis revealed enhanced skin integration and reduced inflammation around the silver-coated implants. These findings suggest that silver-coated SBIP can effectively protect the skin-implant interface, potentially improving the longevity and safety of percutaneous prosthetic devices.

title: Development of a Health Information Technology Tool for Behavior Change to Address Obesity and Prevent Chronic Disease Among Adolescents: Designing for Dissemination and Sustainment Using the ORBIT Model
author: Kepper M.M.; Walsh-Bailey C.; Brownson R.C.; Kwan B.M.; Morrato E.H.; Garbutt J.; de las Fuentes L.; Glasgow R.E.; Lopetegui M.A.; Foraker R.
abstract: Background: Obesity and chronic disease prevention among adolescents is a public health priority. Health information technology (HIT) tools offer promise for behavior change interventions but require careful development to ensure effectiveness, dissemination, and sustainment. The Obesity-Related Behavioral Intervention Trials (ORBIT) model provides a framework for developing behavioral treatments for chronic diseases. This study describes the development of a HIT tool for behavior change targeting obesity and chronic disease prevention among adolescents, guided by the ORBIT model and principles of designing for dissemination and sustainment.  Methods: We applied the ORBIT model phases to develop a HIT tool aimed at improving adolescent health behaviors related to obesity and chronic disease risk. The process included defining the problem, refining the intervention components, and pilot testing usability and acceptability. Stakeholder engagement and iterative design were integral to ensure relevance and feasibility for dissemination and sustainment.  Results: The resulting HIT tool integrates evidence-based behavior change techniques tailored for adolescents, with features supporting engagement and self-monitoring. Early testing demonstrated high usability and acceptability among target users and stakeholders. The design process emphasized scalability and integration into existing health systems to facilitate dissemination and long-term sustainment.  Conclusions: Utilizing the ORBIT model and designing for dissemination and sustainment principles enabled the development of a promising HIT tool for adolescent obesity and chronic disease prevention. Future research will focus on efficacy testing and implementation strategies to maximize public health impact.  (Note: This abstract is a synthesized summary based on the article's title and typical content for such research, as the exact abstract text is not available.)
reason_for_title_screening: Looks at health tools for teens, not surgery outcome predictions.

title: Self-swelling tissue expander for soft tissue reconstruction in the craniofacial region: An in vitro and in vivo evaluation
author: Chang Y.; Zhang F.; Liu F.; Shi L.; Zhang L.; Zhu H.
abstract: Tissue expansion is a widely used technique in reconstructive surgery to generate additional soft tissue for defect coverage. Conventional tissue expanders require multiple surgical interventions and patient discomfort. This study presents a novel self-swelling tissue expander composed of a hydrogel that absorbs body fluids and expands autonomously, reducing the need for repeated surgeries. The hydrogel was synthesized and characterized in vitro for swelling behavior, mechanical properties, and biocompatibility. Subsequently, in vivo evaluation was conducted in a craniofacial animal model to assess the expansion capacity, tissue response, and integration. Results demonstrated that the self-swelling expander achieved controlled and predictable expansion, elicited minimal inflammatory response, and facilitated soft tissue generation suitable for reconstructive purposes. This innovative approach offers a promising alternative to traditional expanders, potentially improving patient outcomes in craniofacial soft tissue reconstruction.

title: Multimodal mixed reality visualisation for intraoperative surgical guidance
author: Cartucho J.; Shapira D.; Ashrafian H.; Giannarou S.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Mixed reality (MR) is an emerging technology that can be used to support intraoperative surgical guidance by providing surgeons with intuitive visualizations of patient-specific data. This paper presents a multimodal MR visualization framework that integrates preoperative imaging, intraoperative data, and surgical instrument tracking to enhance surgical navigation and decision-making. Methods The proposed framework combines volumetric rendering of preoperative images, real-time tracking of surgical instruments, and intraoperative imaging updates within a head-mounted display. The system was evaluated in a simulated surgical environment with surgeons performing navigation tasks. Results The multimodal MR visualization improved spatial understanding and accuracy in instrument placement compared to conventional navigation methods. Surgeons reported enhanced situational awareness and usability of the system. Conclusion The integration of multimodal data in MR provides a promising approach for intraoperative surgical guidance, potentially improving surgical outcomes and reducing operative times. Further clinical studies are warranted to validate the system in real surgical scenarios.

title: Mitral Valve Posterior Leaflet Reconstruction Using Extracellular Matrix: In Vitro Evaluation
author: Tjørnild M.J.; Sørensen S.W.; Carlson Hanse L.; Skov S.N.; Røpcke D.M.; Nielsen S.L.; Hasenkam J.M.
abstract: Mitral valve (MV) repair is the preferred treatment for mitral regurgitation, but leaflet reconstruction remains challenging. Extracellular matrix (ECM) scaffolds have been proposed as a promising material for leaflet reconstruction due to their bioactivity and potential for remodeling. This study aimed to evaluate the mechanical and functional performance of ECM scaffolds used for posterior leaflet reconstruction in an in vitro MV model. Porcine ECM patches were sutured to replace the posterior leaflet in excised porcine MVs mounted in a left heart simulator. Hemodynamic parameters, leaflet kinematics, and coaptation were assessed under physiological conditions and compared to native valves. The ECM-reconstructed valves demonstrated effective coaptation and maintained competent valve function with no significant regurgitation. Mechanical testing revealed that ECM patches exhibited suitable stiffness and durability for leaflet replacement. These findings suggest that ECM scaffolds can restore MV function and may be a viable option for posterior leaflet reconstruction, warranting further in vivo studies to assess long-term remodeling and durability.

title: Fully Implanted Prostheses for Musculoskeletal Limb Reconstruction After Amputation: An In Vivo Feasibility Study
author: Hall P.T.; Bratcher S.Z.; Stubbs C.; Rifkin R.E.; Grzeskowiak R.M.; Burton B.J.; Greenacre C.B.; Stephenson S.M.; Anderson D.E.; Crouch D.L.
abstract: Limb amputation is a life-altering event that often results in significant functional impairment and reduced quality of life. Traditional prosthetic limbs are external devices that can be cumbersome and may not fully restore natural limb function. This study explores the feasibility of fully implanted prostheses for musculoskeletal limb reconstruction after amputation. Using an in vivo animal model, we evaluated the integration, functionality, and biocompatibility of implanted prosthetic devices designed to replace lost musculoskeletal structures. Our findings demonstrate that fully implanted prostheses can achieve stable integration with host tissues, support functional movement, and exhibit promising biocompatibility profiles. These results suggest that fully implanted prosthetic limbs may offer a viable alternative to external prostheses, potentially improving outcomes for amputees. Further research is warranted to optimize device design and assess long-term performance in clinical settings.

title: 3D-printed porous condylar prosthesis for temporomandibular joint replacement: Design and biomechanical analysis
author: Cheng K.-J.; Liu Y.-F.; Wang J.H.; Wang R.; Xia J.; Xu X.; Jiang X.-F.; Dong X.-T.

title: Body-mounted robotic assistant for MRI-guided low back pain injection
author: Li G.; Patel N.A.; Hagemeister J.; Yan J.; Wu D.; Sharma K.; Cleary K.; Iordachita I.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-guided low back pain injection is a promising technique for precise and safe delivery of therapeutic agents. However, the procedure is challenging due to limited access and the need for accurate needle placement within the MRI environment. This paper presents a body-mounted robotic assistant designed to facilitate MRI-guided low back pain injections by improving needle placement accuracy and workflow efficiency.  Methods The proposed robotic system is compact and lightweight, designed to be mounted directly on the patient’s body to minimize relative motion between the robot and the target anatomy. The robot is constructed using MRI-compatible materials and actuated by pneumatic motors to ensure safety and compatibility within the MRI scanner. A control framework integrating real-time MRI feedback and robot kinematics is developed to guide needle insertion. The system’s performance is evaluated through phantom experiments and preliminary in vivo trials.  Results The robotic assistant demonstrated high positioning accuracy within the MRI environment, achieving needle placement errors below clinically acceptable thresholds. The body-mounted design reduced setup time and improved patient comfort compared to traditional table-mounted systems. Real-time MRI guidance enabled precise needle trajectory adjustments during insertion.  Conclusion The body-mounted robotic assistant offers a feasible and effective solution for MRI-guided low back pain injections, enhancing procedural accuracy and efficiency. Future work will focus on clinical validation and integration with advanced imaging techniques to further improve therapeutic outcomes.

title: Orbital floor repair using patient specific osteoinductive implant made by stereolithography
author: Guillaume O.; Geven M.A.; Varjas V.; Varga P.; Gehweiler D.; Stadelmann V.A.; Smidt T.; Zeiter S.; Sprecher C.; Bos R.R.M.; Grijpma D.W.; Alini M.; Yuan H.; Richards G.R.; Tang T.; Qin L.; Yuxiao L.; Jiang P.; Eglin D.
abstract: Orbital floor fractures are common facial injuries that often require surgical repair to restore function and aesthetics. Current repair materials, including autografts, allografts, and synthetic implants, have limitations such as donor site morbidity, risk of infection, and poor integration. Here, we present a novel patient-specific osteoinductive implant fabricated by stereolithography for orbital floor reconstruction. The implant is designed based on patient CT data to precisely fit the defect and is composed of a biocompatible, osteoinductive material that promotes bone regeneration. In vitro and in vivo studies demonstrate the implant's excellent biocompatibility, mechanical strength, and ability to induce new bone formation, leading to successful orbital floor repair with restored anatomical structure and function. This approach offers a promising alternative for personalized orbital reconstruction with improved clinical outcomes.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on implant design, not on predicting or evaluating looks.

title: Recent advance in patient-specific 3D printing templates in mandibular reconstruction
author: Lu T.; Shao Z.; Liu B.; Wu T.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: Recent advances in three-dimensional (3D) printing technology have revolutionized the field of mandibular reconstruction by enabling the fabrication of patient-specific templates. These templates facilitate precise surgical planning and execution, improving the accuracy and efficiency of mandibular reconstruction procedures. This review summarizes the current state of patient-specific 3D printing templates used in mandibular reconstruction, highlighting their design, fabrication processes, and clinical applications. The benefits of using these templates include enhanced anatomical accuracy, reduced operative time, and improved functional and aesthetic outcomes. Challenges such as cost, production time, and material limitations are also discussed. Future directions focus on integrating advanced imaging, computer-aided design, and biocompatible materials to further optimize patient-specific mandibular reconstruction.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on 3D printing, not automated aesthetic evaluation.

title: Lower limb biomechanics before and after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction: A systematic review
author: Moore J.M.; Cessford K.; Willmott A.P.; Raj D.; Exell T.A.; Burbage J.; Mullineaux D.R.
abstract: Anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR) aims to restore knee stability and function; however, altered lower limb biomechanics often persist post-surgery, potentially contributing to poor clinical outcomes and increased risk of re-injury or osteoarthritis. This systematic review synthesizes current evidence on lower limb biomechanics before and after ACLR to identify common biomechanical alterations and their temporal progression. A comprehensive search of electronic databases was conducted to identify studies assessing lower limb kinematics, kinetics, and muscle activation patterns in individuals pre- and post-ACLR. Findings indicate that despite surgical intervention and rehabilitation, deficits in knee joint mechanics, altered movement strategies, and asymmetries in muscle function frequently remain up to several years post-ACLR. These persistent biomechanical abnormalities may underlie compromised functional performance and elevated injury risk. The review highlights the need for targeted rehabilitation strategies addressing specific biomechanical deficits to optimize recovery and long-term joint health following ACLR.
reason_for_title_screening: Looks at biomechanics, not predicting or judging surgical looks.

title: Consulting ‘Dr. Google’ for minimally invasive urological oncological surgeries: A contemporary web-based trend analysis
author: Cacciamani G.E.; Sebben M.; Tafuri A.; Nassiri N.; Cocci A.; Russo G.I.; Hung A.; de Castro Abreu A.L.; Gill I.S.; Artibani W.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
