title: Effect of digital-enabled multidisciplinary therapy conferences on efficiency and quality of the decision making in prostate cancer care
author: Ronmark E.; Hoffmann R.; Skokic V.; De Klerk-Starmans M.; Jaderling F.; Vos P.; Gayet M.C.W.; Hofstraat H.; Janssen M.; Akre O.; Vincent P.H.
abstract: Background: Multidisciplinary therapy conferences (MDTs) are essential for decision making in cancer care but are often time-consuming and lack digital support. This study evaluates the effect of a digital-enabled MDT platform on the efficiency and quality of decision making in prostate cancer care.  Methods: We conducted a prospective observational study comparing MDTs before and after implementation of a digital platform designed to support case preparation, presentation, and documentation. Efficiency was measured by time spent per patient and overall conference duration. Quality was assessed using validated metrics for decision-making completeness and adherence to clinical guidelines.  Results: Implementation of the digital platform significantly reduced the average time spent per patient (p<0.01) and total conference duration (p<0.05). The quality of decisions improved, with increased completeness of case information and higher adherence to guidelines (p<0.05). User satisfaction with the MDT process also increased.  Conclusions: Digital-enabled MDTs enhance efficiency and quality in prostate cancer care decision making. Adoption of such platforms can optimize resource use and improve patient management outcomes.

title: Near-Field Microwave Tomography of Biological Tissues: Future Perspectives
author: Martusevich A.K.; Nazarov V.V.; Surovegina A.V.; Novikov A.V.
abstract: Near-field microwave tomography (NFMT) is an emerging imaging modality that exploits the interaction of microwave signals with biological tissues to reconstruct their dielectric properties at a subwavelength scale. This technique offers promising applications in biomedical engineering, including cancer detection, tissue characterization, and monitoring of physiological changes. The review discusses the fundamental principles of NFMT, recent technological advancements, and challenges such as spatial resolution, penetration depth, and image reconstruction algorithms. Future perspectives highlight the integration of NFMT with other imaging modalities, development of portable devices, and potential clinical translation to improve diagnostic accuracy and patient outcomes.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on imaging and cancer detection, not on aesthetic outcome prediction or evaluation.

title: Does the use of a uterine manipulator in robotic surgery for early-stage endometrial cancer affect oncological outcomes?
author: Ito H.; Moritake T.; Isaka K.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  The use of a uterine manipulator (UM) in minimally invasive surgery for early-stage endometrial cancer (EC) remains controversial due to concerns about potential tumor dissemination and impact on oncological outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of UM use during robotic surgery on oncological outcomes in patients with early-stage EC. We conducted a retrospective analysis of patients with stage I–II EC who underwent robotic hysterectomy with or without UM between 2010 and 2018. Oncological outcomes, including recurrence rates, disease-free survival (DFS), and overall survival (OS), were compared between the two groups. A total of 150 patients were included, with 90 in the UM group and 60 in the no-UM group. There were no significant differences in baseline characteristics between groups. The recurrence rate was 5.6% in the UM group and 6.7% in the no-UM group (p = 0.78). The 3-year DFS and OS rates were comparable between groups (DFS: 94.4% vs. 93.3%, p = 0.85; OS: 96.7% vs. 95.0%, p = 0.72). Multivariate analysis showed that UM use was not an independent predictor of recurrence or survival. Our findings suggest that the use of a uterine manipulator during robotic surgery for early-stage endometrial cancer does not adversely affect oncological outcomes. These results support the safe use of UM in minimally invasive surgical management of early-stage EC.

title: Periosteal expansion osteogenesis using an innovative, shape-memory polyethylene terephthalate membrane: An experimental study in rabbits
author: Imoto K.; Yamauchi K.; Odashima K.; Nogami S.; Shimizu Y.; Kessler P.; Lethaus B.; Unuma H.; Takahashi T.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Periosteal expansion osteogenesis (PEO) is a novel bone augmentation technique that uses the periosteum as an endogenous source of osteoprogenitor cells. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of an innovative, shape-memory polyethylene terephthalate (PET) membrane for PEO in a rabbit calvarial model. Twelve rabbits underwent bilateral calvarial surgery, with the PET membrane placed beneath the periosteum and fixed to the bone to induce periosteal elevation. Animals were sacrificed at 2, 4, and 8 weeks postoperatively for histological and micro-computed tomography analyses. Results demonstrated progressive new bone formation beneath the elevated periosteum, with significant increases in bone volume and thickness over time. The shape-memory PET membrane maintained periosteal elevation effectively without adverse tissue reactions. This study suggests that the shape-memory PET membrane is a promising device for PEO, offering a minimally invasive approach for bone augmentation.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on rabbit bone experiments, not plastic or cancer surgery outcomes.

title: The mechanism of balloon Eustachian tuboplasty: a biomechanical study
author: Smith M.E.; Weir A.E.; Prior D.C.C.; Cope W.; Tysome J.R.; Sutcliffe M.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: Balloon Eustachian tuboplasty (BET) is a minimally invasive treatment for Eustachian tube dysfunction (ETD). However, the mechanism of BET remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the biomechanical mechanism of BET by measuring the deformation of the Eustachian tube (ET) cartilage during balloon inflation. Fresh human cadaveric temporal bones were used. A balloon catheter was inserted into the ET lumen and inflated to 10 atm. The deformation of the ET cartilage was measured using digital image correlation (DIC) techniques. The results showed that balloon inflation caused significant expansion and deformation of the ET cartilage, particularly in the lateral lamina. The maximum principal strain reached up to 20%, indicating plastic deformation. These findings suggest that BET works by mechanically dilating and remodeling the ET cartilage, which may restore ET function in patients with ETD. This biomechanical insight provides a foundation for optimizing BET procedures and improving clinical outcomes.

title: Feasibility of anomaly score detected with deep learning in irradiated breast cancer patients with reconstruction
author: Kim, Dong-Yun and Lee, Soo Jin and Kim, Eun-Kyu and Kang, Eunyoung and Heo, Chan Yeong and Jeong, Jae Hoon and Myung, Yujin and Kim, In Ah and Jang, Bum-Sup
abstract: Radiation therapy (RT) is a critical component of breast cancer treatment, but it can cause complications in patients who undergo breast reconstruction. Early detection of these complications is essential for timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. In this study, we investigated the feasibility of using an anomaly score derived from deep learning models to detect complications in irradiated breast cancer patients with reconstruction. We developed a deep learning framework trained on clinical and imaging data to generate anomaly scores indicative of potential complications. Our results demonstrate that the anomaly score effectively identifies patients at risk of post-RT complications, showing promise as a non-invasive, automated tool for clinical decision support. This approach could enhance monitoring and management strategies for breast cancer patients undergoing reconstruction after radiation therapy.

title: Laparoscopic augmented reality registration for oncological resection site repair
author: Joeres F.; Mielke T.; Hansen C.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Augmented reality (AR) can improve the surgeon’s perception of the surgical site by overlaying preoperative imaging data onto the intraoperative scene. However, the registration of preoperative data to the intraoperative scene remains a challenging task, especially in laparoscopic surgery where the field of view is limited and soft tissue deformation occurs. This paper presents a novel method for laparoscopic AR registration specifically designed for oncological resection site repair. Methods The proposed method uses a combination of feature-based and intensity-based registration techniques to align preoperative computed tomography (CT) images with intraoperative laparoscopic video. The approach incorporates a deformable model to account for soft tissue deformation and employs a real-time tracking system to maintain registration accuracy during surgery. The method was evaluated on a dataset of laparoscopic oncological resections with ground truth annotations. Results The proposed registration method achieved a mean target registration error (TRE) of 3.2 mm, demonstrating improved accuracy compared to existing approaches. The system operated in real-time, maintaining registration throughout the surgical procedure. Qualitative feedback from surgeons indicated enhanced spatial understanding of the resection site. Conclusion The presented laparoscopic AR registration method provides accurate and real-time alignment of preoperative imaging with intraoperative laparoscopic views, facilitating oncological resection site repair. This approach has the potential to improve surgical outcomes by enhancing the surgeon’s perception and precision during minimally invasive oncological procedures.

title: Transplantation of patient-specific bile duct bioengineered with chemically reprogrammed and microtopographically differentiated cells
author: Buisson E.M.; Park S.-H.; Kim M.; Kang K.; Yoon S.; Lee J.E.; Kim Y.W.; Lee N.K.; Jeong M.A.; Kang B.-K.; Lee S.B.; Factor V.M.; Seo D.; Kim H.; Jeong J.; Kim H.J.; Choi D.
abstract: The shortage of donor organs and the lack of effective treatments for biliary diseases have motivated the development of bioengineered bile ducts. Here, we report the transplantation of patient-specific bile ducts bioengineered with chemically reprogrammed and microtopographically differentiated cells. Human chemically derived hepatic progenitor cells (hCdHPCs) were generated from patient-specific fibroblasts using a chemical reprogramming approach. These hCdHPCs were then cultured on microtopographically patterned scaffolds to induce differentiation into cholangiocyte-like cells, forming a functional bile duct tissue. The bioengineered bile ducts exhibited appropriate cellular morphology, marker expression, and bile acid transport function in vitro. Upon transplantation into a rat model with bile duct injury, the bioengineered bile ducts integrated with host tissue, restored bile flow, and improved liver function without eliciting significant immune rejection. This study demonstrates the feasibility of generating patient-specific bioengineered bile ducts using chemically reprogrammed cells and microtopographical cues, offering a promising strategy for personalized regenerative therapy in biliary diseases.

title: The Use of Infrared Thermography in Determining Timing for Early Pedicle Division of the Preexpanded Bipedicled Visor Flap after Ischemic Preconditioning
author: Xiao W.; Zhang S.; Li H.; Feng S.; Nicoli F.; Huynh R.; Lu J.; Zhang Y.; Min P.
abstract: The bipedicled visor flap is a reliable flap for total upper and lower lip reconstruction. However, the timing of pedicle division is crucial to avoid flap necrosis. This study aimed to evaluate the use of infrared thermography (IRT) in determining the timing for early pedicle division of the preexpanded bipedicled visor flap after ischemic preconditioning. A prospective study was conducted on patients undergoing total lip reconstruction with the preexpanded bipedicled visor flap. Ischemic preconditioning was performed by sequential clamping of the pedicles, and IRT was used to monitor flap temperature changes. The timing for pedicle division was determined based on the temperature difference between the flap and surrounding tissue. The results showed that IRT could effectively detect changes in flap perfusion, allowing safe early pedicle division without flap necrosis. The use of IRT provides a noninvasive, real-time, and reliable method to guide the timing of pedicle division in preexpanded bipedicled visor flaps after ischemic preconditioning, potentially reducing the overall treatment time and improving patient outcomes.

title: Unpaired image-to-image translation using cycle-consistent adversarial networks
author: Zhu, Jun-Yan and Park, Taesung and Isola, Phillip and Efros, Alexei A
abstract: Unpaired image-to-image translation is the problem of learning to translate an image from a source domain X to a target domain Y in the absence of paired examples. We present an approach for learning to translate an image from a source domain X to a target domain Y in the absence of paired examples. Our approach consists of two mappings G : X → Y and F : Y → X, and associated adversarial discriminators D_Y and D_X. The goal is to learn these mappings such that the distribution of images from G(X) is indistinguishable from the distribution Y using adversarial loss, and vice versa for F and X. To further regularize the mapping, we introduce a cycle consistency loss that encourages F(G(X)) ≈ X and G(F(Y)) ≈ Y. Qualitative results on several image translation tasks demonstrate the ability of our method to learn mappings between domains without paired data, and quantitative comparisons against prior methods show that our approach outperforms existing methods.

title: Microfluidic-prepared, monodisperse, X-ray-visible, embolic microspheres for non-oncological embolization applications
author: Beh C.W.; Fu Y.; Weiss C.R.; Hu C.; Arepally A.; Mao H.-Q.; Wang T.-H.; Kraitchman D.L.
abstract: Transcatheter embolization is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat a variety of conditions by occluding blood vessels. Current embolic agents, such as polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) particles and microspheres, have limitations including polydispersity and lack of visibility under X-ray imaging, which can affect treatment precision and outcomes. Here, we report the development of monodisperse, X-ray-visible embolic microspheres prepared using a microfluidic platform. These microspheres are composed of a biocompatible polymer matrix loaded with bismuth nanoparticles to confer radiopacity. The microfluidic synthesis allows precise control over particle size and uniformity, resulting in microspheres with narrow size distributions. In vitro characterization demonstrates their stability, biocompatibility, and strong X-ray contrast. Furthermore, in vivo embolization studies in a rabbit model confirm effective vessel occlusion and real-time visualization under fluoroscopy. This work presents a promising approach for producing embolic agents with improved size control and imaging capabilities, potentially enhancing the safety and efficacy of non-oncological embolization procedures.

title: Aesthetic outcome of implants in the anterior zone after socket preservation and conventional implant placement: A retrospective study
author: Rupawat D.; Maiti S.; Nallaswamy D.; Sivaswamy V.
journal: Journal of Long-Term Effects of Medical Implants
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: A novel noncontact high-resolution charge density mapping system to guide ablation of complex atrial arrhythmias: overview of device technology and application
author: Bala G.; De Asmundis C.; Chierchia G.-B.
abstract: Atrial arrhythmias are a common cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Catheter ablation is an established treatment option for many atrial arrhythmias, but the complexity of atrial anatomy and arrhythmia mechanisms can make ablation challenging. Accurate mapping of atrial electrical activity is critical to guide effective ablation. This article provides an overview of a novel noncontact high-resolution charge density mapping system designed to improve the mapping and ablation of complex atrial arrhythmias. The system utilizes a noncontact multi-electrode array to reconstruct high-resolution charge density maps of atrial activation, enabling detailed visualization of arrhythmia mechanisms. We discuss the underlying device technology, mapping principles, and clinical applications, highlighting its potential to enhance procedural efficiency and outcomes in complex atrial arrhythmia ablation.

title: Medrag: Enhancing retrieval-augmented generation with knowledge graph-elicited reasoning for healthcare copilot

title: Robotic radical hysterectomy for stage 1B1 cervical cancer: A case series of survival outcomes from a leading UK cancer centre
author: Patel H.; Madhuri K.; Rockell T.; Montaser R.; Ellis P.; Chatterjee J.; Butler-Manuel S.; Tailor A.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery

title: Collagen membrane for guided bone regeneration in dental and orthopedic applications
author: Allan B.; Ruan R.; Landao-Bassonga E.; Gillman N.; Wang T.; Gao J.; Ruan Y.; Xu Y.; Lee C.; Goonewardene M.; Zheng M.
abstract: Collagen membranes have been widely used in guided bone regeneration (GBR) procedures in dental and orthopedic applications due to their excellent biocompatibility, biodegradability, and ability to facilitate cell adhesion and proliferation. This review summarizes the current advances in collagen membrane technology, including their sources, fabrication methods, and modifications to enhance mechanical properties and biological performance. The clinical outcomes of collagen membranes in GBR are discussed, highlighting their effectiveness in promoting bone regeneration and integration with host tissues. Challenges such as rapid degradation and limited mechanical strength are addressed through cross-linking techniques and incorporation of bioactive molecules. Future perspectives focus on the development of multifunctional collagen membranes with controlled degradation rates and enhanced osteoinductive capabilities to improve clinical success in bone regeneration therapies.

title: Evaluation of facial symmetry after jaw reconstruction surgery
author: Duchscherer J.; Aalto D.; Westover L.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: This study aimed to evaluate facial symmetry after jaw reconstruction surgery using three-dimensional (3D) imaging techniques. A total of 30 patients who underwent jaw reconstruction were assessed preoperatively and postoperatively using 3D stereophotogrammetry. Facial symmetry was quantified by measuring the distances between bilateral anatomical landmarks and calculating asymmetry indices. The results demonstrated a significant improvement in facial symmetry post-surgery, with asymmetry indices decreasing by an average of 35%. The study concludes that 3D imaging provides an effective and objective method for assessing facial symmetry outcomes following jaw reconstruction surgery, aiding in surgical planning and postoperative evaluation.
reason_for_title_screening: Looks at jaw reconstruction but skips automated or advanced computer methods.

title: Biocompatibility and degradation comparisons of four biodegradable copolymeric osteosynthesis systems used in maxillofacial surgery: A goat model with four years follow-up
author: Gareb B.; van Bakelen N.B.; Driessen L.; Buma P.; Kuipers J.; Grijpma D.W.; Vissink A.; Bos R.R.M.; van Minnen B.
abstract: Biodegradable osteosynthesis systems (BOS) have been widely used in maxillofacial surgery, but their long-term biocompatibility and degradation behavior remain unclear. This study aimed to compare the biocompatibility and degradation of four biodegradable copolymeric BOS in a goat model over a four-year follow-up period. Forty-eight goats were randomly assigned to four groups, each receiving one type of BOS: poly(L-lactic acid) (PLLA), poly(L-lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA), poly(L-lactic acid-co-ε-caprolactone) (PLLA-PCL), and poly(L-lactic acid-co-trimethylene carbonate) (PLLA-TMC). Clinical, radiographic, histological, and molecular analyses were performed at 6, 12, 24, and 48 months post-implantation. Results showed that all BOS provided adequate fixation and gradually degraded without adverse tissue reactions. PLLA and PLLA-PCL exhibited slower degradation rates with sustained mechanical integrity, while PLGA and PLLA-TMC degraded faster but induced mild inflammatory responses during early degradation phases. Histological evaluation revealed progressive replacement of BOS by new bone tissue, with PLLA-PCL demonstrating superior osteoconductivity. Molecular assays indicated transient upregulation of inflammatory cytokines correlating with degradation stages. Overall, PLLA-PCL presented the best balance between biocompatibility, degradation rate, and osteointegration, suggesting its potential as an optimal BOS for maxillofacial applications. This long-term comparative study provides valuable insights for selecting biodegradable materials in clinical practice.

title: Utilization of machine learning for the objective assessment of rhinoplasty outcomes
author: Topsakal, Oguzhan and Dobratz, Eric J and Akbas, Mustafa Ilhan and Dougherty, William M and Akinci, Tahir Cetin and Celikoyar, Mehmet Mazhar
abstract: This study explores the application of machine learning techniques to objectively assess rhinoplasty outcomes. Traditional evaluation methods often rely on subjective assessments, which can lead to inconsistent results. By leveraging advanced algorithms and image analysis, the proposed approach aims to provide a standardized and quantifiable measure of surgical success. The methodology involves training models on pre- and post-operative images to detect subtle changes and improvements in nasal structure and aesthetics. Results demonstrate that machine learning can effectively distinguish between different outcome levels, offering a valuable tool for surgeons to evaluate and refine their techniques. This research contributes to the growing field of AI-assisted medical evaluations, promoting more accurate and reproducible assessments in cosmetic surgery.

title: Visual instruction tuning
author: Liu, Haotian and Li, Chunyuan and Wu, Qingyang and Lee, Yong Jae
journal: Advances in neural information processing systems
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Patient-specific plate for navigation and fixation of the distal radius: a case series
author: Dobbe J.G.G.; Peymani A.; Roos H.A.L.; Beerens M.; Streekstra G.J.; Strackee S.D.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of a patient-specific plate (PSP) for navigation and fixation of the distal radius in a clinical setting. Methods A PSP was designed and manufactured for 10 patients with distal radius fractures. The PSP was used intraoperatively for navigation and fixation. Postoperative CT scans were used to assess the accuracy of fracture reduction and implant positioning. Results The PSP was successfully used in all cases without intraoperative complications. The mean deviation between planned and achieved implant position was less than 1 mm. Fracture reduction was anatomically accurate in all patients. Conclusion The use of a PSP for navigation and fixation of distal radius fractures is feasible and allows for accurate implant positioning and fracture reduction. This approach has the potential to improve surgical outcomes in distal radius fracture treatment.

title: Mitral valve flattening and parameter mapping for patient-specific valve diagnosis
author: Lichtenberg N.; Eulzer P.; Romano G.; Brčić A.; Karck M.; Lawonn K.; De Simone R.; Engelhardt S.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Mitral valve (MV) disease is a common heart valve disease that can lead to heart failure. Patient-specific MV diagnosis is essential for treatment planning and outcome prediction. However, current clinical diagnosis relies on qualitative assessment and lacks quantitative parameters that characterize MV morphology and function. This study aims to develop a novel method for MV flattening and parameter mapping to enable quantitative and patient-specific MV diagnosis.  Methods: We propose a computational framework that flattens the 3D MV geometry into a 2D parametric domain while preserving anatomical features. The method involves segmenting the MV from 3D echocardiographic images, reconstructing the 3D MV surface, and applying a flattening algorithm to map the surface onto a 2D plane. We then extract morphological and functional parameters from the flattened MV, such as leaflet area, annulus shape, and coaptation metrics. The framework is validated on synthetic and clinical datasets.  Results: The proposed flattening method successfully maps complex 3D MV geometries into 2D domains with minimal distortion, enabling intuitive visualization and quantitative analysis. Parameter mapping reveals significant differences in MV morphology between healthy and diseased valves. The method demonstrates potential for improving patient-specific MV diagnosis and aiding clinical decision-making.  Conclusion: This study presents a novel MV flattening and parameter mapping approach that facilitates quantitative and patient-specific MV diagnosis. The framework can enhance understanding of MV pathology and support personalized treatment planning. Future work includes integrating dynamic MV function analysis and clinical validation on larger patient cohorts.

title: Central perforated VRAM flap and neurostimulated levator augmentation for functional and aesthetical reconstruction after abdominoperineal excision in cancer
author: Bernuth S.; Jakubietz M.; Isbert C.; Reibetanz J.; Meffert R.; Jakubietz R.; Schmidt K.

title: Nonrigid reconstruction of 3D breast surfaces with a low-cost RGBD camera for surgical planning and aesthetic evaluation
author: Lacher R.M.; Vasconcelos F.; Williams N.R.; Rindermann G.; Hipwell J.; Hawkes D.; Stoyanov D.
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) surface reconstruction of the breast is a key step in computer-assisted breast surgery planning and aesthetic evaluation. However, current 3D imaging systems are either expensive or require complex setups, limiting their clinical use. In this paper, we propose a novel nonrigid reconstruction method using a low-cost RGBD camera to capture the breast surface in multiple views. Our approach addresses the challenges posed by breast deformation and patient movement during acquisition by integrating a nonrigid registration framework that aligns partial scans into a consistent 3D model. We validate our method on synthetic and real data, demonstrating improved accuracy and robustness compared to rigid registration techniques. The proposed system offers a cost-effective and practical solution for 3D breast surface reconstruction, facilitating enhanced surgical planning and aesthetic assessment in clinical practice.

title: A comparison of methods of cosmetic assessment in breast conservation treatment
author: Christie, DRH and O'brien, MY and Christie, JA and Kron, T and Ferguson, SA and Hamilton, CS and Denham, JW

title: Endpoint Detection in Breast Images for Automatic Classification of Breast Cancer Aesthetic Results
author: Freitas, Nuno and Veloso, Carlos and Mavioso, Carlos and Cardoso, Maria J and Oliveira, H{\'e}lder P and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Muscle volume reconstruction from several short magnetic resonance imaging sequences
author: Marzilger R.; Schroll A.; Bohm S.; Arampatzis A.
abstract: Muscle volume is an important parameter for biomechanical modeling and clinical applications. However, acquiring full muscle volume data using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can be time-consuming and challenging, especially in clinical settings. This study proposes a method to reconstruct muscle volume from several short MRI sequences, reducing acquisition time while maintaining accuracy. The approach involves segmenting muscle cross-sectional areas from limited MRI slices and employing interpolation techniques to estimate the full muscle volume. Validation against complete MRI datasets demonstrates that the reconstructed volumes closely approximate the actual muscle volumes, suggesting that this method can effectively facilitate muscle volume estimation in both research and clinical contexts.

title: Safety profile and oncological outcomes of gastric gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) robotic resection: Single center experience
author: Maggioni C.; Shida A.; Mancini R.; Ioni L.; Pernazza G.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic surgery has been increasingly used for the treatment of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) of the stomach. This study aims to evaluate the safety profile and oncological outcomes of robotic gastric GIST resection in a single center experience. We retrospectively analyzed data from patients who underwent robotic resection for gastric GISTs, focusing on perioperative outcomes, complications, and long-term oncological results. Our findings demonstrate that robotic resection is a safe and feasible approach with low morbidity and favorable oncological outcomes, suggesting it as a viable minimally invasive option for gastric GIST management.

title: Comparisons of anterior plate screw pullout strength between polyurethane foams and thoracolumbar cadaveric vertebrae
author: Nagaraja S.; Palepu V.
abstract: Anterior plate fixation is a common technique used in spinal surgery to stabilize the vertebrae. The pullout strength of screws used in anterior plates is critical for the success of the fixation. This study compares the pullout strength of anterior plate screws in polyurethane foams, which are commonly used as bone substitutes in biomechanical testing, with that in thoracolumbar cadaveric vertebrae. The objective is to evaluate the validity of using polyurethane foams as a surrogate for human vertebrae in biomechanical testing of anterior plate screw fixation. The results indicate differences in pullout strength between the two materials, providing insights into the appropriateness of polyurethane foams for simulating human vertebral bone in such tests.

title: Investigating the use of image thresholding in brachytherapy catheter reconstruction
author: Binny D.; Lancaster C.M.; Kairn T.; Trapp J.V.; Back P.; Cheuk R.; Crowe S.B.
journal: Australasian Physical and Engineering Sciences in Medicine
abstract: Accurate catheter reconstruction is essential for effective brachytherapy treatment planning. This study investigates the use of image thresholding techniques to improve the reconstruction of brachytherapy catheters from imaging data. Various thresholding methods were applied to clinical images to segment the catheters, and their performance was evaluated in terms of accuracy and efficiency. The results demonstrate that appropriate thresholding can enhance catheter visualization and facilitate more precise reconstruction, potentially leading to improved treatment outcomes. The study highlights the benefits and limitations of image thresholding in this context and suggests directions for future research to optimize catheter reconstruction workflows in brachytherapy.

title: Time-dependent bladder tissue regeneration using bilayer bladder acellular matrix graft-silk fibroin scaffolds in a rat bladder augmentation model
author: Zhao Y.; He Y.; Guo J.-H.; Wu J.-S.; Zhou Z.; Zhang M.; Li W.; Zhou J.; Xiao D.-D.; Wang Z.; Sun K.; Zhu Y.-J.; Lu M.-J.
abstract: Bladder acellular matrix graft (BAMG) has been widely used in bladder tissue engineering, but its poor mechanical properties and rapid degradation limit its application. In this study, we fabricated a bilayer scaffold composed of BAMG and silk fibroin (SF) to improve the mechanical properties and prolong the degradation time for bladder tissue regeneration. The bilayer scaffold was characterized by scanning electron microscopy, mechanical testing, and in vitro degradation. The scaffold was then implanted in a rat bladder augmentation model, and bladder tissue regeneration was evaluated at 2, 4, and 12 weeks post-implantation by histological, immunohistochemical, and urodynamic analyses. The bilayer scaffold exhibited improved mechanical strength and slower degradation compared to BAMG alone. Histological analysis showed progressive regeneration of urothelium, smooth muscle, and blood vessels over time. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the presence of contractile smooth muscle markers and endothelial markers in the regenerated tissue. Urodynamic studies demonstrated improved bladder capacity and compliance in the bilayer scaffold group compared to controls. These results suggest that the bilayer BAMG-SF scaffold provides a favorable microenvironment for time-dependent bladder tissue regeneration and functional recovery, offering a promising strategy for bladder augmentation.

title: Regenerating a ventricular cavity during left ventricular assist device implantation
author: Altas O.; Ozer T.; Ozgur M.M.; Sarikaya S.; Kirali K.
abstract: Left ventricular assist device (LVAD) implantation is a well-established therapy for patients with end-stage heart failure. However, the presence of a severely dilated and dysfunctional left ventricle (LV) can complicate the procedure and affect postoperative outcomes. This study explores a novel surgical technique aimed at regenerating the ventricular cavity during LVAD implantation to optimize device function and patient prognosis. By employing targeted myocardial remodeling and cavity reshaping strategies, the approach seeks to restore more physiological LV geometry and improve hemodynamics. Initial clinical experiences suggest that this method may enhance LVAD performance and patient recovery, warranting further investigation in larger cohorts.

title: 3D collagen microfibers stimulate the functionality of preadipocytes and maintain the phenotype of mature adipocytes for long term cultures
author: Louis F.; Kitano S.; Mano J.F.; Matsusaki M.
abstract: Adipose tissue engineering is a promising approach for soft tissue reconstruction and in vitro models for drug screening and disease modeling. However, maintaining mature adipocytes in culture remains challenging due to their fragility and tendency to dedifferentiate. Here, we developed a 3D culture system based on collagen microfibers to support both preadipocytes and mature adipocytes. Collagen microfibers were produced by electrospinning and assembled into 3D scaffolds that mimic the native extracellular matrix architecture. Preadipocytes cultured on these scaffolds showed enhanced proliferation and differentiation capacity compared to 2D cultures. Importantly, mature adipocytes maintained their phenotype, including lipid content and adipogenic marker expression, for extended periods in 3D culture, whereas they rapidly lost these features in 2D. This 3D collagen microfiber system provides a physiologically relevant microenvironment that supports adipocyte functionality and phenotype maintenance, offering a valuable platform for adipose tissue engineering and related biomedical applications.

title: A Novel Vascular Coupling System for End-to-End Anastomosis
author: Li H.; Gale B.K.; Sant H.; Shea J.; David Bell E.; Agarwal J.
abstract: A novel vascular coupling system (VCS) for end-to-end anastomosis was developed to overcome the limitations of existing devices. The VCS consists of two interlocking rings with multiple microhooks that securely hold the vessel ends together without the need for sutures. In vitro testing demonstrated that the VCS provided a leak-proof seal and maintained patency under physiological flow conditions. In vivo evaluation in a rabbit carotid artery model showed that the VCS enabled rapid anastomosis with reduced operative time and minimal intimal hyperplasia compared to traditional sutured anastomosis. Histological analysis confirmed endothelialization over the device surface by 14 days post-implantation. The novel VCS offers a promising alternative for vascular anastomosis with potential benefits in surgical efficiency and vessel healing.

title: Mechanical stretching stimulates growth of the basal layer and rete ridges in the epidermis
author: Topczewska J.M.; Ledwon J.K.; Vaca E.E.; Gosain A.K.
journal: Journal of Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
abstract: Mechanical stretching is known to influence skin growth and remodeling, but the underlying cellular mechanisms remain unclear. This study investigates the effects of mechanical stretching on the basal layer and rete ridges of the epidermis. Using an in vitro skin model subjected to controlled mechanical stretching, we observed significant stimulation of basal keratinocyte proliferation and elongation of rete ridges. Histological analysis revealed increased thickness of the basal layer and enhanced epidermal-dermal interactions. These findings suggest that mechanical stretching promotes epidermal growth by stimulating basal layer expansion and rete ridge formation, providing insights into skin regeneration and potential therapeutic approaches for wound healing and tissue engineering.

title: Custom implant design for large cranial defects
author: Marreiros F.M.M.; Heuzé Y.; Verius M.; Unterhofer C.; Freysinger W.; Recheis W.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Cranial defects resulting from trauma, tumor resection, or decompressive craniectomy require reconstruction to protect the brain and restore aesthetics. Custom implants are increasingly used for large cranial defects, but their design remains challenging due to complex defect geometries and the need for precise fit. This study presents a novel method for custom implant design based on patient-specific imaging data.  Methods The proposed approach utilizes computed tomography (CT) scans to generate a three-dimensional model of the skull and defect. A mirror-imaging technique is applied to reconstruct the missing bone geometry, followed by surface smoothing and thickness adjustment to create the implant model. The design process is semi-automated to reduce time and improve reproducibility.  Results The method was applied to several clinical cases with large cranial defects. The resulting implants demonstrated excellent fit and contour restoration when evaluated against the original skull anatomy. The design time was significantly reduced compared to traditional manual methods.  Conclusions The presented custom implant design method offers an efficient and reliable solution for reconstructing large cranial defects. It facilitates precise implant fabrication, potentially improving surgical outcomes and patient satisfaction. Future work will focus on integrating biomechanical analysis and surgical planning tools.

title: Parylene scaffold for cartilage lesion
author: Franciozi C.E.S.; Vangsness C.T., Jr.; Tibone J.E.; Martinez J.C.; Rodger D.; Chou T.-C.; Tai Y.-C.; Brant R.; Wu L.; Abdalla R.J.; Han B.; Evseenko D.; Humayun M.
abstract: Cartilage lesions are a common clinical problem and their treatment remains a challenge. Tissue engineering approaches using scaffolds have been proposed to improve cartilage repair. In this study, we developed a novel parylene-based scaffold for cartilage tissue engineering. Parylene, a biocompatible and chemically inert polymer, was fabricated into a porous scaffold structure suitable for cell attachment and proliferation. The scaffold's physical and chemical properties were characterized, and its biocompatibility was evaluated using chondrocyte cultures. Results demonstrated that the parylene scaffold supports chondrocyte adhesion and growth, maintaining the chondrogenic phenotype. These findings suggest that parylene scaffolds have potential as a platform for cartilage tissue engineering and repair of cartilage lesions.

title: Reconstruction of medial patello-femoral ligament: Comparison of two surgical techniques
author: Criscenti G.; De Maria C.; Sebastiani E.; Tei M.; Placella G.; Speziali A.; Vozzi G.; Cerulli G.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: A novel artificial intelligence model for symmetry evaluation in breast cancer patients
author: Kenig, Nitzan and Monton Echeverria, Javier and Chang Azancot, Luis and De la Ossa, Luis
abstract: Breast symmetry is an important factor in the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer patients after surgery. Traditional methods for assessing breast symmetry are subjective and lack standardization. This study proposes a novel artificial intelligence (AI) model designed to objectively evaluate breast symmetry in breast cancer patients. The model utilizes advanced image processing techniques and deep learning algorithms to analyze postoperative breast images, providing quantitative symmetry scores. The AI model was trained and validated on a dataset of breast cancer patient images, demonstrating high accuracy and reliability compared to expert assessments. This approach offers a standardized, reproducible, and efficient tool for clinicians to assess breast symmetry, potentially improving postoperative evaluation and patient satisfaction.

title: Error-Free Text Typing Performance of an Inductive Intra-Oral Tongue Computer Interface for Severely Disabled Individuals
author: Andreasen Struijk L.N.S.; Bentsen B.; Gaihede M.; Lontis E.R.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
doi: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.
abstract: This paper presents an inductive intra-oral tongue computer interface (ITCI) designed to enable severely disabled individuals to perform error-free text typing. The ITCI system utilizes an inductive sensing mechanism embedded within a dental retainer, which detects tongue movements and translates them into computer commands. The study evaluates the system's performance in terms of typing speed, accuracy, and user comfort. Experimental results demonstrate that the ITCI achieves high accuracy with error-free text input and offers a promising communication solution for individuals with severe motor impairments. The findings suggest that the ITCI can significantly enhance the quality of life for users by providing an effective and reliable means of computer interaction.

title: The Application of Three-Dimensional Printing in Animal Model of Augmentation Rhinoplasty
author: Kim Y.S.; Shin Y.S.; Park D.Y.; Choi J.W.; Park J.K.; Kim D.H.; Kim C.H.; Park S.A.
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) printing has been widely used in medical fields, but its application in animal models of augmentation rhinoplasty has not been reported. This study aimed to explore the feasibility and effectiveness of 3D printing technology in establishing an animal model of augmentation rhinoplasty. A 3D digital model of the nasal implant was designed based on computed tomography (CT) data of a rabbit's nasal bone and soft tissue. The implant was fabricated using 3D printing technology with biocompatible materials. The implant was surgically implanted into the nasal dorsum of rabbits to simulate augmentation rhinoplasty. Postoperative evaluation included clinical observation, CT imaging, and histological analysis. The results demonstrated that the 3D-printed implant fit well with the nasal anatomy, maintained its shape and position, and induced minimal inflammatory response. This study indicates that 3D printing technology can be effectively applied to create precise and individualized implants for animal models of augmentation rhinoplasty, providing a valuable platform for further research in nasal reconstruction and implant development.

title: The PRISMA 2020 statement: an updated guideline for reporting systematic reviews
author: Page, Matthew J and McKenzie, Joanne E and Bossuyt, Patrick M and Boutron, Isabelle and Hoffmann, Tammy C and Mulrow, Cynthia D and Shamseer, Larissa and Tetzlaff, Jennifer M and Akl, Elie A and Brennan, Sue E and others
abstract: Systematic reviews are essential for summarizing evidence to inform healthcare decisions. The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement, published in 2009, is a widely used reporting guideline for systematic reviews and meta-analyses. Since then, advances in systematic review methodology and terminology, as well as developments in technology, have prompted an update to the PRISMA statement. We present the PRISMA 2020 statement, an updated guideline for reporting systematic reviews. The PRISMA 2020 statement includes a 27-item checklist and an expanded explanation and elaboration document. The checklist items cover the title, abstract, introduction, methods, results, discussion, and other information. The updated guideline aims to help authors improve the reporting of systematic reviews, thereby facilitating their use by readers, including clinicians, policymakers, and researchers. The PRISMA 2020 statement is intended for use by authors, editors, and peer reviewers to ensure transparent and complete reporting of systematic reviews.

title: Hydroxyapatite and bioactive glass surfaces for fiber reinforced composite implants via surface ablation by Excimer laser
author: Kulkova J.; Moritz N.; Huhtinen H.; Mattila R.; Donati I.; Marsich E.; Paoletti S.; Vallittu P.K.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: Hydroxyapatite (HA) and bioactive glass (BG) coatings on fiber reinforced composites (FRC) are promising for bone implant applications due to their bioactivity and mechanical properties. In this study, surface ablation by Excimer laser was used to modify the surfaces of HA and BG coatings on FRC substrates to enhance their bioactivity and adhesion. The laser treatment induced surface roughness and microstructural changes, which were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The bioactivity of the laser-treated surfaces was evaluated by immersion in simulated body fluid (SBF), showing enhanced apatite formation compared to untreated samples. Mechanical testing demonstrated improved interfacial bonding strength between the coatings and the FRC substrates after laser ablation. These findings suggest that Excimer laser surface ablation is an effective method to improve the performance of HA and BG coatings on FRC implants for bone tissue engineering applications.

title: Prognosis-Based Shoulder Hemiarthroplasty After Resection of Proximal Humeral Malignancy
author: Chen C.-M.; Wu P.-K.; Tsai S.-W.; Chen C.-F.; Chen W.-M.
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Quantitative comparison of three rat models of Achilles tendon injury: A multidisciplinary approach
author: Huegel J.; Boorman-Padgett J.F.; Nuss C.A.; Minnig M.C.C.; Chan P.Y.; Kuntz A.F.; Waldorff E.I.; Zhang N.; Ryaby J.T.; Soslowsky L.J.
abstract: Tendon injury models are essential for understanding the pathophysiology of tendon healing and for developing new therapeutic strategies. However, the lack of standardized injury models and comprehensive characterization limits the comparability of results across studies. This study aimed to quantitatively compare three commonly used rat models of Achilles tendon injury: partial transection, full transection with suture repair, and collagenase-induced injury. Using a multidisciplinary approach, we assessed the structural, mechanical, and histological properties of the tendons at multiple time points post-injury. Our results demonstrate distinct healing patterns and mechanical outcomes among the models, highlighting the importance of model selection based on the specific research question. This comprehensive comparison provides valuable insights for researchers in selecting appropriate Achilles tendon injury models and interpreting experimental outcomes.

title: Evolution, current challenges, and future possibilities in the objective assessment of aesthetic outcome of breast cancer locoregional treatment
author: Cardoso, Jaime S and Silva, Wilson and Cardoso, Maria J
abstract: Aesthetic outcome assessment after breast cancer locoregional treatment is an important aspect of patient care and research. Over the years, methods have evolved from subjective evaluations by clinicians to more objective and reproducible techniques, including computer-based analyses and patient-reported outcome measures. Despite advancements, challenges remain in standardizing assessment protocols, integrating multimodal data, and addressing the subjective nature of aesthetic satisfaction. Future possibilities include the use of artificial intelligence, three-dimensional imaging, and personalized assessment tools to enhance accuracy and clinical relevance. This review discusses the evolution, current challenges, and future directions in the objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes following breast cancer locoregional treatment.

title: Electrospun nanofiber mesh with fibroblast growth factor and stem cells for pelvic floor repair
author: Hansen S.G.; Taskin M.B.; Chen M.; Wogensen L.; Vinge Nygaard J.; Axelsen S.M.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Electrospun nanofiber mesh with fibroblast growth factor and stem cells for pelvic floor repair  Abstract: Pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) are common conditions that significantly affect women's quality of life. Current surgical treatments often involve synthetic meshes, which can lead to complications such as erosion and infection. Tissue engineering approaches using biocompatible scaffolds combined with bioactive molecules and stem cells offer promising alternatives. In this study, we developed an electrospun nanofiber mesh incorporating fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) to enhance pelvic floor repair. The mesh was fabricated using polycaprolactone (PCL) and gelatin, providing a suitable microenvironment for cell attachment and proliferation. FGF was incorporated to promote angiogenesis and tissue regeneration. In vitro assays demonstrated that the FGF-loaded mesh supported ADSC viability, proliferation, and differentiation. In vivo implantation in a rat model of pelvic floor injury showed improved tissue integration, neovascularization, and mechanical strength compared to control meshes. These findings suggest that the electrospun nanofiber mesh with FGF and ADSCs is a promising candidate for pelvic floor tissue engineering and repair.

title: Computation of breast ptosis from 3D surface scans of the female torso
author: Li D.; Cheong A.; Reece G.P.; Crosby M.A.; Fingeret M.C.; Merchant F.A.
abstract: Breast ptosis is a common condition that is characterized by the downward displacement of the breast tissue and nipple relative to the chest wall. Accurate quantification of breast ptosis is important for clinical assessment, surgical planning, and outcome evaluation in breast surgery. Traditional methods for assessing breast ptosis rely on manual measurements and subjective grading scales, which can be inconsistent and lack precision. In this study, we present a novel computational approach to quantify breast ptosis using three-dimensional (3D) surface scans of the female torso. Our method involves the extraction of anatomical landmarks and the computation of ptosis indices based on the spatial relationships between these landmarks on the 3D breast surface. We validate our approach on a dataset of 3D scans from a diverse cohort of female subjects and demonstrate its accuracy and reproducibility compared to conventional assessment methods. The proposed computational framework offers an objective, non-invasive, and efficient tool for the evaluation of breast ptosis, with potential applications in clinical practice and research.

title: Nyquist and Bode stability criteria to assess changes in dynamic knee stability in healthy and anterior cruciate ligament reconstructed individuals during walking
author: Morgan K.D.; Zheng Y.; Bush H.; Noehren B.
abstract: Dynamic knee stability is essential for normal walking and is often compromised following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR). Traditional biomechanical measures may not fully capture the dynamic stability of the knee joint during gait. This study applied Nyquist and Bode stability criteria, commonly used in control systems engineering, to assess changes in dynamic knee stability in healthy individuals and those with ACLR during walking. Knee joint kinematics and kinetics were recorded, and system stability was evaluated by analyzing the frequency response of knee joint dynamics. Results indicated that individuals with ACLR exhibited altered dynamic stability characteristics compared to healthy controls, with implications for rehabilitation and injury prevention strategies. These findings suggest that Nyquist and Bode criteria provide valuable insights into knee joint stability beyond conventional biomechanical assessments.

title: The convergence of regenerative medicine and rehabilitation: federal perspectives
author: Rose L.F.; Wolf E.J.; Brindle T.; Cernich A.; Dean W.K.; Dearth C.L.; Grimm M.; Kusiak A.; Nitkin R.; Potter K.; Randolph B.J.; Wang F.; Yamaguchi D.
abstract: Regenerative medicine and rehabilitation share the common goal of restoring function and quality of life to individuals with disabling conditions. The convergence of these fields offers new opportunities to enhance recovery and improve outcomes. This article provides federal perspectives on the integration of regenerative medicine and rehabilitation, highlighting current initiatives, challenges, and future directions to advance this interdisciplinary approach.
reason_for_title_screening: Covers federal policy, not surgery outcome prediction.

title: Application of artificial intelligence in oculoplastics
author: Cai, Yilu and Zhang, Xuan and Cao, Jing and Grzybowski, Andrzej and Ye, Juan and Lou, Lixia

title: Semiautomatic neck curve reconstruction for intracranial aneurysm rupture risk assessment based on morphological parameters
author: Saalfeld S.; Berg P.; Niemann A.; Luz M.; Preim B.; Beuing O.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The rupture risk assessment of intracranial aneurysms (IAs) is a challenging task in clinical practice. Morphological parameters of IAs have been widely used for rupture risk assessment. However, the neck curve, which is the boundary between the aneurysm sac and the parent vessel, is difficult to reconstruct accurately and consistently. This paper proposes a semiautomatic method for neck curve reconstruction to improve the accuracy and reproducibility of morphological parameters for IA rupture risk assessment. Methods The proposed method first extracts the IA sac and parent vessel from 3D rotational angiography images. Then, a semiautomatic neck curve reconstruction algorithm is applied, which involves initial manual selection of points on the neck region followed by an automatic curve fitting process. Morphological parameters based on the reconstructed neck curve are calculated and used for rupture risk assessment. Results The method was evaluated on a dataset of 50 IAs, demonstrating improved accuracy and reproducibility of neck curve reconstruction compared to manual delineation. The morphological parameters derived from the semiautomatic neck curve showed better discrimination between ruptured and unruptured IAs. Conclusion The proposed semiautomatic neck curve reconstruction method provides a reliable and consistent way to define the neck boundary of IAs, enhancing the morphological analysis for rupture risk assessment. This approach has the potential to assist clinicians in making more informed treatment decisions.

title: Surgical soundtracks: automatic acoustic augmentation of surgical procedures
author: Matinfar S.; Nasseri M.A.; Eck U.; Kowalsky M.; Roodaki H.; Navab N.; Lohmann C.P.; Maier M.; Navab N.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Surgical procedures are often accompanied by characteristic sounds, which can provide useful information about the surgical workflow and the current surgical phase. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to automatically augment surgical procedures with acoustic feedback, which can support surgeons by providing additional information through sound. Methods: We present a system that captures and analyzes surgical sounds in real time and generates corresponding acoustic augmentations. The system uses machine learning techniques to classify surgical phases based on audio features extracted from the recorded sounds. Results: We evaluated our approach on a dataset of recorded surgical procedures and demonstrated that the system can accurately recognize surgical phases and generate meaningful acoustic feedback. The acoustic augmentation was shown to improve the awareness of the surgical workflow and potentially enhance surgical performance. Conclusion: Our work introduces a new paradigm of using sound as an informative and supportive modality in the operating room. The proposed system can serve as a foundation for further research on acoustic augmentation in surgery and its integration into surgical training and practice.

title: In vivo endothelialization and neointimal hyperplasia assessment after angioplasty of sheep carotid artery with a novel polycarbonate polyurethane patch
author: Jalaie H.; Steitz J.; Afify M.; Barbati M.E.; Hoeft K.; Assar M.A.M.; Hermanns-Sachweh B.; Tolba R.H.; Jacobs M.J.; Schleimer K.
abstract: Endothelialization and neointimal hyperplasia are critical factors influencing the long-term success of vascular patches used in angioplasty. This study evaluates the in vivo endothelialization and neointimal hyperplasia of a novel polycarbonate polyurethane (PCU) patch implanted in the sheep carotid artery following angioplasty. The PCU patch was implanted in 12 sheep, and assessments were conducted at 1, 3, and 6 months post-implantation. Histological and immunohistochemical analyses were performed to evaluate endothelial coverage and neointimal thickness. Results demonstrated progressive endothelialization over the PCU patch surface, with complete endothelial coverage observed by 6 months. Neointimal hyperplasia was minimal and stable over time, indicating favorable vascular healing responses. These findings suggest that the novel PCU patch promotes effective endothelialization while limiting neointimal hyperplasia, supporting its potential use in vascular reconstructive procedures.

title: Performance of marrow stromal cell-seeded small-caliber multilayered vascular graft in a senescent sheep model
author: Madhavan K.; Elliot W.; Tan Y.; Monnet E.; Tan W.
abstract: The development of small-caliber vascular grafts (SCVGs) with long-term patency remains a challenge in tissue engineering. Here, we fabricated a multilayered SCVG composed of an inner electrospun polycaprolactone (PCL) layer, a middle layer of PCL and gelatin, and an outer layer of PCL and collagen. The graft was seeded with autologous bone marrow stromal cells (BMSCs) and implanted into the carotid artery of senescent sheep (aged 7–9 years) for 6 months. The BMSC-seeded grafts showed a patency rate of 83.3% (5/6), whereas the unseeded grafts had a patency rate of 50% (3/6). Histological analysis revealed endothelialization and smooth muscle cell infiltration in the BMSC-seeded grafts, with extracellular matrix deposition and neovascularization. The results demonstrate that BMSC seeding enhances the performance of multilayered SCVGs in a senescent large animal model, suggesting potential for clinical application in elderly patients.

title: Robotic assisted laparoscopic partial nephrectomy using contrast-enhanced ultrasound scan to map renal blood flow
author: Alenezi A.; Motiwala A.; Eves S.; Gray R.; Thomas A.; Meiers I.; Sharif H.; Motiwala H.; Laniado M.; Karim O.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) is a novel imaging technique that allows real-time visualization of microvascular blood flow. We report the first case of robotic-assisted laparoscopic partial nephrectomy (RALPN) using intraoperative CEUS to map renal blood flow. A 62-year-old man with a 3.5 cm left renal mass underwent RALPN. After hilar clamping, CEUS was performed using an intravenous bolus of SonoVue® to identify the tumor and assess the perfusion of the renal parenchyma. CEUS allowed clear delineation of the tumor and identification of the ischemic area, guiding precise tumor excision and minimizing ischemic injury to the remaining kidney. The procedure was completed successfully with minimal blood loss and no complications. This case demonstrates that intraoperative CEUS is a feasible and valuable adjunct in RALPN, providing real-time assessment of renal perfusion and aiding in surgical decision-making. Further studies are warranted to evaluate its impact on surgical outcomes.

title: Chitosan-film enhanced chitosan nerve guides for long-distance regeneration of peripheral nerves
author: Meyer C.; Stenberg L.; Gonzalez-Perez F.; Wrobel S.; Ronchi G.; Udina E.; Suganuma S.; Geuna S.; Navarro X.; Dahlin L.B.; Grothe C.; Haastert-Talini K.
abstract: Peripheral nerve injuries with long gaps require nerve autografts for repair, but these have limitations such as donor site morbidity and limited availability. Artificial nerve guides are promising alternatives, but their efficacy decreases with increasing gap length. In this study, we developed chitosan-film enhanced chitosan nerve guides (CFeCNGs) by inserting a perforated chitosan film into hollow chitosan nerve guides to create two chambers, aiming to improve long-distance peripheral nerve regeneration. We evaluated their performance in a 15 mm rat sciatic nerve defect model compared to hollow chitosan nerve guides (hCNGs) and autologous nerve grafts (ANGs). Functional recovery was assessed by walking track analysis, electrophysiology, and histomorphometry after 4 and 12 weeks. CFeCNGs showed significantly improved functional and morphological outcomes compared to hCNGs and approached the results of ANGs. The chitosan film likely provides additional guidance cues and a favorable microenvironment for axonal growth. These findings suggest that CFeCNGs are a promising strategy for enhancing peripheral nerve regeneration over long gaps.

title: Fibrous composite material for textile heart valve design: In vitro assessment
author: Amri A.; Laroche G.; Chakfe N.; Heim F.
abstract: The development of a textile heart valve (THV) with a fibrous composite material (FCM) is presented. The FCM is composed of a textile fabric and a polymeric matrix, which are combined to improve the mechanical properties and durability of the valve. The in vitro assessment of the THV was performed to evaluate its hydrodynamic performance and durability under physiological conditions. The results demonstrated that the THV with FCM exhibited satisfactory opening and closing behavior, low regurgitation, and good durability after accelerated wear testing. These findings suggest that the fibrous composite material is a promising candidate for the design of textile heart valves, potentially offering improved performance and longevity compared to conventional materials.
reason_for_title_screening: Title's about heart valve materials, not surgery outcome predictions.

title: Rothmund-Thomson syndrome: Insights from new patients on the genetic variability underpinning clinical presentation and cancer outcome
author: Colombo E.A.; Locatelli A.; Sánchez L.C.; Romeo S.; Elcioglu N.H.; Maystadt I.; Martínez A.E.; Sironi A.; Fontana L.; Finelli P.; Gervasini C.; Pecile V.; Larizza L.
abstract: Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS) is a rare autosomal recessive genodermatosis characterized by poikiloderma, skeletal abnormalities, and an increased risk of osteosarcoma and skin cancer. RTS is caused by mutations in the RECQL4 gene, which encodes a DNA helicase involved in DNA replication and repair. Here, we report on new RTS patients and provide insights into the genetic variability underlying the clinical presentation and cancer outcome. We describe the clinical features and molecular findings of five new RTS patients, highlighting the phenotypic variability and the spectrum of RECQL4 mutations. Our data support the existence of genotype-phenotype correlations, with certain mutations associated with a higher risk of malignancy. This study expands the mutational spectrum of RECQL4 and underscores the importance of genetic analysis for prognosis and management of RTS patients.

title: Radiographic reconstruction of lower-extremity bone fragments: a first trial
author: Schumann S.; Bieck R.; Bader R.; Heverhagen J.; Nolte L.-P.; Zheng G.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The reconstruction of bone fragments is a challenging task in orthopedic surgery and forensic medicine. The aim of this study was to develop a method for the radiographic reconstruction of lower-extremity bone fragments. Methods A novel approach was proposed to reconstruct bone fragments from radiographic images. The method involved segmentation of bone fragments, registration, and alignment to reconstruct the original bone shape. The approach was tested on synthetic and real radiographic images of lower-extremity bones. Results The proposed method successfully reconstructed the bone fragments with high accuracy. The reconstructed bones showed good agreement with the original bone shapes, demonstrating the feasibility of the approach. Conclusion This study presents a first trial of radiographic reconstruction of lower-extremity bone fragments, providing a foundation for further research and clinical applications in orthopedic surgery and forensic analysis.

title: In vitro evaluation of decellularized ECM-derived surgical scaffold biomaterials
author: Luo X.; Kulig K.M.; Finkelstein E.B.; Nicholson M.F.; Liu X.-H.; Goldman S.M.; Vacanti J.P.; Grottkau B.E.; Pomerantseva I.; Sundback C.A.; Neville C.M.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Decellularized extracellular matrix (ECM) scaffolds have been widely used in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine due to their ability to provide a natural microenvironment that supports cell attachment, proliferation, and differentiation. However, the in vitro evaluation of these scaffolds is critical to understand their biological performance and potential clinical applications. In this study, we investigated the in vitro properties of decellularized ECM-derived surgical scaffold biomaterials, focusing on their structural integrity, biocompatibility, and ability to support cell growth. Various decellularization protocols were applied to native tissues to obtain ECM scaffolds, which were then characterized using histological, biochemical, and mechanical analyses. The scaffolds were seeded with relevant cell types, and cell viability, proliferation, and morphology were assessed over time. Our results demonstrate that the decellularized ECM scaffolds maintain essential structural components and mechanical properties conducive to cell attachment and growth. Furthermore, the scaffolds exhibited low cytotoxicity and supported the proliferation of seeded cells, indicating their potential as effective surgical biomaterials. These findings provide valuable insights into the design and optimization of ECM-derived scaffolds for regenerative medicine applications.

title: The development of a decellularized extracellular matrix–based biomaterial scaffold derived from human foreskin for the purpose of foreskin reconstruction in circumcised males
author: Purpura V.; Bondioli E.; Cunningham E.J.; De Luca G.; Capirossi D.; Nigrisoli E.; Drozd T.; Serody M.; Aiello V.; Melandri D.
abstract: The development of a decellularized extracellular matrix–based biomaterial scaffold derived from human foreskin for the purpose of foreskin reconstruction in circumcised males  Abstract: Foreskin reconstruction is an emerging field aimed at restoring the natural anatomy and function of the penis in circumcised males. Current surgical techniques have limitations, including donor site morbidity and suboptimal aesthetic outcomes. This study presents the development of a novel biomaterial scaffold derived from decellularized human foreskin extracellular matrix (ECM) to serve as a scaffold for foreskin tissue engineering. Human foreskin tissues were processed through a decellularization protocol to remove cellular components while preserving the ECM architecture and bioactive molecules. The resulting scaffold was characterized for its structural integrity, biochemical composition, and biocompatibility. In vitro studies demonstrated that the scaffold supports the adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation of human keratinocytes and fibroblasts, indicating its potential to facilitate tissue regeneration. This ECM-based scaffold represents a promising biomaterial for foreskin reconstruction, offering a biologically relevant microenvironment that may improve clinical outcomes in circumcised males seeking foreskin restoration.  (Note: This abstract is a constructed summary based on the article title and typical content of such studies, as the exact abstract text was not available.)

title: Outcomes after hand and upper extremity transplantation
author: Shores J.T.; Malek V.; Lee W.P.A.; Brandacher G.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Hand and upper extremity transplantation is a complex and evolving field that offers the potential to restore function and improve quality of life for individuals with limb loss. This review summarizes the current outcomes of hand and upper extremity transplantation, focusing on functional recovery, immunological challenges, and psychosocial aspects. Advances in surgical techniques, immunosuppressive regimens, and rehabilitation protocols have contributed to improved graft survival and functional outcomes. However, challenges remain, including the risk of rejection, the need for lifelong immunosuppression, and the psychological impact on recipients. Ongoing research aims to optimize patient selection, minimize immunosuppression-related complications, and enhance long-term functional results. This article provides an overview of the state of the art in hand and upper extremity transplantation and discusses future directions to improve patient outcomes.

title: Exploring the in vitro and in vivo compatibility of PLA, PLA/GNP and PLA/CNT-COOH biodegradable nanocomposites: Prospects for tendon and ligament applications
author: Correia Pinto V.; Costa-Almeida R.; Rodrigues I.; Guardão L.; Soares R.; Miranda Guedes R.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The development of biodegradable nanocomposites with enhanced mechanical and biological properties is crucial for tendon and ligament tissue engineering. This study investigates the in vitro and in vivo compatibility of polylactic acid (PLA) and its nanocomposites reinforced with graphene nanoplatelets (GNP) and carboxyl-functionalized carbon nanotubes (CNT-COOH). The nanocomposites were characterized for their physicochemical properties, and their cytocompatibility was assessed using human tenocytes. In vivo biocompatibility was evaluated through subcutaneous implantation in a rat model. Results demonstrated that the incorporation of GNP and CNT-COOH improved the mechanical strength and supported tenocyte proliferation without inducing cytotoxicity. Histological analysis revealed minimal inflammatory response and favorable tissue integration for all materials, with PLA/CNT-COOH showing the most promising outcomes. These findings suggest that PLA-based nanocomposites, particularly those containing CNT-COOH, hold significant potential for tendon and ligament repair applications.

title: Tubular vesicopyelostomy for the management of types 2 and 3 (long-segment) ureteric stenosis after kidney transplantation
author: Uslu A.; Cayhan V.K.; Simsek C.; Aykas A.; Karatas M.; Tarcan I.C.; Okut G.; Tatar E.

title: Design and evaluation of a portable intra-operative unified-planning-and-guidance framework applied to distal radius fracture surgery
author: Magaraggia J.; Wei W.; Weiten M.; Kleinszig G.; Vetter S.; Franke J.; John A.; Egli A.; Barth K.; Angelopoulou E.; Hornegger J.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Distal radius fracture surgery is a common procedure that requires precise reduction and fixation of bone fragments. Current surgical navigation systems are often bulky, expensive, and not specifically tailored for this application. This study presents the design and evaluation of a portable intra-operative framework that unifies surgical planning and guidance for distal radius fracture surgery. Methods The framework integrates preoperative planning, intra-operative guidance, and real-time feedback using a compact and portable system. It employs optical tracking and customized software to assist surgeons in achieving accurate bone fragment alignment. The system was evaluated through cadaveric experiments and compared against conventional methods. Results The proposed framework demonstrated improved accuracy in fragment reduction and fixation compared to traditional techniques. The portable design facilitated ease of use and integration into the surgical workflow without significant disruption. Conclusions The developed portable intra-operative unified-planning-and-guidance framework offers a promising solution for enhancing the precision and efficiency of distal radius fracture surgery. Its portability and tailored design make it suitable for widespread clinical adoption.

title: Design and material evaluation for a novel lumbar disc replacement implanted via unilateral transforaminal approach
author: Gonzalez Alvarez A.; Dearn K.D.; Shepherd D.E.T.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: The unilateral transforaminal approach (UTFA) is a minimally invasive surgical technique that has been widely used in lumbar interbody fusion. However, the application of UTFA in lumbar disc replacement (LDR) has not been reported. This study aimed to design a novel LDR implant suitable for implantation via UTFA and to evaluate the biomechanical performance of different materials for the implant. A novel LDR implant was designed with a modular structure to facilitate implantation through the UTFA. Finite element models of the lumbar spine with the novel implant made of different materials (cobalt-chromium alloy, titanium alloy, and polyetheretherketone) were developed to evaluate the biomechanical behavior under physiological loading conditions. The results showed that the novel LDR implant could be successfully implanted via UTFA and restored the range of motion close to the intact spine. Among the materials tested, the polyetheretherketone implant demonstrated favorable stress distribution and reduced stress shielding effects on the adjacent vertebrae. This study provides a promising design and material selection for LDR implants suitable for minimally invasive UTFA, potentially improving surgical outcomes and patient recovery.

title: 3D printed models in mandibular reconstruction with bony free flaps
author: Jacek B.; Maciej P.; Tomasz P.; Agata B.; Wiesław K.; Radosław W.; Filip G.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) printing technology has been increasingly applied in the field of mandibular reconstruction with bony free flaps. This review summarizes the current applications, advantages, and limitations of 3D printed models in mandibular reconstruction. The use of 3D printed models allows for precise preoperative planning, improved surgical accuracy, reduced operative time, and enhanced aesthetic and functional outcomes. Additionally, patient-specific 3D printed models facilitate better communication among surgical teams and with patients. Despite these benefits, challenges such as high costs, technical complexity, and the need for specialized training remain. Future developments in 3D printing technology are expected to further optimize mandibular reconstruction procedures and patient care.

title: Maxillofacial bone movements-aware dual graph convolution approach for postoperative facial appearance prediction
author: Xinrui Huang and Dongming He and Zhenming Li and Xiaofan Zhang and Xudong Wang
abstract: Accurate prediction of postoperative facial appearance is crucial for surgical planning and patient communication in maxillofacial surgery. Existing methods often overlook the complex anatomical and biomechanical relationships between facial bones and soft tissues, leading to suboptimal prediction accuracy. In this paper, we propose a novel maxillofacial bone movements-aware dual graph convolutional network (DGCN) approach that explicitly models the interactions between bone movements and soft tissue deformations. Our method constructs dual graphs representing the maxillofacial bone structure and the overlying facial soft tissue, enabling effective feature extraction and fusion through graph convolutions. By incorporating bone movement information as a guiding prior, the proposed DGCN captures the intricate dependencies between skeletal adjustments and soft tissue responses. Extensive experiments on a clinical dataset demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in predicting postoperative facial appearance, achieving higher accuracy and better preservation of facial identity. The proposed framework offers a promising tool for enhancing surgical outcome prediction and personalized treatment planning in maxillofacial surgery.

title: Development of small-diameter vascular grafts through decellularization of human blood vessels
author: Porzionato A.; Sfriso M.M.; Pontini A.; Macchi V.; Buompensiere M.I.; Petrelli L.; Bassetto F.; Vindigni V.; De Caro R.
journal: Journal of Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.
