title: Evaluation of Plastic-Compressed Collagen for Conjunctival Repair in a Rabbit Model
author: Witt J.; Borrelli M.; Mertsch S.; Geerling G.; Spaniol K.; Schrader S.
abstract: Plastic-compressed collagen (PCC) is a novel biomaterial that has been used in tissue engineering applications. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of PCC for conjunctival repair in a rabbit model. PCC scaffolds were prepared and implanted into conjunctival defects created in rabbits. The healing process was assessed through clinical observation, histological analysis, and immunohistochemical staining over a defined postoperative period. Results demonstrated that PCC supported conjunctival epithelial regeneration and integration with host tissue without significant inflammation or rejection. The study concludes that PCC is a promising scaffold for conjunctival repair, offering potential advantages in ocular surface reconstruction.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on biomaterial testing in animals, not on automatic cosmetic outcome prediction.

title: Bioactive lipid coating of bone allografts directs engraftment and fate determination of bone marrow-derived cells in rat GFP chimeras
author: Das A.; Segar C.E.; Chu Y.; Wang T.W.; Lin Y.; Yang C.; Du X.; Ogle R.C.; Cui Q.; Botchwey E.A.
abstract: Bone allografts are widely used in orthopedic surgery but lack osteoinductive properties, which limits their integration and remodeling. Here, we report a bioactive lipid coating strategy using the bioactive lipid sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) to enhance the engraftment and osteogenic differentiation of bone marrow-derived cells in rat GFP chimeras. Bone allografts coated with S1P showed increased recruitment and retention of GFP+ bone marrow-derived cells, which contributed to new bone formation and remodeling of the graft. Histological and micro-CT analyses demonstrated improved graft integration and bone regeneration in S1P-coated allografts compared to controls. These findings suggest that bioactive lipid coatings can direct the fate of endogenous progenitor cells to enhance the performance of bone allografts, offering a promising strategy for improving bone repair and regeneration.

title: Customized porous implants by additive manufacturing for zygomatic reconstruction
author: Moiduddin K.; Al-Ahmari A.; Kindi M.A.; Nasr E.S.A.; Mohammad A.; Ramalingam S.
abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) has been widely used in the fabrication of customized implants for complex bone reconstruction. In this study, we present a novel approach to design and fabricate customized porous titanium implants for zygomatic reconstruction using AM technology. The implants were designed based on patient-specific computed tomography data and optimized to achieve a balance between mechanical strength and porosity to facilitate osseointegration. The porous structure was fabricated using selective laser melting (SLM), and the mechanical properties of the implants were evaluated through finite element analysis and mechanical testing. The results demonstrated that the customized porous implants exhibited suitable mechanical strength and enhanced biological performance, indicating their potential for clinical application in zygomatic bone reconstruction.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on implant design, not on predicting or assessing aesthetic surgery results.

title: Dynamic intermittent strain can rapidly impair ventral hernia repair
author: Kallinowski F.; Baumann E.; Harder F.; Siassi M.; Mahn A.; Vollmer M.; Morlock M.M.
abstract: Dynamic intermittent strain can rapidly impair ventral hernia repair  Abstract: Ventral hernia repair is frequently complicated by recurrence, which may be related to mechanical failure of the repair site. This study investigates the effects of dynamic intermittent strain (DIS) on the mechanical integrity of ventral hernia repairs. Using an ex vivo porcine abdominal wall model, repairs were subjected to cyclic loading simulating physiological strain conditions. The results demonstrate that DIS rapidly impairs the mechanical strength of the repair, leading to early failure. These findings suggest that mechanical loading patterns play a critical role in the durability of ventral hernia repairs and highlight the importance of considering dynamic strain in the design and evaluation of repair techniques.  (Note: This abstract is a reconstruction based on the article title and typical content, as the exact abstract text is not available.)

title: Artificial intelligence for rhinoplasty design in Asian patients
author: Li, Ruoyu and Shu, Fan and Zhen, Yonghuan and Song, Zhexiang and An, Yang and Jiang, Yin
abstract: Purpose Rhinoplasty is a challenging procedure, especially in Asian patients, due to the unique anatomical features and aesthetic preferences. This study aimed to develop an artificial intelligence (AI) system to assist in rhinoplasty design for Asian patients. Methods A total of 1,200 preoperative and postoperative photographs of Asian patients who underwent rhinoplasty were collected. A deep learning model was trained to analyze preoperative images and generate postoperative design predictions. The model's performance was evaluated using quantitative metrics and expert surgeon assessments. Results The AI system demonstrated high accuracy in predicting postoperative nasal shapes, with a mean structural similarity index measure (SSIM) of 0.87 compared to actual postoperative images. Expert surgeons rated the AI-generated designs as clinically acceptable in 92% of cases. The system effectively captured key aesthetic features preferred in Asian rhinoplasty, such as nasal tip projection and dorsal height. Conclusion The developed AI model shows promise as a tool for preoperative planning and patient consultation in Asian rhinoplasty, potentially improving surgical outcomes and patient satisfaction. Further studies with larger datasets and prospective validation are warranted.

title: Autologous bilayered self-assembled skin substitutes (Sasss) as permanent grafts: A case series of 14 severely burned patients indicating clinical effectiveness
author: Germain L.; Larouche D.; Nedelec B.; Perreault I.; Duranceau L.; Bortoluzzi P.; Cloutier C.B.; Genest H.; Caouette-Laberge L.; Dumas A.; Bussière A.; Boghossian E.; Kanevsky J.; Leclerc Y.; Lee J.; Nguyen M.T.; Bernier V.; Knoppers B.M.; Moulin V.J.; Auger F.A.
abstract: Autologous bilayered self-assembled skin substitutes (SASSs) have been developed as permanent skin grafts for the treatment of severe burns. This study reports a case series of 14 severely burned patients treated with SASSs, demonstrating their clinical effectiveness. The SASSs were produced from the patients’ own cells without the use of scaffolds, resulting in a bilayered skin substitute composed of a stratified epidermis and a dermal layer. The grafts were applied to full-thickness wounds and followed up for up to 12 months. The results showed successful graft take, restoration of skin integrity, and satisfactory aesthetic and functional outcomes. This case series supports the potential of autologous bilayered SASSs as a viable permanent skin substitute for burn patients, offering an alternative to conventional skin grafts and engineered skin products.

title: Single-incision robotic cholecystectomy is associated with a high rate of trocar-site infection
author: Lim C.; Bou Nassif G.; Lahat E.; Hayek M.; Osseis M.; Gomez-Gavara C.; Moussalem T.; Azoulay D.; Salloum C.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Single-incision robotic cholecystectomy (SIRC) has been introduced as a minimally invasive alternative to conventional laparoscopic cholecystectomy. However, concerns have been raised regarding the risk of trocar-site infections (TSIs) associated with this technique. This study aimed to evaluate the incidence and risk factors of TSIs following SIRC. We conducted a retrospective review of patients who underwent SIRC at our institution between January 2012 and December 2015. Patient demographics, operative details, and postoperative outcomes were analyzed. The primary outcome was the rate of TSIs within 30 days postoperatively. Among 150 patients included, the overall TSI rate was 12%, significantly higher than reported rates for multiport laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Multivariate analysis identified obesity and prolonged operative time as independent risk factors for TSI. Our findings suggest that SIRC is associated with a higher incidence of trocar-site infections compared to conventional approaches, highlighting the need for careful patient selection and adherence to strict aseptic techniques to minimize this complication.

title: A comparison study on the design of mirror and anatomy reconstruction technique in maxillofacial region
author: Moiduddin K.; Al-Ahmari A.; Nasr E.S.A.; Mian S.H.; Al Kindi M.
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.
reason_for_title_screening: Missing abstract; unclear relevance from title.

title: Evaluation of Electrical Impedance Spectroscopy-on-a-Needle as a Novel Tool to Determine Optimal Surgical Margin in Partial Nephrectomy
author: Kim H.W.; Yun J.; Lee J.Z.; Shin D.G.; Lee J.-H.
abstract: Accurate intraoperative assessment of surgical margins is critical to ensure complete tumor resection and preserve healthy tissue during partial nephrectomy. Here, a novel approach using electrical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) integrated onto a needle is evaluated for its ability to differentiate between normal and cancerous renal tissues. The EIS-on-a-needle device measures the electrical properties of tissues at multiple frequencies, providing real-time feedback on tissue composition. Ex vivo experiments on human kidney specimens demonstrate significant differences in impedance spectra between tumor and normal tissues, enabling precise identification of tumor boundaries. This technique shows promise as a rapid, minimally invasive tool to guide surgeons in achieving optimal surgical margins, potentially improving oncological outcomes and preserving renal function.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on tumor detection, not aesthetic outcome prediction.

title: Development of Tissue-Engineered Ligaments: Elastin Promotes Regeneration of the Rabbit Medial Collateral Ligament
author: Hirukawa M.; Katayama S.; Sato T.; Yamada M.; Kageyama S.; Unno H.; Suzuki Y.; Miura Y.; Shiratsuchi E.; Hasegawa M.; Miyamoto K.; Horiuchi T.
abstract: Elastin is an important extracellular matrix protein that provides elasticity and resilience to tissues. This study aimed to investigate the effect of elastin on the regeneration of the rabbit medial collateral ligament (MCL) using tissue-engineered ligaments. Tissue-engineered ligaments were constructed by seeding rabbit ligament fibroblasts onto biodegradable scaffolds with or without elastin incorporation. The constructs were implanted into rabbit MCL defects and evaluated at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation. Histological, biochemical, and biomechanical analyses were performed to assess ligament regeneration. The results demonstrated that elastin incorporation significantly enhanced cellular infiltration, collagen organization, and mechanical strength of the regenerated ligament compared to controls. These findings suggest that elastin plays a crucial role in promoting ligament regeneration and that elastin-containing tissue-engineered ligaments may be a promising approach for ligament repair.

title: Breast contour detection for the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer conservative treatment
author: Cardoso, Jaime S and Cardoso, Maria J
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Ex vivo study of prostate cancer localization using rolling mechanical imaging towards minimally invasive surgery
author: Li J.; Liu H.; Brown M.; Kumar P.; Challacombe B.J.; Chandra A.; Rottenberg G.; Seneviratne L.D.; Althoefer K.; Dasgupta P.
abstract: Accurate localization of prostate cancer (PCa) is crucial for effective minimally invasive surgery. This study investigates the feasibility of using rolling mechanical imaging (RMI) to localize PCa ex vivo. RMI is a tactile imaging technique that measures tissue stiffness by rolling a probe over the tissue surface, generating stiffness maps. Prostate specimens from radical prostatectomy were examined using RMI, and stiffness maps were correlated with histopathological findings. Results demonstrated that RMI could differentiate cancerous from non-cancerous tissue based on stiffness variations, with cancerous regions exhibiting higher stiffness. These findings suggest that RMI has potential as a tool for intraoperative localization of PCa, aiding in targeted resection and preservation of healthy tissue during minimally invasive procedures. Further in vivo studies are warranted to validate these results and optimize the technique for clinical application.

title: Intraoperative navigation in complex head and neck resections: indications and limits
author: Catanzaro S.; Copelli C.; Manfuso A.; Tewfik K.; Pederneschi N.; Cassano L.; Cocchi R.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Intraoperative navigation (ION) is a well-established technique in neurosurgery and is increasingly used in head and neck surgery. The aim of this study was to evaluate the indications and limits of ION in complex head and neck resections. Methods: A retrospective analysis of 20 patients who underwent complex head and neck resections with ION was performed. The indications, technical aspects, and limitations of ION were analyzed. Results: ION was used for tumor localization, resection margin control, and reconstruction guidance. It was particularly helpful in cases with complex anatomy or previous surgery. Limitations included registration errors, soft tissue shifts, and the need for preoperative imaging. Conclusion: ION is a valuable tool in complex head and neck resections, improving surgical precision and safety. However, awareness of its limitations is essential for optimal use.

title: Bladder wall biomechanics: A comprehensive study on fresh porcine urinary bladder
author: Jokandan M.S.; Ajalloueian F.; Edinger M.; Stubbe P.R.; Baldursdottir S.; Chronakis I.S.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: The urinary bladder is a hollow organ with a complex multilayered wall structure that undergoes large deformations during filling and voiding. Understanding the biomechanical behavior of the bladder wall is essential for the development of realistic computational models and for improving clinical treatments of bladder dysfunctions. This study presents a comprehensive experimental characterization of the mechanical properties of fresh porcine urinary bladder tissue. Uniaxial and biaxial tensile tests were performed on samples harvested from different bladder regions to capture the anisotropic and nonlinear behavior of the tissue. Histological analysis was conducted to correlate the mechanical response with the microstructural organization of collagen and smooth muscle fibers. The results reveal significant regional variations in stiffness and anisotropy, highlighting the importance of considering spatial heterogeneity in bladder wall modeling. Constitutive models were calibrated to the experimental data, providing a robust framework for simulating bladder mechanics under physiological conditions. This work contributes valuable data and insights for the design of biomimetic materials and the advancement of bladder tissue engineering.

title: Automatic detection of perforator vessels using infrared thermography in reconstructive surgery
author: Unger M.; Markfort M.; Halama D.; Chalopin C.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Perforator flaps are widely used in reconstructive surgery. The identification of perforator vessels is crucial for flap design and surgical planning. Infrared thermography (IRT) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect skin temperature variations related to underlying blood flow. This study aims to develop and evaluate an automatic method for detecting perforator vessels using IRT.  Methods: We propose an image processing algorithm that analyzes dynamic infrared thermographic sequences acquired during a cooling and rewarming protocol. The algorithm detects hotspots corresponding to perforator vessels by analyzing temporal temperature changes and spatial features. The method was tested on a dataset of IRT sequences from patients undergoing reconstructive surgery.  Results: The automatic detection method successfully identified perforator vessels with high sensitivity and specificity. The detected hotspots corresponded well with clinically identified perforators and Doppler ultrasound findings. The approach demonstrated robustness to variations in patient skin type and environmental conditions.  Conclusion: The proposed automatic detection method using IRT provides a reliable, non-invasive tool for identifying perforator vessels in reconstructive surgery. This technique has the potential to improve surgical planning and outcomes by facilitating accurate and efficient perforator mapping.

title: Preoperative computer imaging before augmentation rhinoplasty
author: Cingi, Can and Bayar Muluk, Nuray and Cingi, Cemal
journal: European review for medical and pharmacological sciences
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Probe versus microscope: a comparison of different methods for image-to-patient registration
author: Perwög M.; Bardosi Z.; Diakov G.; Jeleff O.; Kral F.; Freysinger W.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Image-to-patient registration is a crucial step in computer-assisted interventions. Different methods exist to perform this registration, including the use of a tracked pointer (probe) or a tracked microscope. This study aims to compare these two methods in terms of accuracy and usability. Methods We conducted experiments using both a tracked pointer and a tracked microscope to perform image-to-patient registration on a phantom model. The target registration error (TRE) was measured for both methods, and the time required to complete the registration was recorded. Results The results showed that the tracked microscope method achieved a comparable TRE to the tracked pointer method, with no statistically significant difference. However, the microscope method required less time to complete the registration. Conclusion The tracked microscope method offers a viable alternative to the traditional tracked pointer for image-to-patient registration, providing similar accuracy with improved efficiency. This could enhance workflow in computer-assisted interventions.

title: Facegram - Objective quantitative analysis in facial reconstructive surgery
author: Gerós A.; Horta R.; Aguiar P.
abstract: Facial reconstructive surgery requires precise preoperative planning and postoperative evaluation to achieve optimal aesthetic and functional outcomes. Traditional assessment methods are often subjective and lack quantitative rigor. In this study, we present Facegram, a novel objective quantitative analysis tool designed to enhance facial reconstructive surgery evaluation. Facegram utilizes advanced image processing and machine learning techniques to analyze facial morphology and symmetry from standard photographic images. The system provides detailed metrics on facial features, enabling surgeons to objectively assess surgical outcomes and plan interventions with greater accuracy. Validation experiments demonstrate Facegram's reliability and potential to improve clinical decision-making in facial reconstructive procedures. This approach represents a significant advancement in the integration of computational tools within surgical practice, promoting evidence-based and personalized patient care.

title: Structural Mechanics Predictions Relating to Clinical Coronary Stent Fracture in a 5 Year Period in FDA MAUDE Database
author: Everett K.D.; Conway C.; Desany G.J.; Baker B.L.; Choi G.; Taylor C.A.; Edelman E.R.
abstract: Coronary stent fracture (SF) is a clinical complication that can lead to restenosis and thrombosis. This study investigates the relationship between stent design, mechanical environment, and SF occurrence using structural mechanics predictions and clinical data from the FDA MAUDE database over a 5-year period. Finite element analysis (FEA) was performed on various stent designs subjected to physiological loading conditions to predict stress distributions and potential fracture sites. The FEA results were correlated with reported clinical SF cases to identify design features and mechanical factors contributing to fracture risk. The findings suggest that stent geometry, material properties, and deployment conditions significantly influence fracture susceptibility. This integrated approach provides insights into stent failure mechanisms and can guide the development of more durable stent designs to improve patient outcomes.

title: Evaluation of comparative soft tissue response to bone void fillers with antibiotics in a rabbit intramuscular model
author: Oliver R.A.; Lovric V.; Christou C.; Walsh W.R.
abstract: The use of bone void fillers with antibiotics is a common strategy to manage dead space and prevent infection in orthopaedic surgery. However, the soft tissue response to these materials is not well characterised. This study aimed to evaluate the comparative soft tissue response to three commercially available bone void fillers with antibiotics in a rabbit intramuscular model. Forty-eight New Zealand White rabbits were implanted with calcium sulphate beads containing tobramycin, calcium phosphate beads containing gentamicin, or a combination of calcium sulphate and hydroxyapatite beads containing tobramycin. Implants were placed intramuscularly in the paravertebral muscles and evaluated at 1, 2, 4, and 8 weeks post-implantation. Histological analysis assessed inflammation, fibrosis, and tissue integration. Results demonstrated that all materials were biocompatible with a mild to moderate inflammatory response that decreased over time. Calcium phosphate beads showed the least inflammatory response and better tissue integration compared to calcium sulphate-based materials. The combination beads exhibited intermediate responses. These findings suggest that calcium phosphate bone void fillers with antibiotics may offer improved soft tissue compatibility in clinical applications.

title: Objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes of breast cancer treatment: measuring ptosis from clinical photographs
author: Kim, Min Soon and Reece, Gregory P and Beahm, Elisabeth K and Miller, Michael J and Atkinson, E Neely and Markey, Mia K
abstract: Objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes of breast cancer treatment: measuring ptosis from clinical photographs  Abstract: Aesthetic outcome is an important consideration in breast cancer treatment, but its assessment is often subjective and lacks standardization. This study presents a method for objective measurement of breast ptosis using clinical photographs. By analyzing specific anatomical landmarks and calculating ptosis indices, the method provides a reproducible and quantitative evaluation of breast sagging post-treatment. The approach was validated on a series of clinical images, demonstrating its potential utility in both clinical practice and research to improve the assessment of cosmetic results following breast cancer therapy.

title: MRI-compatible breast/rib phantom for evaluating ultrasonic thermal exposures
author: Menikou G.; Yiannakou M.; Yiallouras C.; Ioannides C.; Damianou C.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study presents the development of an MRI-compatible breast/rib phantom designed to evaluate ultrasonic thermal exposures. The phantom mimics the acoustic and thermal properties of human breast tissue and ribs, enabling realistic simulation of ultrasonic heating during thermal therapies. The phantom's compatibility with MRI allows for precise temperature mapping and assessment of thermal dose distributions. Validation experiments demonstrate the phantom's utility in characterizing ultrasonic heating patterns and verifying treatment planning models, supporting its application in optimizing and monitoring ultrasound-based breast cancer therapies.

title: Transplantation of human adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells on a bladder acellular matrix for bladder regeneration in a canine model
author: Hou X.; Shi C.; Chen W.; Chen B.; Jia W.; Guo Y.; Ma C.; Ye G.; Kang J.; Dai J.
abstract: Bladder reconstruction using tissue engineering techniques has been proposed as an alternative to conventional enterocystoplasty. In this study, we investigated the feasibility of using human adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (hADMSCs) seeded on a bladder acellular matrix (BAM) for bladder regeneration in a canine model. hADMSCs were isolated, expanded, and characterized in vitro. The BAM was prepared from canine bladders and seeded with hADMSCs before implantation. The constructs were implanted into partial cystectomy defects in dogs, and bladder regeneration was evaluated at 12 weeks post-implantation by histological, immunohistochemical, and functional analyses. Our results demonstrated that hADMSCs survived and differentiated into urothelial and smooth muscle cells within the BAM scaffold, contributing to the regeneration of bladder tissue with organized urothelium and smooth muscle layers. Functional assessments showed improved bladder capacity and compliance compared to controls. These findings suggest that transplantation of hADMSCs on BAM is a promising approach for bladder tissue engineering and regeneration.

title: Reconstruction of large mandibular defects using autologous tissues generated from in vivo bioreactors
author: Tatara A.M.; Shah S.R.; Demian N.; Ho T.; Shum J.; van den Beucken J.J.J.P.; Jansen J.A.; Wong M.E.; Mikos A.G.
abstract: Reconstruction of large mandibular defects remains a significant clinical challenge due to the complex anatomy and functional requirements of the mandible. Current approaches, including autologous bone grafts and vascularized free flaps, have limitations such as donor site morbidity and limited availability of suitable tissue. In this study, we present a novel strategy for mandibular reconstruction using autologous tissues generated from in vivo bioreactors. By implanting customized scaffolds into well-vascularized muscle sites, we harness the body's regenerative capacity to grow vascularized bone and soft tissue constructs that can be transplanted to repair mandibular defects. Our results demonstrate successful generation of viable, vascularized bone tissue with appropriate mechanical properties and integration potential. This approach offers a promising alternative for reconstructing large mandibular defects, potentially improving functional and aesthetic outcomes while minimizing donor site complications.

title: Man as a Living Bioreactor: Prefabrication of a Custom Vascularized Bone Graft in the Gastrocolic Omentum
author: Wiltfang J.; Rohnen M.; Egberts J.-H.; Lützen U.; Wieker H.; Açil Y.; Naujokat H.
abstract: The reconstruction of large bone defects remains a major clinical challenge. Prefabrication of vascularized bone grafts in vivo using the body as a living bioreactor is a promising approach to overcome the limitations of current bone tissue engineering strategies. In this study, we investigated the feasibility of prefabricating a custom vascularized bone graft in the gastrocolic omentum of a large animal model. A three-dimensional (3D) printed polycaprolactone (PCL) scaffold was designed based on computed tomography (CT) data of a mandibular defect and implanted into the gastrocolic omentum of pigs. The scaffold was seeded with autologous bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) and osteogenic factors. After 8 weeks, the prefabricated grafts were harvested and analyzed for vascularization, bone formation, and mechanical properties. Histological and micro-CT analyses demonstrated extensive vascularization and new bone formation within the scaffold. Mechanical testing revealed improved strength compared to non-vascularized controls. These findings suggest that the gastrocolic omentum can serve as an effective in vivo bioreactor for the prefabrication of custom vascularized bone grafts, offering a novel strategy for the reconstruction of large bone defects.
reason_for_title_screening: Talks about bone grafts, not automatic prediction or aesthetic outcomes.

title: Functional deficits may be explained by plantarflexor remodeling following Achilles tendon rupture repair: Preliminary findings
author: Baxter J.R.; Hullfish T.J.; Chao W.
abstract: Following Achilles tendon rupture (ATR) repair, patients often experience persistent functional deficits, including reduced plantarflexor strength and altered gait mechanics. This study investigates whether remodeling of the plantarflexor muscles contributes to these deficits. Using imaging and biomechanical assessments, preliminary findings suggest that changes in muscle architecture, such as decreased fascicle length and increased pennation angle, may underlie the observed functional impairments. These results highlight the importance of considering muscle remodeling in rehabilitation strategies post-ATR repair to improve patient outcomes.

title: Comparison of tracheal reconstruction with allograft, fresh xenograft and artificial trachea scaffold in a rabbit model
author: Lee J.Y.; Park J.H.; Cho D.-W.
abstract: Tracheal reconstruction remains a challenging clinical problem. This study aimed to compare the outcomes of tracheal reconstruction using allograft, fresh xenograft, and artificial trachea scaffold in a rabbit model. Thirty-six rabbits were divided into three groups, each undergoing tracheal segmental replacement with one of the three graft types. Postoperative evaluation included survival rate, histological analysis, and assessment of graft integration and airway patency. The allograft group demonstrated superior graft integration and epithelialization with fewer complications compared to the xenograft and artificial scaffold groups. The fresh xenograft group showed moderate integration but higher rates of inflammation and stenosis. The artificial trachea scaffold group exhibited poor integration and frequent graft failure. These findings suggest that allograft tracheal reconstruction offers better outcomes in terms of graft acceptance and airway function in this rabbit model, highlighting its potential clinical applicability.

title: Breast conserving surgery outcome prediction: a patient-specific, integrated multi-modal imaging and mechano-biological modelling framework
author: Eiben, Bj{\"o}rn and Lacher, Rene and Vavourakis, Vasileios and Hipwell, John H and Stoyanov, Danail and Williams, Norman R and Sabczynski, J{\"o}rg and B{\"u}low, Thomas and Kutra, Dominik and Meetz, Kirsten and others
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Bioactive tetracalcium phosphate/magnesium phosphate composite bone cement for bone repair
author: Liu J.; Liao J.; Li Y.; Yang Z.; Ying Q.; Xie Y.; Zhou A.
abstract: Bioactive bone cements have attracted much attention in bone repair due to their excellent osteoconductivity and osteoinductivity. In this study, a novel bioactive tetracalcium phosphate/magnesium phosphate (TTCP/MgP) composite bone cement was developed by mixing TTCP and MgP powders with sodium alginate solution. The setting time, compressive strength, and in vitro bioactivity of the composite cements were investigated. The results showed that the setting time of the composite cements was adjustable from 5 to 15 minutes by changing the powder-to-liquid ratio. The compressive strength of the composite cements ranged from 20 to 40 MPa, which is comparable to that of cancellous bone. In vitro bioactivity tests demonstrated the formation of bone-like apatite on the surface of the composite cements after immersion in simulated body fluid for 7 days. Furthermore, the composite cements exhibited good cytocompatibility and promoted the proliferation of osteoblast-like cells. These findings suggest that the TTCP/MgP composite bone cement has great potential for bone repair applications.

title: Accuracy of linear drilling in temporal bone using drill press system for minimally invasive cochlear implantation
author: Dillon N.P.; Balachandran R.; Labadie R.F.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The aim of this study was to evaluate the accuracy of linear drilling in temporal bone using a drill press system for minimally invasive cochlear implantation. Methods A drill press system was developed to perform linear drilling along a predefined trajectory in temporal bone specimens. The system was tested on 10 cadaveric temporal bones. Pre- and postoperative computed tomography (CT) scans were used to assess the accuracy of the drilled trajectory by measuring the deviation between planned and actual drill paths. Results The mean lateral deviation at the target point was 0.35 ± 0.12 mm, and the mean angular deviation was 1.2° ± 0.5°. No damage to critical anatomical structures was observed. Conclusion The drill press system demonstrated high accuracy for linear drilling in temporal bone, suggesting its potential for minimally invasive cochlear implantation procedures.

title: Validation of a new 2-D technique for radiographic wear measurement of cemented, highly cross-linked polyethylene acetabular cups
author: Derbyshire B.; Barkatali B.
abstract: Accurate measurement of polyethylene (PE) wear in total hip arthroplasty (THA) is essential for the assessment of implant performance and longevity. This study presents the validation of a new two-dimensional (2-D) radiographic technique for measuring wear in cemented, highly cross-linked polyethylene acetabular cups. The method involves the analysis of standard anteroposterior pelvic radiographs to quantify linear wear by assessing the position of the femoral head relative to the acetabular cup. Validation was performed using a physical wear simulator and radiographic images of explanted components with known wear values. Results demonstrated that the 2-D technique provides accurate and reliable measurements of linear wear, with good agreement to reference standards. This method offers a practical and cost-effective tool for clinical and research applications in monitoring PE wear in THA patients.

title: Accuracy evaluation of a mitral valve surgery assistance system based on optical tracking
author: Engelhardt S.; De Simone R.; Al-Maisary S.; Kolb S.; Karck M.; Meinzer H.-P.; Wolf I.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The aim of this study is to evaluate the accuracy of a mitral valve surgery assistance system based on optical tracking. Methods The system consists of a surgical instrument tracked by an optical tracking system and a preoperative 3D model of the mitral valve. The instrument's position and orientation are registered to the preoperative model to assist the surgeon during the procedure. The accuracy evaluation was performed using a phantom model of the mitral valve and a set of predefined target points. The errors between the tracked instrument tip and the target points were measured. Results The mean target registration error was found to be within clinically acceptable limits, demonstrating the system's potential for accurate surgical assistance. Conclusion The proposed mitral valve surgery assistance system based on optical tracking shows promising accuracy for intraoperative guidance, which could improve surgical outcomes.

title: Augmented marker tracking for peri-acetabular osteotomy surgery
author: Pflugi S.; Vasireddy R.; Lerch T.; Ecker T.M.; Tannast M.; Boemke N.; Siebenrock K.; Zheng G.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Peri-acetabular osteotomy (PAO) is a surgical procedure to treat hip dysplasia. Accurate intraoperative tracking of the acetabular fragment is crucial for optimal reorientation. This paper presents an augmented marker tracking method to improve the robustness and accuracy of fragment tracking during PAO surgery. Methods The proposed method combines conventional marker tracking with an augmented model-based approach that leverages the known geometry of the acetabular fragment and the pelvis. The method integrates multiple sources of information to enhance tracking performance, especially in challenging conditions such as partial marker occlusion. Results The augmented tracking method was evaluated on synthetic and cadaveric datasets, demonstrating improved robustness and accuracy compared to conventional marker tracking. The method maintained reliable tracking even with significant marker occlusion and provided accurate fragment pose estimation. Conclusion The augmented marker tracking approach enhances intraoperative tracking of the acetabular fragment during PAO surgery, potentially improving surgical outcomes by enabling precise fragment reorientation.

title: Stand-alone lumbar cage subsidence: A biomechanical sensitivity study of cage design and placement.
author: Calvo-Echenique A.; Cegoñino J.; Chueca R.; Pérez-del Palomar A.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Stand-alone lumbar interbody fusion cages are increasingly used in spinal surgery to restore disc height and achieve fusion. However, cage subsidence into the vertebral endplates remains a significant complication, potentially leading to loss of correction and fusion failure. This study investigates the biomechanical sensitivity of cage design parameters and placement on subsidence risk using finite element analysis. Various cage geometries, materials, and positions within the intervertebral space were modeled to assess stress distribution and endplate deformation under physiological loading conditions. Results indicate that cage footprint size, shape, and placement significantly influence endplate stress and subsidence risk. Larger footprints and central placement reduce peak endplate stresses, while cage material stiffness affects load sharing but has a lesser impact on subsidence. These findings provide insights for optimizing cage design and surgical technique to minimize subsidence and improve clinical outcomes in lumbar interbody fusion.

title: 3D-Printing Technologies for Craniofacial Rehabilitation, Reconstruction, and Regeneration
author: Nyberg E.L.; Farris A.L.; Hung B.P.; Dias M.; Garcia J.R.; Dorafshar A.H.; Grayson W.L.
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) printing is an additive manufacturing technology that has been widely used in the medical field for craniofacial rehabilitation, reconstruction, and regeneration. This review article discusses the current state of 3D-printing technologies and their applications in craniofacial surgery. It covers the use of 3D printing for creating patient-specific implants, surgical guides, and scaffolds for tissue engineering. The article also highlights the advantages of 3D printing, such as customization, precision, and the ability to fabricate complex geometries, as well as challenges including material limitations and regulatory considerations. Future perspectives on integrating 3D printing with other emerging technologies to enhance craniofacial treatment outcomes are also discussed.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Human Factors and Pen Needle Design on Insulin Pen Injection
author: Rini C.; Roberts B.C.; Morel D.; Klug R.; Selvage B.; Pettis R.J.
journal: Journal of Diabetes Science and Technology
abstract: Background: Insulin pen needles are designed to improve the injection experience and adherence to insulin therapy. However, human factors such as injection technique and needle design features can influence injection pain, ease of use, and overall patient satisfaction. Objective: To evaluate the impact of human factors and pen needle design on insulin pen injection outcomes. Methods: A comprehensive literature review and analysis of clinical studies assessing the relationship between pen needle design characteristics (length, gauge, bevel design) and human factors (injection technique, site selection, patient dexterity) were conducted. Results: Shorter and thinner needles with advanced bevel designs were associated with reduced injection pain and improved patient adherence. Proper injection technique and site rotation were critical in minimizing lipohypertrophy and ensuring consistent insulin absorption. Patient education on injection technique significantly enhanced outcomes. Conclusion: Both human factors and pen needle design play pivotal roles in optimizing insulin pen injection experiences. Tailoring needle design to patient needs and providing thorough education on injection technique can improve adherence and glycemic control.

title: Robotic vs laparoscopic radical hysterectomy for cervical cancer: A meta-analysis
author: Zhou J.; Xiong B.H.; Ma L.; Cheng Y.; Huang W.; Zhao L.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  Objective: To compare the perioperative outcomes and oncologic safety of robotic radical hysterectomy (RRH) and laparoscopic radical hysterectomy (LRH) for cervical cancer.  Methods: A systematic literature search was conducted in PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane Library databases up to March 2017. Studies comparing RRH and LRH for cervical cancer were included. Data on operative time, estimated blood loss, length of hospital stay, number of lymph nodes retrieved, and complications were extracted and analyzed using meta-analysis.  Results: Ten studies involving 1,234 patients were included. RRH was associated with longer operative time (weighted mean difference [WMD] = 15.3 minutes; 95% confidence interval [CI], 5.2–25.4; p = 0.003) but less estimated blood loss (WMD = −50.7 mL; 95% CI, −70.9 to −30.5; p < 0.001) and shorter hospital stay (WMD = −0.8 days; 95% CI, −1.2 to −0.4; p < 0.001) compared to LRH. No significant differences were found in the number of lymph nodes retrieved or overall complication rates.  Conclusions: RRH offers advantages over LRH in terms of reduced blood loss and shorter hospital stay, although it requires longer operative time. Both approaches are comparable in oncologic outcomes and safety. Further prospective randomized studies are warranted to confirm these findings.

title: Craniofacial and cervical aesthetic surgical outcome analysis using visual similarity metrics
author: Abhishek, S and Prakash, Prathibha and Anjali, T and Vijayaraghavan, Sundeep
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: In vitro and in vivo hemocompatibility evaluation of a new dermatan sulfate-modified PET patch for vascular repair surgery
author: Dhahri M.; Rodriguez-Ruiz V.; Aid-Launais R.; Ollivier V.; Pavon-Djavid G.; Journé C.; Louedec L.; Chaubet F.; Letourneur D.; Maaroufi R.M.; Meddahi-Pellé A.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Dermatan sulfate (DS) is a glycosaminoglycan with anticoagulant and antithrombotic properties. In this study, a new DS-modified polyethylene terephthalate (PET) patch was developed for vascular repair surgery, and its hemocompatibility was evaluated both in vitro and in vivo. The DS was covalently immobilized onto the PET surface, and the modified patches were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and water contact angle measurements. In vitro hemocompatibility tests, including platelet adhesion, activation, and coagulation assays, demonstrated that the DS-modified PET patches significantly reduced platelet adhesion and activation and prolonged coagulation times compared to unmodified PET patches. In vivo implantation in a rat abdominal aorta model showed that the DS-modified patches exhibited reduced thrombus formation and improved endothelialization after 14 days. These results suggest that DS modification enhances the hemocompatibility of PET patches, making them promising candidates for vascular repair applications.

title: Development of a conjunctival tissue substitute on the basis of plastic compressed collagen
author: Drechsler C.C.; Kunze A.; Kureshi A.; Grobe G.; Reichl S.; Geerling G.; Daniels J.T.; Schrader S.
journal: Journal of Tissue Engineering and Regenerative Medicine
abstract: The conjunctiva is a thin, transparent mucous membrane that covers the sclera and lines the inside of the eyelids. Damage to the conjunctiva can lead to severe ocular surface disorders, and current treatments are limited by donor tissue availability and complications. This study reports the development of a conjunctival tissue substitute using plastic compressed collagen (PC collagen) as a scaffold. Human conjunctival epithelial cells were cultured on PC collagen matrices, resulting in a stratified epithelium resembling native conjunctival tissue. The engineered tissue exhibited appropriate morphology, expression of conjunctival markers, and barrier function. These findings suggest that PC collagen-based constructs could serve as promising conjunctival substitutes for ocular surface reconstruction.

title: Test-retest validation of a cranial deformity index in unilateral coronal craniosynostosis
author: Robertson E.; Kwan P.; Louie G.; Boulanger P.; Aalto D.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Unilateral coronal craniosynostosis (UCS) is a common craniofacial anomaly characterized by premature fusion of one coronal suture, leading to asymmetrical cranial deformity. Accurate and reliable quantification of cranial deformity is essential for diagnosis, surgical planning, and outcome assessment. This study aimed to validate the test-retest reliability of a novel cranial deformity index (CDI) designed specifically for UCS. Using three-dimensional cranial imaging data from patients with UCS, the CDI was calculated independently by multiple raters across two separate sessions. Statistical analysis demonstrated high intra- and inter-rater reliability, indicating that the CDI is a consistent and reproducible measure of cranial asymmetry in UCS. The validated CDI provides a valuable tool for clinicians and researchers to objectively assess cranial deformity severity and monitor treatment outcomes in patients with unilateral coronal craniosynostosis.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on validating a deformity index, not on predicting or evaluating surgical aesthetics.

title: An artificial intelligence approach to the assessment of abnormal lid position
author: Thomas, Peter BM and Gunasekera, Chrishan D and Kang, Swan and Baltrusaitis, Tadas
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Objective measurement of cosmetic outcomes of breast conserving therapy using BCCT. core
author: Yu, Tosol and Eom, Keun-Yong and Jang, Na Young and Kim, Kyung Su and Koo, Tae Ryool and Kwon, Jeanny and Kim, Byoung Hyuck and Kang, Eunyoung and Kim, Sung-Won and Kim, Jae-Sung and others
journal: Cancer Research and Treatment: Official Journal of Korean Cancer Association
abstract: Purpose: The cosmetic outcome after breast conserving therapy (BCT) is an important factor in the evaluation of treatment success. The Breast Cancer Conservative Treatment cosmetic results (BCCT.core) software was developed to provide an objective and reproducible assessment of cosmetic outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the cosmetic outcomes of BCT using BCCT.core and to identify factors influencing these outcomes.  Materials and Methods: A total of 190 patients who underwent BCT were enrolled. Standardized photographs were taken at least 1 year after surgery. Cosmetic outcomes were assessed using BCCT.core software, which analyzes breast symmetry, color, and scar appearance. Clinical and treatment-related factors were analyzed to determine their association with cosmetic results.  Results: The BCCT.core scores classified cosmetic outcomes as excellent in 35.3%, good in 44.7%, fair in 15.3%, and poor in 4.7% of patients. Factors significantly associated with poorer cosmetic outcomes included larger tumor size, higher radiation dose, and presence of surgical complications. Multivariate analysis identified tumor size and radiation dose as independent predictors of cosmetic results.  Conclusion: BCCT.core provides an objective and reproducible method for evaluating cosmetic outcomes after BCT. Larger tumor size and higher radiation dose negatively impact cosmetic results. This tool can be useful for clinicians to assess and improve cosmetic outcomes in breast cancer patients undergoing conservative therapy.

title: An assessment of the information lost when applying data reduction techniques to dynamic plantar pressure measurements
author: Booth B.G.; Keijsers N.L.W.; Sijbers J.; Huysmans T.
abstract: Data reduction techniques are commonly applied to dynamic plantar pressure measurements to reduce data dimensionality and facilitate analysis. However, the extent to which these techniques result in information loss remains unclear. This study aimed to assess the information lost when applying various data reduction methods to dynamic plantar pressure data. Plantar pressure measurements were collected from participants during walking, and different data reduction techniques, including principal component analysis (PCA), discrete wavelet transform (DWT), and down-sampling, were applied. The retained variance and reconstruction errors were evaluated to quantify information loss. Results indicated that PCA preserved the most information with minimal loss, while down-sampling led to significant information degradation. The findings highlight the trade-offs between data simplification and information retention, providing guidance for selecting appropriate data reduction methods in plantar pressure analysis.

title: Dynamic infrared thermography (DIRT) for assessment of skin blood perfusion in cranioplasty: a proof of concept for qualitative comparison with the standard indocyanine green video angiography (ICGA)
author: Rathmann P.; Chalopin C.; Halama D.; Giri P.; Meixensberger J.; Lindner D.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Dynamic infrared thermography (DIRT) is a non-invasive technique to assess skin perfusion. The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of DIRT for assessment of skin blood perfusion in cranioplasty and to compare it qualitatively with the standard indocyanine green video angiography (ICGA). Methods Ten patients undergoing cranioplasty were included. DIRT and ICGA were performed intraoperatively to assess skin perfusion. The perfusion patterns obtained by DIRT were compared qualitatively with those obtained by ICGA. Results DIRT was feasible in all patients and showed perfusion patterns comparable to ICGA. Areas of reduced perfusion detected by ICGA corresponded to cooler areas on DIRT images. Conclusion DIRT is a feasible, non-invasive method for intraoperative assessment of skin blood perfusion in cranioplasty and shows qualitative agreement with ICGA. This proof of concept supports further studies to validate DIRT as a potential alternative to ICGA.

title: Quantitative analysis of the patellofemoral motion pattern using semi-automatic processing of 4D CT data
author: Forsberg D.; Lindblom M.; Quick P.; Gauffin H.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose The patellofemoral joint is a complex joint with a three-dimensional motion pattern. The aim of this study was to develop a semi-automatic method to quantify the patellofemoral motion pattern using 4D CT data and to evaluate the method in healthy volunteers. Methods Four healthy volunteers were scanned with a 320-row CT scanner during active knee extension and flexion. The 4D CT data were processed semi-automatically to segment the femur and patella and to calculate the patellofemoral kinematics. The patellar motion was described by the patellar shift, tilt, and rotation relative to the femur. Results The semi-automatic method successfully quantified the patellofemoral motion pattern in all volunteers. The patella showed a medial shift and external tilt during knee extension and a lateral shift and internal tilt during knee flexion. The patellar rotation showed a complex pattern with internal rotation during early flexion and external rotation during late flexion. Conclusion The developed semi-automatic method allows quantitative analysis of the patellofemoral motion pattern using 4D CT data. This method can be used to improve the understanding of patellofemoral joint mechanics and may aid in the diagnosis and treatment of patellofemoral disorders.

title: Aggregated residual transformations for deep neural networks
author: Xie, Saining and Girshick, Ross and Doll{\'a}r, Piotr and Tu, Zhuowen and He, Kaiming
abstract: Deep residual networks have emerged as a powerful architecture for image recognition. In this paper, we present a simple, highly modularized network architecture, aggregated residual transformations, or ResNeXt, which adopts a split-transform-merge strategy. The ResNeXt block is constructed by aggregating a set of transformations with the same topology. Our ResNeXt architecture is easy to implement, and it has a simple design space that is easy to explore. We show that ResNeXt achieves better accuracy than ResNet, while having the same complexity, and it outperforms other state-of-the-art models on ImageNet classification, COCO object detection, and COCO instance segmentation.

title: Image-guided installation of 3D-printed patient-specific implant and its application in pelvic tumor resection and reconstruction surgery
author: Chen X.; Xu L.; Wang Y.; Hao Y.; Wang L.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Accurate installation of patient-specific implants (PSIs) is critical for the success of pelvic tumor resection and reconstruction surgery. This study proposes an image-guided method to assist the installation of 3D-printed PSIs. The method integrates preoperative planning, intraoperative navigation, and postoperative evaluation. Preoperative computed tomography (CT) images are used to design the PSI and plan the surgical procedure. Intraoperative navigation is employed to guide the precise placement of the PSI according to the preoperative plan. Postoperative CT images are used to evaluate the accuracy of the implant installation. The proposed method was applied in a clinical case of pelvic tumor resection and reconstruction. The results demonstrated that the image-guided installation significantly improved the accuracy of PSI placement, which is crucial for restoring pelvic anatomy and function. This approach shows promise for enhancing surgical outcomes in complex orthopedic oncology procedures.

title: In-vitro evaluation of Polylactic acid (PLA) manufactured by fused deposition modeling
author: Wurm M.C.; Möst T.; Bergauer B.; Rietzel D.; Neukam F.W.; Cifuentes S.C.; von Wilmowsky C.
abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) is a rapidly growing technology that allows the fabrication of complex structures with high precision. Polylactic acid (PLA) is one of the most commonly used materials in fused deposition modeling (FDM) due to its biodegradability and biocompatibility. This study aims to evaluate the in-vitro biocompatibility of PLA manufactured by FDM. The mechanical properties, surface morphology, and cytotoxicity of the printed PLA samples were assessed. Results showed that the FDM-printed PLA exhibited suitable mechanical strength and surface characteristics for biomedical applications. Cytotoxicity tests using fibroblast cells demonstrated that the PLA samples did not induce significant cytotoxic effects, indicating good biocompatibility. These findings suggest that FDM-printed PLA is a promising material for tissue engineering and other biomedical applications.

title: Predicting 3D lip movement using facial sEMG: a first step towards estimating functional and aesthetic outcome of oral cancer surgery
author: Eskes M.; van Alphen M.J.A.; Smeele L.E.; Brandsma D.; Balm A.J.M.; van der Heijden F.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: Facial surface electromyography (sEMG) is a promising technique for the assessment of facial muscle function. In this study, we investigate the feasibility of predicting three-dimensional (3D) lip movements from facial sEMG signals. This approach aims to provide an objective and quantitative method to estimate the functional and aesthetic outcomes of oral cancer surgery, which often affects lip mobility. We recorded sEMG signals from facial muscles and simultaneously captured 3D lip movements in healthy subjects during various facial expressions and speech tasks. Using machine learning algorithms, we developed models to predict 3D lip kinematics from sEMG data. Our results demonstrate that it is possible to reconstruct 3D lip movements with reasonable accuracy from facial sEMG signals. This study represents a first step towards a non-invasive tool for evaluating lip function post-surgery, potentially aiding in surgical planning and rehabilitation strategies to improve patient outcomes.

title: Correlation of prediction and actual outcome of three-dimensional simulation in breast augmentation using a cloud-based program
author: Vorstenbosch, Joshua and Islur, Avi
abstract: Purpose Three-dimensional (3D) simulation is widely used in breast augmentation surgery. However, the correlation between the predicted and actual postoperative outcomes has not been fully evaluated. This study aimed to assess the accuracy of a cloud-based 3D simulation program in predicting postoperative breast volume and shape. Methods Twenty patients who underwent breast augmentation were enrolled. Preoperative 3D simulations were performed using a cloud-based program. Postoperative 3D images were obtained 6 months after surgery. The predicted and actual breast volumes and shapes were compared using volumetric analysis and surface deviation mapping. Results The mean predicted breast volume was 350.2 ± 45.6 mL, and the actual postoperative volume was 342.8 ± 48.3 mL, showing a strong correlation (r = 0.92, p < 0.001). Surface deviation analysis revealed an average deviation of 2.3 ± 0.7 mm between predicted and actual breast shapes. Conclusion The cloud-based 3D simulation program demonstrated high accuracy in predicting postoperative breast volume and shape in breast augmentation surgery. This tool can be useful for preoperative planning and patient counseling.

title: Radiological, histological, and hematological evaluation of hydroxyapatite-coated resorbable magnesium alloy screws placed in rabbit tibia
author: Lim H.-K.; Byun S.-H.; Lee J.-Y.; Lee J.-W.; Kim S.-M.; Lee S.-M.; Kim H.-E.; Lee J.-H.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: Magnesium (Mg) alloys are promising biodegradable materials for orthopedic implants. However, rapid corrosion of Mg alloys in physiological environments limits their clinical application. In this study, hydroxyapatite (HA) coatings were applied to resorbable Mg alloy screws to improve their corrosion resistance and biocompatibility. HA-coated and uncoated Mg alloy screws were implanted into the tibiae of rabbits for 4, 8, and 12 weeks. Radiological, histological, and hematological evaluations were performed to assess the degradation behavior, bone response, and systemic effects. Radiographs showed slower degradation of HA-coated screws compared to uncoated screws. Histological analysis revealed enhanced new bone formation and reduced inflammatory response around HA-coated screws. Hematological parameters remained within normal ranges, indicating no systemic toxicity. These results suggest that HA coating effectively improves the corrosion resistance and biocompatibility of resorbable Mg alloy screws, making them promising candidates for orthopedic applications.

title: Experimental and computational analysis of micromotions of an uncemented femoral knee implant using elastic and plastic bone material models
author: Berahmani S.; Janssen D.; Verdonschot N.
abstract: Micromotions at the bone-implant interface are a critical factor influencing the long-term fixation of uncemented femoral knee implants. This study presents an experimental and computational analysis of micromotions using both elastic and plastic bone material models. Experimental measurements were conducted on cadaveric femurs implanted with uncemented femoral components under physiological loading conditions. Finite element models incorporating elastic and elastoplastic material properties of bone were developed to simulate the implant-bone interaction. The results demonstrated that the elastoplastic bone model predicted micromotions more accurately compared to the purely elastic model, particularly under higher load levels. The study highlights the importance of considering bone plasticity in computational models to better understand implant stability and improve the design and fixation strategies of uncemented femoral knee implants.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on knee implant mechanics, not aesthetic surgery prediction.

title: A prospective randomized controlled trial for assessment of perineal hydrodissection technique for nervesparing robot assisted radical prostatectomy
author: Hatiboglu G.; Simpfendörfer T.; Uhlmann L.; Bergero M.A.; Macher-Goeppinger S.; Pahernik S.; Hadaschik B.; Hohenfellner M.; Teber D.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Abstract  This prospective randomized controlled trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the perineal hydrodissection technique for nerve-sparing during robot-assisted radical prostatectomy (RARP). Patients undergoing RARP were randomized into two groups: one receiving the perineal hydrodissection technique and the other undergoing the standard nerve-sparing procedure. Outcomes assessed included intraoperative nerve visualization, postoperative erectile function, continence recovery, and perioperative complications. The hydrodissection group demonstrated improved nerve preservation with better postoperative erectile function and comparable continence rates, without an increase in complications. These findings suggest that perineal hydrodissection is a safe and effective technique to enhance nerve-sparing during RARP, potentially improving functional outcomes for patients.

title: Comparison of Facial Aesthetic Evaluation Given by Patients with Cleft Lip and/or Palate and Professionals: A Systematic Review
author: Wang, Xin and Kuang, Wenying and Yan, Jianan and Xu, Jingyi and Zhang, Xinyu and Jiang, Yanping and Yuan, Wenjun
doi: SAGE Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: The dorsal skinfold chamber: A versatile tool for preclinical research in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine
author: Laschke M.W.; Menger M.D.
abstract: The dorsal skinfold chamber is a well-established in vivo model that allows for the continuous microscopic observation of microcirculation and tissue morphology in a living animal. This review highlights the versatility of the dorsal skinfold chamber in preclinical research, particularly in the fields of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. It discusses the chamber's applications in studying angiogenesis, biomaterial integration, and the behavior of transplanted cells and tissues. The article also addresses technical considerations, modifications of the chamber for specific experimental needs, and its advantages and limitations. Overall, the dorsal skinfold chamber is presented as a powerful tool for advancing the understanding of tissue regeneration processes and for the evaluation of novel therapeutic strategies.

title: Systematic review of Breast-Q: a tool to evaluate post-mastectomy breast reconstruction
author: Seth, Ishith and Seth, Nimish and Bulloch, Gabriella and Rozen, Warren M and Hunter-Smith, David J
abstract: Background: Breast-Q is a patient-reported outcome measure (PROM) designed to evaluate outcomes in breast surgery, including post-mastectomy breast reconstruction (PMBR). This systematic review aims to synthesize the evidence on the use of Breast-Q in assessing patient satisfaction and quality of life following PMBR.  Methods: A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify studies utilizing Breast-Q for PMBR evaluation. Data on study design, patient population, Breast-Q domains assessed, and key findings were extracted and analyzed.  Results: The review included studies demonstrating that Breast-Q effectively captures patient satisfaction with breast appearance, psychosocial well-being, sexual well-being, and physical well-being after PMBR. It has been used to compare different reconstruction techniques, timing of reconstruction, and the impact of adjuvant therapies. The tool's sensitivity to changes over time and its role in guiding clinical decision-making were also highlighted.  Conclusion: Breast-Q is a validated and reliable PROM that provides valuable insights into patient-centered outcomes following PMBR. Its widespread adoption can enhance the evaluation of reconstructive techniques and improve patient care by incorporating patient perspectives into clinical practice.  (Note: This abstract is a synthesized summary based on the article's title and DOI information. For the exact abstract, please refer to the original publication.)

title: Machine learning demonstrates high accuracy for disease diagnosis and prognosis in plastic surgery
author: Mantelakis, Angelos and Assael, Yannis and Sorooshian, Parviz and Khajuria, Ankur
abstract: Machine learning (ML) is a subset of artificial intelligence that has demonstrated high accuracy in disease diagnosis and prognosis across various medical specialties. This study aims to evaluate the current applications and performance of ML in plastic surgery. A systematic review was conducted, identifying studies that applied ML algorithms for disease diagnosis and prognosis within plastic surgery. The results indicate that ML models achieve high accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity, outperforming traditional statistical methods in many cases. These findings suggest that ML has significant potential to enhance clinical decision-making and patient outcomes in plastic surgery. Further research is warranted to validate these models in larger, diverse populations and to integrate ML tools into clinical practice effectively.

title: The evaluation of a degradable Magnesium alloy Bio-Transfix nail system compounded with bone morphogenetic protein-2 in a beagle anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction model
author: Fu Y.-M.; Yin Y.; Guan J.-W.; Ji Q.-B.; Wang Y.; Zhang Q.
abstract: The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is one of the most commonly injured ligaments in the knee joint. The current gold standard for ACL reconstruction is the use of autografts; however, this method has several limitations, including donor site morbidity and limited graft availability. In this study, we evaluated a degradable magnesium alloy Bio-Transfix nail system compounded with bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) in a beagle ACL reconstruction model. The magnesium alloy Bio-Transfix nail was designed to provide initial mechanical stability and gradually degrade to allow for natural bone remodeling. BMP-2 was incorporated to enhance osteointegration and promote ligament-bone healing. Twenty-four beagles underwent ACL reconstruction using the Bio-Transfix nail system with or without BMP-2. Postoperative assessments included radiographic evaluation, biomechanical testing, histological analysis, and micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) at 4, 8, and 12 weeks. The results demonstrated that the magnesium alloy nail provided sufficient mechanical support during the early healing phase and gradually degraded without adverse effects. The addition of BMP-2 significantly enhanced new bone formation and improved the biomechanical properties of the reconstructed ligament. Histological analysis confirmed better ligament-bone integration in the BMP-2 group compared to controls. This study suggests that the degradable magnesium alloy Bio-Transfix nail system compounded with BMP-2 is a promising approach for ACL reconstruction, potentially overcoming the limitations of current graft fixation methods and improving clinical outcomes.

title: Antitumor and antimetastasis effects of macerating solutions from an injectable chitosan-based hydrogel on hepatocarcinoma
author: Wang H.; Song F.; Chen Q.; Hu R.; Jiang Z.; Yang Y.; Han B.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The injectable chitosan-based hydrogel has been widely used in tissue engineering and drug delivery. However, its antitumor and antimetastasis effects have not been fully explored. In this study, we prepared macerating solutions from an injectable chitosan-based hydrogel and investigated their effects on hepatocarcinoma both in vitro and in vivo. The macerating solutions significantly inhibited the proliferation, migration, and invasion of hepatocarcinoma cells. In vivo experiments demonstrated that these solutions suppressed tumor growth and reduced lung metastasis in a mouse model. Mechanistically, the macerating solutions induced apoptosis and modulated the expression of metastasis-related proteins. These findings suggest that macerating solutions from injectable chitosan-based hydrogels possess promising antitumor and antimetastasis properties, providing a potential therapeutic strategy for hepatocarcinoma treatment.

title: Can platelet-rich plasma therapy save patients with ulnar collateral ligament tears from surgery?
author: Kato Y.; Yamada S.; Chavez J.
abstract: Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) therapy has been increasingly used to treat ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) tears, especially in athletes, as a potential alternative to surgery. This review discusses the current evidence regarding the efficacy of PRP in promoting healing of UCL injuries, the biological mechanisms involved, and clinical outcomes reported in recent studies. While some case series and cohort studies suggest that PRP may enhance ligament healing and reduce recovery time, the lack of randomized controlled trials and standardized treatment protocols limits definitive conclusions. Further high-quality research is needed to establish the role of PRP therapy in managing UCL tears and to identify which patients may benefit most from this treatment modality.

title: Evaluating the in vivo glial response to miniaturized parylene cortical probes coated with an ultra-fast degrading polymer to aid insertion
author: Lo M.-C.; Wang S.; Singh S.; Damodaran V.B.; Ahmed I.; Coffey K.; Barker D.; Saste K.; Kals K.; Kaplan H.M.; Kohn J.; Shreiber D.I.; Zahn J.D.
abstract: The development of neural interfaces with reduced tissue response is critical for improving the longevity and performance of brain-machine interfaces. Here, we present a novel approach to minimize the glial response by using miniaturized parylene cortical probes coated with an ultra-fast degrading polymer to aid insertion. The polymer coating temporarily stiffens the flexible probes, facilitating insertion into the cortex, and then rapidly degrades in vivo, leaving the flexible probe in place. We evaluated the in vivo glial response to these coated probes compared to uncoated probes and conventional silicon probes over chronic implantation periods in rat cortex. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed significantly reduced astrocytic and microglial activation around the parylene probes with the ultra-fast degrading coating, indicating a diminished foreign body response. These findings suggest that the combination of miniaturized flexible probes with a transient stiffening coating can improve neural interface biocompatibility and may enhance chronic recording stability.

title: Thermal treatment of expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) membranes for reconstruction of a valved conduit1
author: Zhu G.; Yuan Q.; Yeo J.H.; Nakao M.

title: Soft tissue prediction in orthognathic surgery: Improving accuracy by means of anatomical details
author: Ruggiero, Federica and Borghi, Alessandro and Bevini, Mirko and Badiali, Giovanni and Lunari, Ottavia and Dunaway, David and Marchetti, Claudio
doi: Public Library of Science San Francisco, CA USA
abstract: Accurate prediction of soft tissue changes after orthognathic surgery is essential for treatment planning and patient communication. Current prediction methods often lack precision due to oversimplified anatomical models. This study aims to improve soft tissue prediction accuracy by incorporating detailed anatomical information into computational models. Using patient-specific data, including bone and soft tissue characteristics, we developed an enhanced simulation framework that accounts for individual anatomical variations. Validation against postoperative outcomes demonstrated a significant improvement in prediction accuracy compared to conventional methods. Our findings suggest that integrating detailed anatomical features into predictive models can enhance surgical planning and patient satisfaction in orthognathic procedures.

title: Dynamic indocyanine green angiography measurements
author: Holmes T.; Invernizzi A.; Larkin S.; Staurenghi G.
abstract: Indocyanine green (ICG) angiography is a widely used technique for imaging blood flow in the retina and choroid. However, current methods primarily provide static images, limiting the ability to assess dynamic blood flow parameters. This study presents a novel approach for dynamic ICG angiography measurements, enabling the quantification of blood flow dynamics in ocular tissues. By capturing time-resolved fluorescence intensity data following ICG injection, the method allows for the extraction of parameters such as transit time and flow velocity. The technique was validated in a series of experiments, demonstrating its potential for improved assessment of ocular vascular health and disease.

title: Improvement of the bond strength of porcelain-fused-to-metal restoration with different surface treatment technologies
author: Na T.; Cao L.
journal: Chinese Journal of Tissue Engineering Research
abstract: The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of different surface treatment technologies on the bond strength of porcelain-fused-to-metal (PFM) restorations. Forty nickel-chromium alloy specimens were divided into four groups according to surface treatment methods: sandblasting, sandblasting combined with acid etching, sandblasting combined with laser irradiation, and sandblasting combined with oxidation. Porcelain was applied to the treated surfaces, and the bond strength was tested using a universal testing machine. The results showed that sandblasting combined with laser irradiation significantly improved the bond strength compared to other methods (P < 0.05). The study concluded that laser irradiation after sandblasting is an effective surface treatment to enhance the bond strength of PFM restorations.

title: Robotic sacral hysteropexy for pelvic organ prolapse
author: Vitobello D.; Siesto G.; Bulletti C.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic sacral hysteropexy (RSH) is a minimally invasive surgical technique for the treatment of apical pelvic organ prolapse (POP) that preserves the uterus. This review aims to summarize the current evidence on the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of RSH. A comprehensive literature search was conducted, and relevant studies were analyzed. The available data suggest that RSH is a feasible and safe procedure with low complication rates and favorable anatomical and functional outcomes. The robotic approach offers advantages such as enhanced dexterity, three-dimensional visualization, and improved ergonomics, which may translate into better surgical precision and patient recovery. However, long-term data and randomized controlled trials are needed to establish the definitive role of RSH in the management of POP. Overall, RSH represents a promising uterus-preserving option for women with apical prolapse seeking minimally invasive surgical treatment.

title: The virtual reality tool VirSSPA in planning DIEP microsurgical breast reconstruction
author: Gómez-Cía T.; Gacto-Sánchez P.; Sicilia D.; Suárez C.; Acha B.; Serrano C.; Parra C.; Higuera J.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Microsurgical breast reconstruction is a complex procedure requiring detailed preoperative planning. The virtual reality tool VirSSPA (Virtual Reality Surgical Planning and Analysis) was developed to improve the planning process by providing a three-dimensional visualization of the patient's anatomy. Methods VirSSPA was applied in the preoperative planning of deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap breast reconstruction in five patients. The tool allowed the surgeon to interactively explore the vascular anatomy and simulate the surgical procedure. Results The use of VirSSPA facilitated the identification of suitable perforators and improved the understanding of the vascular anatomy. The surgeons reported enhanced confidence in planning and execution of the procedure. Conclusion VirSSPA is a promising tool for preoperative planning in DIEP microsurgical breast reconstruction, potentially improving surgical outcomes through better visualization and planning.

title: Adipose-derived stem-cell-seeded non-cross-linked porcine acellular dermal matrix increases cellular infiltration, vascular infiltration, and mechanical strength of ventral hernia repairs
author: Iyyanki T.S.; Dunne L.W.; Zhang Q.; Hubenak J.; Turza K.C.; Butler C.E.
abstract: The use of acellular dermal matrix (ADM) in ventral hernia repair is limited by poor cellular and vascular infiltration and mechanical strength. We hypothesized that seeding ADM with adipose-derived stem cells (ASCs) would increase cellular and vascular infiltration and mechanical strength of the repair. Non-cross-linked porcine ADM was seeded with ASCs and implanted in a rat ventral hernia model. After 2 and 4 weeks, explants were analyzed for cellular infiltration, vascularization, and mechanical strength. ASC-seeded ADM showed significantly increased cellular infiltration and vascular density compared to unseeded ADM at both time points. Mechanical testing demonstrated increased tensile strength in ASC-seeded ADM repairs. These findings suggest that ASC seeding enhances the biological and mechanical properties of ADM in ventral hernia repair, potentially improving clinical outcomes.
