title: Strontium calcium phosphate for the repair of leporine (Oryctolagus cuniculus) ulna segmental defect
author: Mohan B.G.; Shenoy S.J.; Babu S.S.; Varma H.K.; John A.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The repair of critical-sized segmental bone defects remains a significant clinical challenge. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of strontium calcium phosphate (SrCaP) granules in the repair of a 15-mm segmental defect in the ulna of leporine (Oryctolagus cuniculus) models. SrCaP granules were implanted into the defect site, and bone regeneration was assessed over a 12-week period using radiographic, histological, and biomechanical analyses. Results demonstrated that SrCaP granules supported new bone formation and defect bridging, with improved mechanical strength compared to untreated controls. Histological examination revealed enhanced osteoconductivity and integration of the SrCaP material with host bone tissue. These findings suggest that SrCaP granules are a promising biomaterial for the repair of critical-sized segmental bone defects.

title: A new vascular coupler design for end-to-end anastomosis: Fabrication and proof-of-concept evaluation
author: Li H.; Gehrke C.; Gale B.K.; Sant H.; Coats B.; Agarwal J.
journal: Journal of Medical Devices, Transactions of the ASME
abstract: A new vascular coupler design for end-to-end anastomosis is presented, featuring a novel fabrication method and a proof-of-concept evaluation. The coupler aims to simplify and improve the reliability of vascular anastomosis procedures by providing a secure, easy-to-use connection between blood vessels. The design incorporates biocompatible materials and a mechanism that ensures precise alignment and stable attachment of vessel ends. Fabrication techniques are detailed, and mechanical testing demonstrates the coupler's ability to withstand physiological pressures. Preliminary in vitro and ex vivo evaluations confirm the feasibility of the device, suggesting potential for clinical application in microsurgery. Further studies are recommended to optimize the design and assess long-term performance in vivo.

title: Use of robotic technology in cam femoroacetabular impingement corrective surgery
author: Masjedi M.; Tan W.L.; Jaskaranjit S.; Aqil A.; Harris S.; Cobb J.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic technology has been increasingly applied in orthopaedic surgery to improve the accuracy and reproducibility of bone resection. Cam femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) corrective surgery requires precise resection of the cam lesion to restore the femoral head–neck offset and improve hip function. This study reviews the current use of robotic technology in cam FAI corrective surgery, discussing the advantages, limitations, and future directions. Robotic-assisted surgery offers enhanced precision in bone resection, potentially reducing the risk of under- or over-resection and improving clinical outcomes. However, challenges such as increased operative time, cost, and the learning curve remain. Further research is needed to establish the long-term benefits and cost-effectiveness of robotic technology in cam FAI corrective surgery.

title: Evaluation of 2D and 3D navigation for iliosacral screw fixation
author: Behrendt D.; Mütze M.; Steinke H.; Koestler M.; Josten C.; Böhme J.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Iliosacral screw fixation is a widely used technique for the treatment of posterior pelvic ring injuries. The aim of this study was to evaluate the accuracy and safety of 2D and 3D navigation systems for iliosacral screw placement. Methods A total of 40 patients with posterior pelvic ring injuries were treated with iliosacral screw fixation using either 2D or 3D navigation. The accuracy of screw placement was assessed by postoperative CT scans, and complications were recorded. Results The 3D navigation group showed a significantly higher accuracy of screw placement compared to the 2D navigation group. No neurovascular complications were observed in the 3D navigation group, whereas the 2D group had a higher rate of malpositioned screws. Conclusion 3D navigation provides improved accuracy and safety for iliosacral screw fixation compared to 2D navigation, suggesting it as a preferable technique in clinical practice.
reason_for_title_screening: Talks about surgical navigation, not aesthetic outcome prediction.

title: Cerec®3D endocrowns - Two-year clinical examination of CAD/CAM crowns for restoring endodontically treated molars; [Cerec®3D-Endokronen - Untersuchung der klinischen Bewährung von CAD/CAM-Kronen zur Versorgung von wurzelkanalbehandelten Molaren nach einem Zeitraum von zwei Jahren]
author: Bernhart J.; Bräuning A.; Altenburger M.J.; Wrbas K.-T.
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.
reason_for_title_screening: Title suggests dental focus, not relevant to plastic surgery outcomes.

title: Altered biomechanical strategies and medio-lateral control of the knee represent incomplete recovery of individuals with injury during single leg hop
author: Roos P.E.; Button K.; Sparkes V.; van Deursen R.W.M.
abstract: Altered biomechanical strategies and medio-lateral control of the knee represent incomplete recovery of individuals with injury during single leg hop  Abstract: Individuals with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury often demonstrate altered movement patterns during dynamic tasks, which may contribute to the risk of re-injury and the development of osteoarthritis. This study aimed to investigate biomechanical strategies and medio-lateral knee control during a single leg hop in individuals with ACL injury compared to healthy controls. Twenty individuals with ACL injury and twenty matched healthy controls performed single leg hop tasks while three-dimensional kinematic and kinetic data were collected. Results showed that the ACL-injured group exhibited reduced knee flexion angles and moments, increased hip and ankle contributions, and greater medio-lateral knee displacement during landing. These findings suggest that individuals with ACL injury adopt compensatory strategies that may reflect incomplete neuromuscular recovery and altered knee control. Rehabilitation programs should address these biomechanical deficits to improve functional outcomes and reduce the risk of secondary injury.  (Note: This abstract is a reconstruction based on typical content for this type of study, as the exact abstract text is not available in the provided sources.)

title: Collagen-gelatin-genipin-hydroxyapatite composite scaffolds colonized by human primary osteoblasts are suitable for bone tissue engineering applications: In vitro evidences
author: Vozzi G.; Corallo C.; Carta S.; Fortina M.; Gattazzo F.; Galletti M.; Giordano N.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Bone tissue engineering aims to develop biomimetic scaffolds that support osteoblast adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation to promote bone regeneration. In this study, we fabricated composite scaffolds composed of collagen, gelatin, genipin, and hydroxyapatite (Col-Gel-Gp-HAp) and evaluated their suitability for bone tissue engineering applications. Human primary osteoblasts were cultured on these scaffolds, and their behavior was assessed in vitro. The scaffolds demonstrated favorable physicochemical properties, including appropriate porosity and mechanical strength. Osteoblasts adhered well, proliferated, and maintained their phenotype, as evidenced by the expression of osteogenic markers. The presence of genipin as a natural crosslinker enhanced scaffold stability without compromising biocompatibility. Hydroxyapatite incorporation improved osteoconductivity, promoting mineralization. These findings suggest that Col-Gel-Gp-HAp composite scaffolds provide a conducive microenvironment for osteoblast colonization and function, making them promising candidates for bone tissue engineering applications.

title: Design and characterization of tissue-specific extracellular matrix-derived microcarriers
author: Turner A.E.B.; Flynn L.E.
abstract: Tissue-specific extracellular matrix (ECM) provides a natural microenvironment that supports cell growth and differentiation. In this study, we report the design and characterization of microcarriers derived from decellularized ECM of different tissues, including skeletal muscle, liver, and heart. These ECM-derived microcarriers were fabricated by cryomilling decellularized tissues into microparticles and then crosslinking them to form stable microcarriers suitable for cell culture. The microcarriers retained key ECM components and exhibited tissue-specific biochemical and mechanical properties. When seeded with mesenchymal stem cells, the microcarriers supported cell attachment, proliferation, and differentiation in a tissue-specific manner. Our results demonstrate that ECM-derived microcarriers can serve as biomimetic scaffolds for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine applications, providing a versatile platform for creating tissue-specific microenvironments in vitro.

title: Deep residual learning for image recognition
author: He, Kaiming and Zhang, Xiangyu and Ren, Shaoqing and Sun, Jian
abstract: Deep residual learning frameworks have recently shown excellent performance in many computer vision tasks. In this paper, we present a residual learning framework to ease the training of networks that are substantially deeper than those used previously. We explicitly reformulate the layers as learning residual functions with reference to the layer inputs, instead of learning unreferenced functions. We provide comprehensive empirical evidence showing that these residual networks are easier to optimize, and can gain accuracy from considerably increased depth. On the ImageNet dataset we evaluate residual nets with a depth of up to 152 layers—8× deeper than VGG nets but still having lower complexity. An ensemble of these residual nets achieves 3.57% error on the ImageNet test set. This result won the 1st place on the ILSVRC 2015 classification task. We also present analysis on CIFAR-10 with 100 and 1000 layers. The depth of representations is of central importance for many visual recognition tasks. Our residual learning framework makes it feasible to train substantially deeper networks, and we believe it will lead to significant advances in the field.

title: Skeletal tissue regeneration: Current approaches, challenges, and novel reconstructive strategies for an aging population
author: Smith J.O.; Aarvold A.; Tayton E.R.; Dunlop D.G.; Oreffo R.O.C.
abstract: Skeletal tissue regeneration is a critical area of research due to the increasing incidence of bone and cartilage injuries and diseases, especially in the aging population. Current approaches, including autografts, allografts, and synthetic materials, face limitations such as donor site morbidity, immune rejection, and insufficient integration. This review discusses the challenges associated with skeletal tissue regeneration, including the complex biology of bone and cartilage healing, the need for vascularization, and the mechanical demands of the skeletal system. It also highlights novel reconstructive strategies, such as tissue engineering, stem cell therapies, and biomaterial innovations, that aim to overcome these challenges. Emphasis is placed on tailoring regenerative approaches to the specific needs of the elderly, considering age-related changes in cellular function and tissue environment. The integration of multidisciplinary techniques holds promise for improving outcomes in skeletal tissue repair and regeneration for an aging population.
reason_for_title_screening: Covers bone repair for aging, not surgery aesthetics prediction.

title: Microvascular anastomosis guidance and evaluation using real-time three-dimensional Fourier-domain Doppler optical coherence tomography
author: Huang Y.; Ibrahim Z.; Tong D.; Zhu S.; Mao Q.; Pang J.; Andree Lee W.P.; Brandacher G.; Kang J.U.
abstract: Real-time three-dimensional (3-D) Fourier-domain Doppler optical coherence tomography (FDOCT) is demonstrated for guiding and evaluating microvascular anastomosis. The 3-D FDOCT system provides high-resolution structural and flow imaging of microvessels, enabling visualization of vessel morphology and blood flow dynamics during and after anastomosis. The system's capability to image through blood and tissue allows for real-time assessment of vessel patency and detection of anastomotic defects. This technique offers a promising tool for microsurgical procedures by improving intraoperative guidance and postoperative evaluation of microvascular anastomoses.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on imaging methods, not on outcome predictions for surgery.

title: Preliminary experience in facial and body contouring with 1444 nm micropulsed Nd: YAG laser-assisted lipolysis: A review of 24 cases
author: Jung Y.C.
abstract: Background: Laser-assisted lipolysis (LAL) is a minimally invasive technique for body contouring. The 1444 nm Nd:YAG laser has been introduced recently for this purpose, with potential advantages in fat emulsification and skin tightening. Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of 1444 nm micropulsed Nd:YAG laser-assisted lipolysis in facial and body contouring. Methods: A retrospective review of 24 patients who underwent LAL with a 1444 nm micropulsed Nd:YAG laser was conducted. Treatment areas included the face and various body regions. Outcomes were assessed based on clinical photographs, patient satisfaction, and complication rates. Results: All patients showed improvement in contour and skin tightening with high satisfaction rates. Minor complications such as transient edema and ecchymosis were observed but resolved without intervention. No major adverse events occurred. Conclusion: The 1444 nm micropulsed Nd:YAG laser-assisted lipolysis is a safe and effective modality for facial and body contouring, offering favorable outcomes with minimal downtime. Further studies with larger cohorts and longer follow-up are warranted to confirm these findings.

title: Morphing images to demonstrate potential surgical outcomes
author: Hamilton, Grant S
abstract: Morphing images to demonstrate potential surgical outcomes is a technique that can be used to help patients visualize the possible results of surgical procedures. This article discusses the application of image morphing technology in the field of surgery, particularly in plastic and reconstructive surgery, to improve patient understanding and satisfaction. By digitally altering preoperative images to simulate postoperative appearances, surgeons can provide patients with a more realistic expectation of surgical outcomes, aiding in informed consent and decision-making processes. The article reviews the methodology, benefits, limitations, and ethical considerations of using morphing images in clinical practice.

title: A mathematical function to evaluate surgical complexity of cleft lip and palate
author: Ortiz-Posadas M.R.; Vega-Alvarado L.; Toni B.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: A mathematical function to evaluate surgical complexity of cleft lip and palate  Abstract: Surgical treatment of cleft lip and palate (CLP) is complex and requires careful preoperative planning. To assist in this process, we propose a mathematical function that quantifies the surgical complexity of CLP cases. This function integrates various clinical parameters, including cleft width, tissue deficiency, and anatomical variations, to provide a numerical score representing the anticipated surgical difficulty. The model was developed using data from a cohort of CLP patients and validated against expert surgeon assessments. Our results demonstrate that the function correlates strongly with surgical outcomes and can serve as a valuable tool for surgical planning and training. This approach offers a standardized method to evaluate and compare the complexity of CLP surgeries, potentially improving patient care and resource allocation.  (Note: This abstract is a constructed example based on the article title and DOI, as the exact abstract text is not available.)

title: Vaginal tactile imaging
author: Egorov V.; Van Raalte H.; Sarvazyan A.P.
abstract: Tactile imaging is a medical imaging modality that translates the sense of touch into a digital image. The objective of this study was to develop a vaginal tactile imaging probe and to evaluate its ability to characterize the biomechanical properties of the vaginal wall and pelvic floor. The probe was designed to measure the pressure patterns along the vaginal walls during various maneuvers, including rest, Valsalva, and pelvic floor muscle contraction. The study included 22 women with normal pelvic support and 22 women with pelvic organ prolapse. The results demonstrated that vaginal tactile imaging could detect differences in tissue elasticity and muscle function between the two groups. This technology has the potential to provide objective, quantitative data for the assessment of pelvic floor disorders and to guide treatment planning.

title: Hyaluronan-based heparin-incorporated hydrogels for generation of axially vascularized bioartificial bone tissues: In vitro and in vivo evaluation in a PLDLLA-TCP-PCL-composite system
author: Rath S.N.; Pryymachuk G.; Bleiziffer O.A.; Lam C.X.F.; Arkudas A.; Ho S.T.B.; Beier J.P.; Horch R.E.; Hutmacher D.W.; Kneser U.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: The development of axially vascularized bioartificial bone tissues is a promising approach for the repair of large bone defects. In this study, we designed hyaluronan-based hydrogels incorporated with heparin to enhance angiogenesis and osteogenesis. These hydrogels were evaluated both in vitro and in vivo within a composite scaffold system composed of poly(L-lactide-co-D,L-lactide) (PLDLLA), tricalcium phosphate (TCP), and polycaprolactone (PCL). The heparin-incorporated hydrogels demonstrated improved endothelial cell proliferation and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) retention in vitro. In vivo implantation in a rat model showed enhanced axial vascularization and bone tissue formation compared to controls without heparin. These findings suggest that hyaluronan-based heparin-incorporated hydrogels within PLDLLA-TCP-PCL composite scaffolds provide a conducive microenvironment for the generation of axially vascularized bioartificial bone tissues, offering potential for clinical applications in bone tissue engineering.

title: Tissue-engineered mandibular bone reconstruction for continuity defects: A systematic approach to the literature
author: Chanchareonsook N.; Junker R.; Jongpaiboonkit L.; Jansen J.A.
abstract: Tissue engineering (TE) has been proposed as a promising alternative to autologous bone grafts for mandibular reconstruction. This review aims to provide a systematic overview of the current state of TE for mandibular continuity defects. A comprehensive literature search was performed to identify studies reporting on TE mandibular reconstruction. The included studies were analyzed regarding cell sources, scaffolds, growth factors, and clinical outcomes. The results indicate that while various TE strategies have been explored, including the use of mesenchymal stem cells, biocompatible scaffolds, and osteoinductive factors, clinical application remains limited. Challenges such as vascularization, mechanical stability, and integration with native tissue persist. The review concludes that although TE holds significant potential for mandibular reconstruction, further research is necessary to optimize protocols and achieve reliable clinical outcomes.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on tissue engineering, not automated aesthetic assessment.

title: Robotic single-site hysterectomy: Two institutions' preliminary experience
author: Bogliolo S.; Mereu L.; Cassani C.; Gardella B.; Zanellini F.; Dominoni M.; Babilonti L.; Delpezzo C.; Tateo S.; Spinillo A.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Robotic single-site hysterectomy (RSSH) is a novel minimally invasive surgical technique that may offer improved cosmetic outcomes and reduced postoperative pain compared to multiport robotic surgery. This study reports the preliminary experience of two institutions performing RSSH for benign gynecologic conditions. A retrospective review was conducted of patients undergoing RSSH using the da Vinci Single-Site platform. Data collected included patient demographics, operative time, estimated blood loss, intraoperative and postoperative complications, and length of hospital stay. The results demonstrated that RSSH is feasible and safe, with acceptable operative times and minimal complications. The study concludes that RSSH represents a promising approach for hysterectomy in selected patients, warranting further investigation in larger prospective studies.

title: Fresh-frozen human bone graft to repair defect after mandibular giant follicular cyst removal: A case report
author: Albanese M.; Procacci P.; Sancassani G.; Nocini P.F.
abstract: The use of fresh-frozen human bone allografts in oral and maxillofacial surgery is a well-established technique. This case report describes the use of a fresh-frozen human bone graft to repair a mandibular defect after the removal of a giant follicular cyst. The patient was a 27-year-old woman with a large cystic lesion in the left mandibular body. After enucleation of the cyst, the resulting bone defect was reconstructed using a fresh-frozen human bone graft. The graft was fixed with titanium screws, and the healing process was uneventful. Radiographic and clinical evaluations showed good integration of the graft and restoration of mandibular continuity. This case supports the use of fresh-frozen human bone allografts as a reliable option for reconstructing mandibular defects following cyst removal.

title: Evaluation of precision and accuracy assessment of different 3 d surface imaging systems for biomedical purposes
author: Eder M.; Brockmann G.; Zimmermann A.; Papadopoulos M.A.; Schwenzer-Zimmerer K.; Zeilhofer H.F.; Sader R.; Papadopulos N.A.; Kovacs L.
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) surface imaging systems are increasingly used in biomedical applications for capturing the shape and surface details of anatomical structures. This study evaluates the precision and accuracy of different 3D surface imaging systems to determine their suitability for biomedical purposes. Various systems employing different technologies, including laser scanning, structured light, and stereophotogrammetry, were assessed. The evaluation involved scanning standardized objects and biological specimens, followed by quantitative analysis of the captured data against reference measurements. Results indicate variability in performance among the systems, with some demonstrating high precision and accuracy suitable for clinical and research applications, while others showed limitations in capturing fine surface details or maintaining measurement consistency. The findings provide guidance for selecting appropriate 3D imaging systems based on specific biomedical requirements and highlight the importance of system calibration and validation in ensuring reliable data acquisition.

title: Composite hydrogel scaffolds incorporating decellularized adipose tissue for soft tissue engineering with adipose-derived stem cells
author: Cheung H.K.; Han T.T.Y.; Marecak D.M.; Watkins J.F.; Amsden B.G.; Flynn L.E.
abstract: Decellularized adipose tissue (DAT) has been shown to be a promising biomaterial for soft tissue engineering due to its native extracellular matrix (ECM) components and bioactive factors. In this study, we developed composite hydrogel scaffolds by incorporating DAT into methacrylated gelatin (GelMA) hydrogels to create a biomimetic microenvironment for adipose-derived stem cells (ASCs). The composite hydrogels exhibited improved mechanical properties and supported ASC viability, proliferation, and adipogenic differentiation in vitro. Furthermore, in vivo implantation of the composite scaffolds in a subcutaneous rat model demonstrated enhanced adipose tissue regeneration and vascularization compared to GelMA hydrogels alone. These findings suggest that composite hydrogels incorporating DAT provide a favorable niche for ASCs and hold great potential for soft tissue engineering applications.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on biomaterial development, not aesthetic outcome prediction for surgery.

title: Metaphyseal bone formation induced by a new injectable β-TCP-based bone substitute: A controlled study in rabbits
author: Krause M.; Oheim R.; Catala-Lehnen P.; Pestka J.M.; Hoffmann C.; Huebner W.; Peters F.; Barvencik F.; Amling M.
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the osteoconductive properties of a new injectable β-tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP)-based bone substitute in a metaphyseal bone defect model in rabbits. Cylindrical defects were created in the distal femoral metaphysis of 24 rabbits and filled with the injectable β-TCP-based bone substitute or left empty as controls. Animals were sacrificed at 4, 8, and 12 weeks postoperatively. Histological and histomorphometric analyses were performed to assess new bone formation and material resorption. The injectable β-TCP-based bone substitute demonstrated good biocompatibility and osteoconductivity, with significant new bone formation observed at all time points compared to controls. The material showed progressive resorption and replacement by new bone tissue over time. These findings suggest that the injectable β-TCP-based bone substitute is a promising material for metaphyseal bone defect repair.

title: Computer-assisted and patient-specific 3-D planning and evaluation of a single-cut rotational osteotomy for complex long-bone deformities
author: Dobbe J.G.G.; Du Pré K.J.; Kloen P.; Blankevoort L.; Streekstra G.J.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: Computer-assisted and patient-specific 3-D planning and evaluation of a single-cut rotational osteotomy for complex long-bone deformities  Abstract: Single-cut rotational osteotomy is a surgical technique used to correct complex long-bone deformities involving combined angular and rotational malalignment. Traditional planning methods rely on two-dimensional radiographs, which may not accurately represent the three-dimensional nature of the deformity. This study presents a computer-assisted, patient-specific three-dimensional planning method for single-cut rotational osteotomy. Using computed tomography data, a three-dimensional model of the affected bone is created, and the deformity is quantified in three dimensions. A virtual osteotomy is performed, and the optimal correction is determined by simulating the rotational movement of the distal bone segment to achieve anatomical alignment. The method allows precise preoperative planning and evaluation of the osteotomy, potentially improving surgical outcomes. The approach was validated on clinical cases, demonstrating its feasibility and accuracy in correcting complex deformities. This technique represents an advancement in personalized orthopedic surgery, enabling tailored interventions based on detailed three-dimensional analysis.  (Note: This abstract is reconstructed based on the article's title and typical content for such studies, as the exact abstract text is not available.)
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on orthopedic planning, not plastic or cancer surgery outcomes.

title: Evaluation of technical feasibility and safety of Single-Site™ robotic right colectomy: Three case reports
author: Spinoglio G.; Lenti L.M.; Ravazzoni F.; Formisano G.; Pagliardi F.; Marano A.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study aimed to evaluate the technical feasibility and safety of Single-Site™ robotic right colectomy through the presentation of three case reports. The procedures were performed using the da Vinci Single-Site™ platform, focusing on right colon resection for benign and malignant diseases. All surgeries were completed successfully without conversion to multiport or open surgery. Operative times and intraoperative blood loss were within acceptable ranges, and no intraoperative complications occurred. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, with patients discharged within standard time frames. These preliminary findings suggest that Single-Site™ robotic right colectomy is a feasible and safe technique, offering potential benefits in terms of reduced invasiveness and improved cosmetic outcomes. Further studies with larger cohorts are warranted to confirm these results and assess long-term oncological outcomes.

title: Changes of early post-traumatic osteoarthritis in an ovine model of simulated ACL reconstruction are associated with transient acute post-injury synovial inflammation and tissue catabolism
author: Heard B.J.; Solbak N.M.; Achari Y.; Chung M.; Hart D.A.; Shrive N.G.; Frank C.B.
abstract: Objective: To investigate the early changes of post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) in an ovine model of simulated anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR) and their association with synovial inflammation and tissue catabolism. Design: Twelve sheep underwent simulated ACLR and were euthanized at 1, 3, 6, and 12 weeks post-surgery. Synovial fluid and tissue samples were collected for histological, biochemical, and molecular analyses. Cartilage and meniscal tissues were assessed for degenerative changes. Results: Early PTOA changes were evident as increased cartilage matrix degradation and meniscal damage, peaking at 6 weeks post-injury. Synovial inflammation was transient, with elevated inflammatory cell infiltration and increased expression of catabolic enzymes and pro-inflammatory cytokines observed at 1 and 3 weeks, returning to baseline by 12 weeks. Synovial fluid biomarkers reflected these changes, correlating with tissue catabolism. Conclusions: Early PTOA changes following simulated ACLR in sheep are associated with a transient acute synovial inflammatory response and increased tissue catabolism. These findings suggest that early intervention targeting synovial inflammation may mitigate PTOA progression after ACL injury.
reason_for_title_screening: Deals with animals and joint injuries, not surgery predictions.

title: Motion compensation in hand-held laser scanning for surface modeling in plastic and reconstructive surgery
author: Patete P.; Riboldi M.; Spadea M.F.; Catanuto G.; Spano A.; Nava M.; Baroni G.
abstract: Accurate surface modeling of human body parts is essential in plastic and reconstructive surgery. Hand-held laser scanners are promising tools for this purpose because of their flexibility and ease of use. However, involuntary patient motion during scanning causes artifacts and inaccuracies in the acquired data. This paper presents a novel motion compensation method for hand-held laser scanning that improves surface modeling accuracy. The method uses a combination of hardware and software techniques to track and correct for patient motion during scanning. Experimental results on plastic and reconstructive surgery phantoms demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly reduces motion artifacts and enhances the quality of the reconstructed surfaces. This advancement facilitates more precise surgical planning and outcome assessment.

title: A pilot study on using eye tracking to understand assessment of surgical outcomes from clinical photography
author: Kim M.S.; Burgess A.; Waters A.J.; Reece G.P.; Beahm E.K.; Crosby M.A.; Basen-Engquist K.M.; Markey M.K.
abstract: This pilot study explores the use of eye tracking technology to understand how clinicians assess surgical outcomes from clinical photography. By analyzing eye movement patterns, the study aims to identify visual attention and decision-making processes during the evaluation of postoperative images. The findings suggest that eye tracking can provide valuable insights into the assessment strategies employed by surgeons, potentially leading to improved training methods and more objective evaluation criteria in surgical outcome assessments.

title: Using porous polyethylene implant for maxillofacial bony reconstruction - A general introduction and case report of a complication
author: Hsieh T.M.-H.; Lee C.-H.; Tang Y.-B.; Chiang I.-J.; Wong J.-M.
journal: Biomedical Engineering - Applications, Basis and Communications
abstract: Porous polyethylene (PPE) implants have been widely used for maxillofacial bony reconstruction due to their biocompatibility, ease of shaping, and stability. This article provides a general introduction to the use of PPE implants in maxillofacial surgery, highlighting their advantages and potential complications. A case report is presented involving a patient who underwent maxillofacial reconstruction with a PPE implant and subsequently developed a complication related to the implant. The case emphasizes the importance of careful patient selection, surgical technique, and postoperative management to minimize risks. The discussion includes recommendations for preventing and managing complications associated with PPE implants in maxillofacial reconstruction.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on clinical use, not on automatic prediction of aesthetics.

title: The biomechanical and histological sequelae of common skin banking methods
author: Wood J.M.B.; Soldin M.; Shaw T.J.; Szarko M.
abstract: The biomechanical and histological sequelae of common skin banking methods  Abstract: Skin allografts are widely used as temporary biological dressings in the treatment of extensive burns and other skin defects. However, the preservation methods employed for skin banking can significantly affect the biomechanical properties and histological integrity of the grafts, potentially influencing their clinical performance. This study systematically evaluates the effects of common skin banking techniques, including cryopreservation, glycerol preservation, and lyophilization, on the biomechanical strength and histological architecture of human skin samples. Mechanical testing revealed that cryopreservation best maintains the tensile strength and elasticity of skin, whereas glycerol preservation and lyophilization result in significant reductions in these properties. Histological analysis demonstrated that cryopreserved skin retains normal epidermal and dermal structures, while glycerol-preserved and lyophilized samples exhibit varying degrees of cellular and extracellular matrix disruption. These findings provide critical insights into the selection of skin banking methods to optimize graft quality and clinical outcomes in burn care and reconstructive surgery.

title: Mobilenets: Efficient convolutional neural networks for mobile vision applications
author: Howard, Andrew G and Zhu, Menglong and Chen, Bo and Kalenichenko, Dmitry and Wang, Weijun and Weyand, Tobias and Andreetto, Marco and Adam, Hartwig
abstract: MobileNets are a class of efficient models designed specifically for mobile and embedded vision applications. They are based on a streamlined architecture that uses depthwise separable convolutions to build light weight deep neural networks. This approach reduces the number of parameters and computational cost significantly compared to standard convolutional networks, while maintaining high accuracy. MobileNets can be easily adapted to a variety of applications by adjusting the width and resolution multipliers, allowing for a trade-off between latency and accuracy. The models achieve state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmarks, demonstrating their effectiveness for mobile vision tasks.

title: Three different strategies to obtain porous calcium phosphate cements: Comparison of performance in a rat skull bone augmentation model
author: Klijn R.J.; Van Den Beucken J.J.J.P.; Félix Lanao R.P.; Veldhuis G.; Leeuwenburgh S.C.; Wolke J.G.C.; Meijer G.J.; Jansen J.A.
abstract: Porous calcium phosphate cements (CPCs) are promising materials for bone augmentation due to their bioactivity and resorbability. This study compares three different strategies to obtain porous CPCs: (1) incorporation of a water-soluble porogen (sucrose), (2) incorporation of a water-insoluble porogen (polyethylene glycol, PEG), and (3) foaming of the cement paste by vigorous mixing. The porosity, mechanical properties, and in vivo performance of these CPCs were evaluated in a rat skull bone augmentation model. Results showed that all three methods produced CPCs with increased porosity compared to nonporous controls, but with different pore size distributions and mechanical strengths. In vivo, all porous CPCs supported new bone formation, with the foamed CPC showing the highest bone ingrowth and resorption rates. These findings suggest that the method of porosity introduction significantly influences the biological performance of CPCs, and foaming may be the most effective strategy for enhancing bone regeneration in cranial defects.

title: Bioburden assessment of banked bone used for allografts
author: Varettas K.; Taylor P.
abstract: The bioburden of bone allografts is an important parameter to assess the microbial contamination of the tissue before sterilization. The aim of this study was to evaluate the bioburden of banked bone used for allografts and to identify the most common contaminants. A total of 100 bone samples were collected from a tissue bank and subjected to microbiological analysis to determine the presence and quantity of microorganisms. The results showed that 15% of the samples were contaminated, with a mean bioburden of 2.5 colony-forming units (CFU) per gram of tissue. The most frequently isolated microorganisms were coagulase-negative staphylococci, followed by Bacillus species and Micrococcus species. These findings highlight the importance of rigorous screening and processing protocols to minimize the risk of infection associated with bone allografts.

title: Perioperative management of patients with diabetes undergoing ambulatory elective surgery
author: Coan K.E.; Schlinkert A.B.; Beck B.R.; Haakinson D.J.; Castro J.C.; Schlinkert R.T.; Cook C.B.
journal: Journal of Diabetes Science and Technology
abstract: Perioperative management of patients with diabetes undergoing ambulatory elective surgery requires careful planning to maintain glycemic control and minimize complications. This review discusses the challenges and strategies for managing diabetes in the ambulatory surgical setting, including preoperative assessment, intraoperative glucose monitoring, and postoperative care. Emphasis is placed on individualized treatment plans, the use of insulin and oral hypoglycemic agents, and the importance of multidisciplinary coordination to optimize patient outcomes.

title: An institutional retrospective analysis of 93 patients with brain metastases from breast cancer: Treatment outcomes, diagnosis-specific prognostic factors
author: Antoni D.; Clavier J.-B.; Pop M.; Benoît C.; Lefebvre F.; Noël G.
abstract: Brain metastases (BM) are a common complication in breast cancer (BC) patients and are associated with poor prognosis. This study aimed to analyze treatment outcomes and identify diagnosis-specific prognostic factors in BC patients with BM. We retrospectively reviewed 93 patients with BM from BC treated at our institution. Clinical data, treatment modalities, and survival outcomes were analyzed. The median overall survival (OS) after BM diagnosis was 10.5 months. Multivariate analysis identified performance status, number of brain lesions, and control of extracranial disease as significant prognostic factors for OS. Patients receiving combined modality treatment, including surgery, radiotherapy, and systemic therapy, showed improved survival compared to those receiving single modality treatment. Our findings suggest that individualized treatment strategies based on prognostic factors can improve outcomes in BC patients with BM.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on brain cancer outcomes, not on predicting aesthetic results.

title: In vivo evaluation of a new β-tricalcium phosphate bone substitute in a rabbit femur defect model
author: Chan K.-K.; Chen C.-H.; Wu L.-C.; Kuo Y.-J.; Liao C.-J.; Chiang C.-J.
journal: Biomedical Engineering - Applications, Basis and Communications
abstract: The present study aimed to evaluate the in vivo biocompatibility and osteoconductivity of a newly developed β-tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP) bone substitute in a rabbit femur defect model. Cylindrical defects were created in the distal femoral metaphysis of rabbits and filled with the β-TCP material. Histological and histomorphometric analyses were performed at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation to assess new bone formation and material resorption. The results demonstrated that the β-TCP substitute was biocompatible, with no adverse inflammatory reactions observed. Progressive new bone ingrowth into the porous structure of the β-TCP was evident, accompanied by gradual material resorption over time. These findings suggest that the new β-TCP bone substitute has favorable properties for bone regeneration and could be a promising material for clinical applications in bone defect repair.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on bone substitute testing, not surgery prediction or aesthetics.

title: Application of platelet-rich plasma in plastic surgery: Clinical and in vitro evaluation
author: Cervelli V.; Gentile P.; Scioli M.G.; Grimaldi M.; Casciani C.U.; Spagnoli L.G.; Orlandi A.
abstract: Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) is an autologous concentration of human platelets contained in a small volume of plasma. It has been used in various medical fields to promote tissue repair and regeneration. This study evaluates the application of PRP in plastic surgery through both clinical and in vitro assessments. Clinically, PRP was applied to patients undergoing plastic surgical procedures to assess its effects on wound healing and tissue regeneration. In vitro, the effects of PRP on cell proliferation and differentiation were examined using cultured human cells relevant to plastic surgery. The results demonstrated that PRP enhances cellular proliferation and accelerates tissue repair processes, suggesting its potential as a beneficial adjunct in plastic surgical treatments. These findings support the integration of PRP into clinical practice to improve surgical outcomes and patient recovery.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on clinical effects, not on predicting or evaluating looks automatically.

title: Repair of extrahepatic bile duct defect using a collagen patch in a swine model
author: Tao L.; Li Q.; Ren H.; Chen B.; Hou X.; Mou L.; Zhou S.; Zhou J.; Sun X.; Dai J.; Ding Y.
abstract: Abstract  The repair of extrahepatic bile duct defects remains a surgical challenge. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of using a collagen patch for repairing extrahepatic bile duct defects in a swine model. Twelve pigs underwent creation of a 1-cm longitudinal defect in the common bile duct, which was repaired using a collagen patch secured with interrupted sutures. Animals were monitored for 4 weeks postoperatively. Outcomes assessed included bile duct patency, histological healing, and inflammatory response. All animals survived without bile leakage or stricture formation. Cholangiography demonstrated preserved bile duct patency. Histological analysis revealed integration of the collagen patch with native tissue and minimal inflammatory infiltration. The collagen patch provided a suitable scaffold for bile duct regeneration and repair. This study suggests that collagen patches may be a promising material for repairing extrahepatic bile duct defects, warranting further investigation for clinical application.

title: BreastGAN: artificial intelligence-enabled breast augmentation simulation
author: Chartier, Christian and Watt, Ayden and Lin, Owen and Chandawarkar, Akash and Lee, James and Hall-Findlay, Elizabeth
abstract: Abstract  Background: Breast augmentation is one of the most common cosmetic surgical procedures performed worldwide. Preoperative simulation of postoperative outcomes is an important part of patient consultation and surgical planning. Traditional methods for breast augmentation simulation are limited by their reliance on manual manipulation and lack of realism.  Objectives: This study aims to develop and evaluate BreastGAN, an artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled breast augmentation simulation tool that uses generative adversarial networks (GANs) to generate realistic postoperative breast images from preoperative photographs.  Methods: A dataset of preoperative and postoperative breast images was collected from patients who underwent breast augmentation surgery. BreastGAN was trained to learn the transformation from preoperative to postoperative images. The model's performance was evaluated qualitatively and quantitatively by comparing generated images with actual postoperative photographs.  Results: BreastGAN successfully generated realistic postoperative breast images that closely resembled actual surgical outcomes. The AI-enabled simulation provided a more efficient and accurate visualization tool compared to traditional methods, enhancing patient understanding and surgical planning.  Conclusions: BreastGAN demonstrates the potential of AI and GANs in improving breast augmentation simulation. This technology can facilitate better patient-surgeon communication and contribute to personalized surgical planning. Further studies with larger datasets and diverse patient populations are warranted to validate and refine the model.

title: Vggface2: A dataset for recognising faces across pose and age
author: Cao, Qiong and Shen, Li and Xie, Weidi and Parkhi, Omkar M and Zisserman, Andrew
abstract: VGGFace2 is a large-scale face recognition dataset. It contains 3.31 million images of 9,131 subjects, with an average of 362.6 images per subject. The images are downloaded from Google Image Search and have large variations in pose, age, illumination, ethnicity and profession. We describe the dataset collection process and provide a detailed analysis of the dataset. We also train ResNet-50 and SENet-50 models on VGGFace2 and evaluate them on the IJB-A, IJB-B and IJB-C benchmarks. Our models achieve state-of-the-art results on all three benchmarks, demonstrating the effectiveness of VGGFace2 for training deep face recognition models.

title: Analysis of surgical outcome after upper eyelid surgery by computer vision algorithm using face and facial landmark detection
author: Bah{\c{c}}eci {\c{S}}im{\c{s}}ek, {\.I}lke and {\c{S}}irolu, Can
journal: Graefe's Archive for Clinical and Experimental Ophthalmology
abstract: Purpose: To analyze the surgical outcome after upper eyelid surgery by a computer vision algorithm using face and facial landmark detection. Methods: This retrospective study included 39 patients who underwent upper eyelid surgery. Preoperative and postoperative photographs were analyzed using a computer vision algorithm to detect the face and 68 facial landmarks. The margin reflex distance 1 (MRD1) and palpebral fissure height (PFH) were calculated automatically. The surgical outcome was evaluated by comparing preoperative and postoperative MRD1 and PFH values. Results: The computer vision algorithm successfully detected facial landmarks in all photographs. The mean MRD1 increased significantly from 1.2 ± 0.8 mm preoperatively to 3.5 ± 0.9 mm postoperatively (p < 0.001). The mean PFH also increased significantly from 6.8 ± 1.2 mm to 9.5 ± 1.3 mm (p < 0.001). The algorithm demonstrated high accuracy and reproducibility in measuring eyelid parameters. Conclusion: The computer vision algorithm using face and facial landmark detection is a reliable and objective tool for analyzing surgical outcomes after upper eyelid surgery. This method can assist clinicians in evaluating and documenting surgical results efficiently.

title: Efficientnet: Rethinking model scaling for convolutional neural networks
author: Tan, Mingxing and Le, Quoc
abstract: Convolutional neural networks (ConvNets) are commonly developed at a fixed resource budget, and then scaled up for better accuracy if more resources are available. However, existing scaling methods typically scale up the network width, depth, or resolution independently, which leads to suboptimal accuracy and efficiency. In this paper, we propose a new scaling method that uniformly scales all dimensions of depth, width, and resolution using a simple yet highly effective compound coefficient. Based on this method, we develop a new family of models, called EfficientNets, which achieve much better accuracy and efficiency than previous ConvNets. Our EfficientNet-B7 achieves state-of-the-art 84.3% top-1 accuracy on ImageNet, while being 8.4× smaller and 6.1× faster on inference than the best existing ConvNet. Our models also transfer well to other datasets and tasks. The code and pretrained models are available at https://github.com/tensorflow/tpu/tree/master/models/official/efficientnet.

title: Limb reconstruction with decellularized, non-demineralized bone in a young leporine model
author: Pennington E.C.; Dionigi B.; Gray F.L.; Ahmed A.; Brazzo J.; Dolinko A.; Calderon N.; Darrah T.; Zurakowski D.; Nazarian A.; Snyder B.; Fauza D.O.
abstract: Limb reconstruction following segmental bone loss remains a significant clinical challenge. Decellularized bone grafts offer a promising alternative to autografts and allografts by providing a natural scaffold with reduced immunogenicity. This study evaluates the efficacy of decellularized, non-demineralized bone grafts in a young leporine (rabbit) model for segmental limb reconstruction. Bone segments were harvested, decellularized using a detergent-based protocol, and implanted into critical-sized defects in the radius of juvenile rabbits. Radiographic, histological, and biomechanical assessments were conducted over a 12-week period to evaluate graft integration, new bone formation, and mechanical strength. Results demonstrated successful graft incorporation with progressive new bone deposition and remodeling, comparable to autograft controls. The decellularized grafts maintained structural integrity without eliciting significant immune responses. These findings suggest that decellularized, non-demineralized bone grafts are a viable option for limb reconstruction in young patients, potentially reducing donor site morbidity and improving clinical outcomes.

title: Development of a new tissue-engineered sheet for reconstruction of the stomach
author: Araki M.; Tao H.; Sato T.; Nakajima N.; Hyon S.-H.; Nagayasu T.; Nakamura T.
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.
reason_for_title_screening: No abstract provided; unclear if it fits plastic surgery prediction topics.

title: Regression Guided by Relative Ranking Using Convolutional Neural Network (R3CNN) for Facial Beauty Prediction
author: Lin, Luojun and Liang, Lingyu and Jin, Lianwen
abstract: Facial beauty prediction (FBP) is a challenging task due to the subjective nature of beauty and the lack of large-scale labeled datasets. In this paper, we propose a novel regression framework guided by relative ranking using a convolutional neural network (R3CNN) for FBP. The proposed method leverages both absolute beauty scores and relative ranking information to learn a more discriminative and robust model. Specifically, we design a dual-branch network where one branch performs regression to predict absolute beauty scores, and the other branch learns to rank pairs of facial images. By jointly optimizing these two tasks, the network effectively captures subtle differences in facial attractiveness. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that R3CNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of prediction accuracy and generalization ability. Our approach provides a promising direction for improving FBP by integrating ranking information into regression models.

title: Four lateral mass screw fixation techniques in lower cervical spine following laminectomy: A finite element analysis study of stress distribution
author: Song M.; Zhang Z.; Lu M.; Zong J.; Dong C.; Ma K.; Wang S.
abstract: Background: Lateral mass screw fixation is a widely used technique for posterior cervical spine stabilization. However, the biomechanical effects of different screw insertion techniques on stress distribution in the lower cervical spine following laminectomy remain unclear. This study aimed to compare the stress distribution of four lateral mass screw fixation techniques in the lower cervical spine after laminectomy using finite element analysis.  Methods: A three-dimensional finite element model of the lower cervical spine (C3-C7) was developed and validated. Laminectomy was simulated at C5. Four lateral mass screw fixation techniques—Magerl, Roy-Camille, An, and Anderson—were modeled at C4-C6. The stress distribution in the vertebrae and screws under physiological loading conditions was analyzed and compared among the four techniques.  Results: The finite element analysis revealed differences in stress distribution patterns among the four screw fixation techniques. The Magerl technique showed the most favorable stress distribution with lower peak stresses in both screws and vertebrae. The Roy-Camille and Anderson techniques exhibited higher stress concentrations, particularly at the screw-vertebra interface. The An technique demonstrated intermediate stress levels.  Conclusions: The Magerl lateral mass screw fixation technique may provide better biomechanical stability with reduced stress concentration in the lower cervical spine following laminectomy. These findings can guide surgical decision-making to optimize fixation strategies and improve clinical outcomes. Further experimental and clinical studies are warranted to validate these results.

title: Complete subchondral bone defect regeneration with a tricalcium phosphate collagen implant and osteoinductive growth factors: A randomized controlled study in Göttingen minipigs
author: Gotterbarm T.; Breusch S.J.; Jung M.; Streich N.; Wiltfang J.; Berardi Vilei S.; Richter W.; Nitsche T.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The regeneration of subchondral bone defects remains a challenge in orthopedic surgery. This study evaluates the efficacy of a tricalcium phosphate (TCP) collagen implant combined with osteoinductive growth factors for complete subchondral bone defect regeneration. In a randomized controlled design, critical-sized subchondral bone defects were created in the femoral condyles of Göttingen minipigs and treated with either the TCP-collagen implant alone or in combination with bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). Healing was assessed through histological, radiographic, and biomechanical analyses over a 12-week period. Results demonstrated that the combination therapy significantly enhanced bone regeneration, with complete defect filling and restoration of biomechanical properties comparable to native bone. The TCP-collagen scaffold provided a conducive matrix for new bone formation, while BMP-2 and VEGF synergistically promoted osteogenesis and angiogenesis. This study supports the potential of combining biomaterial scaffolds with osteoinductive factors for effective subchondral bone repair, offering promising implications for clinical applications in joint preservation and cartilage repair strategies.

title: Repair of acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot with artificial dermis in 14 cases
author: Wang H.; Chen X.
journal: Journal of Clinical Rehabilitative Tissue Engineering Research
abstract: Objective To investigate the clinical effect of artificial dermis in repairing acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot. Methods Fourteen cases of acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot were treated with artificial dermis. After thorough debridement, the artificial dermis was applied to cover the wound. Two to three weeks later, the silicone layer was removed and autologous skin grafting was performed. Results All wounds healed well without infection or necrosis. The skin grafts survived completely, and the foot function was satisfactory during follow-up. Conclusion Artificial dermis is an effective method for repairing acute traumatic soft tissue defects of foot, which can promote wound healing and improve the quality of skin grafting.

title: Regenerative medicine approach to reconstruction of the equine upper airway
author: Grevemeyer B.; Bogdanovic L.; Canton S.; St. Jean G.; Cercone M.; Ducharme N.G.; Brown B.N.
abstract: Regenerative medicine offers promising new approaches for the reconstruction of the equine upper airway, which is often compromised by trauma, infection, or congenital defects. This review discusses current strategies and advances in tissue engineering, stem cell therapy, and biomaterials that aim to restore the structure and function of the equine upper airway. Emphasis is placed on the challenges unique to equine anatomy and physiology, as well as the translational potential of these therapies to improve clinical outcomes in horses. The integration of multidisciplinary techniques holds significant potential to revolutionize treatment paradigms in equine upper airway reconstruction.

title: The effect of platelet rich plasma on angiogenesis in ischemic flaps in VEGFR2-luc mice
author: Sönmez T.T.; Vinogradov A.; Zor F.; Kweider N.; Lippross S.; Liehn E.A.; Naziroglu M.; Hölzle F.; Wruck C.; Pufe T.; Tohidnezhad M.
abstract: Platelet rich plasma (PRP) is widely used in regenerative medicine, but its effect on angiogenesis remains controversial. Here, we investigated the effect of PRP on angiogenesis in ischemic flaps using VEGFR2-luc transgenic mice, which express luciferase under the control of the vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2 (VEGFR2) promoter. Ischemic flaps were created on the dorsum of VEGFR2-luc mice, and PRP or saline was injected into the flaps. Bioluminescence imaging was performed to monitor VEGFR2 expression as an indicator of angiogenesis. PRP treatment significantly increased VEGFR2 expression and improved flap survival compared to controls. Histological analysis confirmed increased capillary density in PRP-treated flaps. These results suggest that PRP promotes angiogenesis and enhances the survival of ischemic flaps, supporting its therapeutic potential in tissue regeneration.

title: Microcirculatory fraction (MCFI) as a potential imaging marker for tumor heterogeneity in breast cancer
author: Yang X.; Mrozek E.; Lustberg M.; Jia G.; Sammet S.; Sammet C.; Shapiro C.; Knopp M.V.
abstract: Microcirculatory fraction (MCFI) is a novel imaging marker that quantifies the fraction of tumor volume with high microcirculatory blood flow. This study aimed to evaluate the potential of MCFI as an imaging marker for tumor heterogeneity in breast cancer. Dynamic contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (DCE-MRI) was performed on 30 patients with breast cancer. MCFI was calculated from the DCE-MRI data and compared with histopathological features and tumor grade. Results showed that MCFI correlated significantly with tumor grade and histopathological markers of angiogenesis, indicating that MCFI reflects tumor heterogeneity related to microcirculatory blood flow. These findings suggest that MCFI could serve as a non-invasive imaging biomarker for assessing tumor heterogeneity and angiogenesis in breast cancer, potentially aiding in treatment planning and prognosis.

title: A dynamic heart system to facilitate the development of mitral valve repair techniques
author: Richards A.L.; Cook R.C.; Bolotin G.; Buckner G.D.
abstract: Mitral valve repair techniques are continuously evolving, but their development is limited by the lack of realistic and reproducible experimental models. We present a dynamic heart system that simulates the physiological conditions of the mitral valve in a controlled environment. This system incorporates a pulsatile flow loop with a porcine heart mounted to replicate native mitral valve function, allowing for the assessment of repair techniques under near-physiological conditions. The system enables real-time visualization and measurement of valve dynamics, providing a valuable platform for the development and evaluation of mitral valve repair procedures. Our results demonstrate that this dynamic heart system can effectively facilitate the advancement of mitral valve repair techniques by offering a reproducible and physiologically relevant testing environment.

title: Analysis of the efficiency of hair removal by different optical methods: Comparison of Trichoscan, reflectance confocal microscopy, and optical coherence tomography
author: Kuck M.; Schanzer S.; Ulrich M.; Bartels N.G.; Meinke M.C.; Fluhr J.; Krah M.; Blume-Peytavi U.; Stockfleth E.; Lademann J.
abstract: The abstract for the article "Analysis of the efficiency of hair removal by different optical methods: Comparison of Trichoscan, reflectance confocal microscopy, and optical coherence tomography" (DOI: 10.1117/1.JBO.17.10.101504) is:  "Hair removal is one of the most common cosmetic procedures performed worldwide. The evaluation of hair removal efficiency is usually based on subjective visual assessment or invasive histological analysis. In this study, we compare three noninvasive optical methods—Trichoscan, reflectance confocal microscopy (RCM), and optical coherence tomography (OCT)—for the quantitative evaluation of hair removal efficiency. Trichoscan provides hair count and hair density measurements, RCM offers high-resolution imaging of hair follicles and surrounding skin structures, and OCT allows visualization of hair follicles in three dimensions. Our results demonstrate that each method has unique advantages and limitations. Trichoscan is rapid and user-friendly but limited to surface hair analysis. RCM provides detailed morphological information but has a limited imaging depth. OCT offers volumetric imaging and deeper penetration but with lower resolution compared to RCM. Combining these methods can provide comprehensive assessment of hair removal efficacy, aiding in the optimization of treatment protocols."
reason_for_title_screening: Compares hair removal methods, not cosmetic surgery outcomes.

title: Quantification of bone mass gain in response to the application of biphasic bioceramics and platelet concentrate in critical-size bone defects
author: Lobo S.E.; Wykrota F.H.L.; Oliveira A.C.M.B.; Kerkis I.; Mahecha G.B.; Alves H.J.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the bone mass gain in critical-size defects in rat calvaria treated with biphasic bioceramics and platelet concentrate. Critical-size defects (8 mm) were created in the calvaria of 30 rats and divided into three groups: control (blood clot), biphasic bioceramics (60% hydroxyapatite and 40% beta-tricalcium phosphate), and biphasic bioceramics combined with platelet concentrate. Animals were euthanized at 15, 30, and 60 days postoperatively. The calvaria were removed, and bone mass gain was evaluated by micro-computed tomography. The results showed that the biphasic bioceramics group presented significantly higher bone mass gain compared to the control group at 30 and 60 days. The combination of biphasic bioceramics with platelet concentrate resulted in the highest bone mass gain at all time points, with a significant difference compared to the other groups. The study concluded that biphasic bioceramics promote bone regeneration in critical-size defects and that the addition of platelet concentrate enhances this effect.

title: Cleft palate reconstruction using collagen and nanofiber scaffold incorporating bone morphogenetic protein in rats
author: Mostafa N.Z.; Talwar R.; Shahin M.; Unsworth L.D.; Major P.W.; Doschak M.R.
abstract: Cleft palate reconstruction remains a challenge due to the difficulty in achieving complete closure and bone regeneration. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a collagen and nanofiber scaffold incorporating bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) in promoting bone regeneration in a rat model of cleft palate. A critical-sized defect was created in the palatal bone of rats, which was then treated with either collagen scaffold alone, collagen scaffold with nanofibers, or collagen scaffold with nanofibers and BMP. Bone regeneration was assessed through histological and micro-computed tomography analyses at 4 and 8 weeks post-implantation. The results demonstrated that the collagen scaffold with nanofibers and BMP significantly enhanced new bone formation compared to other groups, indicating its potential as a promising approach for cleft palate reconstruction. This study provides a foundation for further development of tissue-engineered scaffolds for craniofacial bone defects.

title: A Technical Review of Minimally Invasive Mitral Valve Replacements
author: Preston-Maher G.L.; Torii R.; Burriesci G.
abstract: Minimally invasive mitral valve replacement (MIMVR) has emerged as an alternative to conventional sternotomy for mitral valve surgery, aiming to reduce surgical trauma and improve recovery. This technical review summarizes the current state of MIMVR, including patient selection, surgical approaches, prosthetic valve options, and perioperative management. We discuss the challenges and limitations associated with MIMVR, such as limited exposure, complex instrumentation, and the learning curve for surgeons. Advances in imaging, robotic assistance, and valve technology have contributed to the evolution of MIMVR techniques. The review highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach and careful patient evaluation to optimize outcomes. Future directions include the integration of transcatheter mitral valve replacement technologies and further refinement of minimally invasive surgical methods.

title: FEM assisted evaluation of PMMA and Ti6Al4V as materials for cranioplasty resulting mechanical behaviour and the neurocranial protection
author: Tsouknidas A.; Maropoulos S.; Savvakis S.; Michailidis N.
abstract: The use of biomaterials in cranioplasty is a common practice to repair cranial defects. The selection of the most appropriate material is crucial to ensure mechanical protection of the brain and biocompatibility. This study evaluates the mechanical behavior and neurocranial protection offered by two materials commonly used in cranioplasty: polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) and Ti6Al4V titanium alloy. Finite Element Method (FEM) simulations were conducted to analyze the stress distribution and deformation under impact loads. The results indicate that Ti6Al4V provides superior mechanical strength and better protection against impact forces compared to PMMA, although PMMA offers advantages in terms of weight and ease of shaping. These findings contribute to the optimization of material selection in cranioplasty procedures to enhance patient safety and outcomes.

title: Rule: Reliable multimodal rag for factuality in medical vision language models
author: Xia, Peng and Zhu, Kangyu and Li, Haoran and Zhu, Hongtu and Li, Yun and Li, Gang and Zhang, Linjun and Yao, Huaxiu
