title: Effectiveness of surgical reconstruction to restore radiocarpal joint mechanics after scapholunate ligament injury: An in vivo modeling study
author: Johnson J.E.; Lee P.; McIff T.E.; Toby E.B.; Fischer K.J.
abstract: The scapholunate interosseous ligament (SLIL) is the primary stabilizer of the scapholunate joint, and its injury leads to altered carpal kinematics and eventual wrist arthritis. Surgical reconstruction aims to restore normal joint mechanics, but its effectiveness remains unclear. This study uses in vivo modeling to evaluate the biomechanical outcomes of surgical reconstruction on radiocarpal joint mechanics following SLIL injury. Using subject-specific wrist models derived from imaging data, we simulated the effects of SLIL injury and subsequent surgical reconstruction on carpal bone motion and joint contact mechanics during wrist motion. Results indicate that surgical reconstruction partially restores normal kinematics and contact mechanics but does not fully replicate the intact joint's behavior. These findings provide insight into the biomechanical efficacy of current surgical techniques and may guide improvements in treatment strategies for SLIL injuries.

title: Biomechanical testing procedures in tendon graft reconstructive ACL surgery
author: Chizari M.; Wang B.; Barrett M.; Snow M.
journal: Biomedical Engineering - Applications, Basis and Communications
abstract: Biomechanical testing procedures in tendon graft reconstructive ACL surgery have been widely used to evaluate the mechanical properties of grafts and fixation devices. This review summarizes the current methodologies employed in biomechanical testing, including tensile testing, cyclic loading, and failure testing, highlighting their relevance in assessing graft strength, stiffness, and durability. The article discusses the importance of standardized testing protocols to ensure reproducibility and comparability of results across studies. Additionally, it addresses the challenges in simulating physiological conditions and the implications of biomechanical findings for clinical practice in anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

title: Rapidly constructed scaffold-free cornea epithelial sheets for ocular surface reconstruction
author: Zhang W.; Xiao J.; Li C.; Wan P.; Liu Y.; Wu Z.; Huang M.; Wang X.; Wang Z.
abstract: Corneal epithelial sheets are widely used for ocular surface reconstruction. However, the current methods for fabricating these sheets are time-consuming and require the use of scaffolds, which may cause immune reactions and other complications. In this study, we developed a rapid and scaffold-free method to construct corneal epithelial sheets using temperature-responsive culture dishes. Human limbal epithelial cells were cultured on these dishes and harvested as intact sheets by reducing the temperature. The resulting sheets maintained cell-cell junctions and extracellular matrix components, exhibited high viability, and expressed corneal epithelial markers. In vivo transplantation of these sheets onto rabbit corneal surfaces with epithelial defects demonstrated successful epithelialization and restoration of corneal transparency without significant inflammation or neovascularization. This scaffold-free approach offers a promising strategy for rapid and safe ocular surface reconstruction.

title: Machine learning, deep learning, artificial intelligence and aesthetic plastic surgery: a qualitative systematic review
author: Nogueira, Raquel and Eguchi, Marina and Kasmirski, Julia and de Lima, Bruno Veronez and Dimatos, Dimitri Cardoso and Lima, Diego L and Glatter, Robert and Tran, David L and Piccinini, Pedro Salomao
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and deep learning (DL) are rapidly evolving fields that have the potential to revolutionize aesthetic plastic surgery. This qualitative systematic review aims to synthesize current evidence on the applications, benefits, and challenges of AI, ML, and DL in aesthetic plastic surgery. A comprehensive literature search was conducted across multiple databases to identify relevant studies. The findings highlight the use of AI-driven tools for preoperative planning, outcome prediction, patient selection, and postoperative monitoring. Despite promising results, challenges such as data privacy, algorithm transparency, and the need for large, high-quality datasets remain. The integration of AI technologies in aesthetic plastic surgery holds significant promise for enhancing surgical precision, patient satisfaction, and clinical outcomes, but further research and ethical considerations are essential for their safe and effective implementation.

title: Evaluation of gel spun silk-based biomaterials in a murine model of bladder augmentation
author: Mauney J.R.; Cannon G.M.; Lovett M.L.; Gong E.M.; Di Vizio D.; Gomez P.; Kaplan D.L.; Adam R.M.; Estrada C.R.
abstract: Bladder augmentation is a surgical procedure used to increase bladder capacity and reduce bladder pressure in patients with congenital or acquired bladder diseases. Current clinical approaches use gastrointestinal segments for bladder reconstruction, but these are associated with significant complications. Tissue engineering offers a promising alternative, and silk fibroin-based biomaterials have shown potential due to their biocompatibility and mechanical properties. In this study, we evaluated gel spun silk-based scaffolds for bladder augmentation in a murine model. The scaffolds were implanted into bladder defects, and tissue regeneration was assessed over time. Histological and immunohistochemical analyses demonstrated the formation of smooth muscle and urothelial layers, as well as neovascularization within the scaffold. Functional assessments indicated improved bladder capacity and compliance. These findings suggest that gel spun silk-based biomaterials support bladder tissue regeneration and may serve as a viable scaffold for bladder augmentation.

title: Keratin films for ocular surface reconstruction: Evaluation of biocompatibility in an in-vivo model
author: Borrelli M.; Joepen N.; Reichl S.; Finis D.; Schoppe M.; Geerling G.; Schrader S.
abstract: The development of biomaterials for ocular surface reconstruction is a challenging task due to the complex structure and function of the cornea. In this study, we evaluated the biocompatibility of keratin films derived from human hair as a potential scaffold for ocular surface reconstruction. Keratin films were fabricated and characterized for their physical and chemical properties. In vivo biocompatibility was assessed by implanting the films onto the ocular surface of a rabbit model. Clinical observations, histological analysis, and immunohistochemical staining were performed to evaluate the inflammatory response, epithelialization, and integration of the films with the host tissue. The results demonstrated that keratin films were well tolerated, promoted epithelial cell adhesion and proliferation, and supported corneal tissue regeneration without eliciting significant inflammation. These findings suggest that keratin films have promising potential as a biocompatible scaffold for ocular surface reconstruction applications.

title: Immunocompatibility evaluation of hydrogel-coated polyimide implants for applications in regenerative medicine
author: Sirova M.; Vlierberghe S.V.; Matyasova V.; Rossmann P.; Schacht E.; Dubruel P.; Rihova B.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Hydrogel coatings have been widely used to improve the biocompatibility of implantable devices. In this study, we evaluated the immunocompatibility of hydrogel-coated polyimide (PI) implants for applications in regenerative medicine. PI films were coated with a poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG)-based hydrogel using a photopolymerization method. The surface properties of the coated films were characterized by water contact angle measurements and scanning electron microscopy. In vitro cytotoxicity and cell adhesion assays were performed using fibroblasts and macrophages. The inflammatory response was assessed by measuring cytokine secretion and macrophage activation markers. Our results demonstrated that the hydrogel coating significantly reduced protein adsorption and cell adhesion compared to uncoated PI. Moreover, the hydrogel-coated PI showed decreased macrophage activation and pro-inflammatory cytokine production, indicating improved immunocompatibility. These findings suggest that PEG-based hydrogel coatings on PI implants can enhance their biocompatibility and may be beneficial for regenerative medicine applications.

title: Plastic surgery: A new dimension to face recognition
author: Singh, Richa and Vatsa, Mayank and Bhatt, Himanshu S and Bharadwaj, Samarth and Noore, Afzel and Nooreyezdan, Shahin S
journal: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Plastic surgery is becoming increasingly popular and has a significant impact on face recognition systems. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the effects of various plastic surgery procedures on face recognition performance. We analyze the challenges posed by surgical alterations and propose a novel approach to improve recognition accuracy in the presence of such changes. Experimental results on a newly created plastic surgery face database demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, highlighting the need for developing robust face recognition algorithms that can handle post-surgical facial variations.

title: A method for assessing 3D shape variations of fuzzy regions and its application on human bony orbits
author: Noser H.; Hammer B.; Kamer L.
abstract: This paper presents a method for assessing three-dimensional (3D) shape variations of fuzzy regions and applies it to human bony orbits. The method involves representing fuzzy regions by fuzzy membership functions and analyzing their shape variations using a fuzzy shape descriptor based on the concept of fuzzy moments. The approach allows for the quantification and comparison of shape differences in regions where boundaries are not sharply defined. The application to human bony orbits demonstrates the method's capability to capture subtle anatomical variations, which can be valuable in medical imaging and anthropological studies.

title: Kinetic evaluation study on the bioactivity of silver doped hydroxyapatite-polyvinyl alcohol nanocomposites
author: Mostafa A.A.; Oudadesse H.; El Sayed M.M.H.; Kamal G.; Kamel M.; Foad E.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: Silver doped hydroxyapatite-polyvinyl alcohol (Ag-HAp-PVA) nanocomposites were synthesized by a simple chemical precipitation method. The prepared nanocomposites were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The bioactivity of the nanocomposites was evaluated by immersing them in simulated body fluid (SBF) for different time intervals. The formation of apatite layer on the surface of the nanocomposites was confirmed by SEM and XRD analysis. The kinetic study of apatite formation was carried out by measuring the weight gain of the samples after immersion in SBF. The results showed that the incorporation of silver ions into hydroxyapatite enhanced the bioactivity and antibacterial properties of the nanocomposites. The kinetic evaluation indicated that the apatite formation followed a pseudo-second-order kinetic model, suggesting chemisorption as the rate-limiting step. These findings demonstrate the potential of Ag-HAp-PVA nanocomposites for biomedical applications such as bone tissue engineering and implant coatings.

title: Tensor-based subspace learning and its applications in multi-pose face synthesis
author: Qiao X.; Han X.-H.; Igarashi T.; Nakao K.; Chen Y.-W.
abstract: This paper presents a novel tensor-based subspace learning method for multi-pose face synthesis. Unlike traditional vector-based subspace learning methods, the proposed method directly operates on tensor objects, which can better preserve the intrinsic structure of multi-dimensional data. By exploiting the multilinear algebra framework, the method effectively captures the correlations among different modes of the tensor, leading to improved representation and synthesis of faces under varying poses. Experimental results on benchmark face databases demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves superior performance in multi-pose face synthesis compared to existing methods, showing its potential for applications in face recognition and computer vision.
reason_for_title_screening: Deals with face synthesis, not surgery outcomes.

title: Ag/SiOxCy plasma polymer coating for antimicrobial protection of fracture fixation devices
author: Khalilpour P.; Lampe K.; Wagener M.; Stigler B.; Heiss C.; Ullrich M.S.; Domann E.; Schnettler R.; Alt V.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The development of antimicrobial coatings for fracture fixation devices is crucial to prevent implant-associated infections. In this study, silver-containing silicon oxycarbide (Ag/SiOxCy) plasma polymer coatings were deposited on titanium substrates using plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) to provide antimicrobial protection. The coatings were characterized for their chemical composition, morphology, and silver release profile. Antimicrobial efficacy was evaluated against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli, demonstrating significant bacterial growth inhibition. Cytocompatibility tests with osteoblast-like cells indicated good biocompatibility of the coatings. The results suggest that Ag/SiOxCy plasma polymer coatings offer a promising strategy for enhancing the antimicrobial properties of fracture fixation devices while maintaining biocompatibility.

title: Further development of a tissue engineered muscle repair construct in vitro for enhanced functional recovery following implantation in vivo in a murine model of volumetric muscle loss injury
author: Corona B.T.; MacHingal M.A.; Criswell T.; Vadhavkar M.; Dannahower A.C.; Bergman C.; Zhao W.; Christ G.J.
abstract: Volumetric muscle loss (VML) injury results in a permanent functional deficit due to the loss of a critical mass of skeletal muscle and the inability of the remaining muscle to regenerate. Tissue engineering strategies to treat VML injuries have focused on the development of tissue engineered muscle repair (TEMR) constructs composed of muscle-derived cells seeded on three-dimensional (3D) scaffolds. We have previously demonstrated that TEMR constructs composed of muscle-derived cells seeded on bladder acellular matrix (BAM) scaffolds can be used to repair VML injuries in a murine model. In this study, we further developed the TEMR construct in vitro by incorporating a 3D collagen I hydrogel to enhance cell alignment and differentiation prior to implantation. The enhanced TEMR constructs exhibited improved myogenic differentiation and alignment in vitro. Following implantation into a murine VML injury model, the enhanced TEMR constructs demonstrated improved functional recovery compared to BAM-only and nonenhanced TEMR constructs. Histological analysis revealed increased muscle fiber regeneration and vascularization in the enhanced TEMR group. These findings suggest that the incorporation of a 3D collagen I hydrogel into TEMR constructs improves their regenerative potential and functional outcomes following VML injury.

title: Paradoxical uptake of Gd-EOB-DTPA on the hepatobiliary phase in the evaluation of hepatic metastasis from breast cancer: Is the "target sign" a common finding?
author: Ha S.; Lee C.H.; Kim B.H.; Park Y.S.; Lee J.; Choi J.W.; Kim K.A.; Park C.M.
abstract: The hepatobiliary phase of gadoxetic acid (Gd-EOB-DTPA)-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is useful for detecting hepatic metastases. However, paradoxical uptake of Gd-EOB-DTPA in hepatic metastases from breast cancer has been reported, which may cause diagnostic confusion. This study aimed to evaluate the frequency and imaging features of paradoxical uptake, particularly the "target sign," in hepatic metastases from breast cancer. We retrospectively reviewed Gd-EOB-DTPA-enhanced MRI scans of 30 patients with hepatic metastases from breast cancer. The presence of paradoxical uptake and the "target sign" on hepatobiliary phase images were assessed. Paradoxical uptake was observed in 40% of patients, and the "target sign" was identified in 30% of cases. These findings suggest that paradoxical uptake and the "target sign" are relatively common in hepatic metastases from breast cancer and should be recognized to avoid misdiagnosis.

title: Study on injectable and degradable cement of calcium sulphate and calcium phosphate for bone repair
author: Hu G.; Xiao L.; Fu H.; Bi D.; Ma H.; Tong P.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Injectable and degradable calcium sulphate/calcium phosphate (CS/CP) composite cements were prepared by mixing calcium sulphate hemihydrate and calcium phosphate powders with a sodium phosphate solution. The setting time, compressive strength, and degradation behavior of the cements were investigated. The results showed that the setting time of the cements could be controlled by adjusting the ratio of calcium sulphate to calcium phosphate. The compressive strength of the cements increased with the increase of calcium phosphate content. The degradation rate of the cements in vitro was dependent on the composition, with higher calcium sulphate content leading to faster degradation. The composite cements exhibited good biocompatibility and osteoconductivity in vivo, promoting new bone formation in rabbit femoral defects. These findings suggest that the injectable and degradable CS/CP composite cements have potential applications in bone repair.

title: Fractional skin harvesting: Device operational principles and deployment evaluation
author: Franco W.; Jimenez-Lozano J.N.; Tam J.; Purschke M.; Wang Y.; Sakamoto F.H.; Farinelli W.A.; Doukas A.G.; Rox Anderson R.
journal: Journal of Medical Devices, Transactions of the ASME
abstract: Fractional skin harvesting (FSH) is a novel technique for harvesting skin microcolumns for wound healing and skin regeneration. This paper presents the operational principles of a device designed for FSH and evaluates its deployment performance. The device utilizes a microarray of hollow needles to extract skin microcolumns with minimal donor site morbidity. The study includes mechanical characterization of the device, assessment of the harvested microcolumns' viability, and evaluation of the healing response in an animal model. Results demonstrate that the device can reliably harvest viable skin microcolumns, and the donor sites exhibit rapid healing with minimal scarring. These findings support the potential of FSH as a minimally invasive method for skin grafting applications.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on device design, not on predicting or assessing surgical aesthetics.

title: MRI-based breast volumetry-evaluation of three different software solutions
author: Herold C.; Reichelt A.; Stieglitz L.H.; Dettmer S.; Knobloch K.; Lotz J.; Vogt P.M.
abstract: Breast volume is an important parameter in breast surgery. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a promising technique for breast volumetry. The aim of this study was to evaluate three different software solutions for MRI-based breast volumetry. Twenty patients underwent breast MRI. Breast volumes were calculated using three different software programs: (1) a manual segmentation tool, (2) a semiautomatic segmentation tool, and (3) a fully automatic segmentation tool. The results were compared with the actual resection weights in patients undergoing breast reduction surgery. The manual and semiautomatic methods showed good correlation with the resection weights (r = 0.95 and r = 0.93, respectively), whereas the fully automatic method showed a lower correlation (r = 0.78). The manual method was the most time-consuming, while the fully automatic method was the fastest. In conclusion, MRI-based breast volumetry is feasible with all three software solutions, but manual and semiautomatic methods provide more accurate volume estimations compared to the fully automatic method.

title: In vitro and in vivo evaluation of poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)/ poly(styrene sulfonate)/dopamine-coated electrodes for dopamine delivery
author: Sui L.; Song X.J.; Ren J.; Cai W.J.; Ju L.H.; Wang Y.; Wang L.Y.; Chen M.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The development of implantable electrodes capable of delivering neurotransmitters locally is a promising approach for treating neurological disorders. In this study, we report the fabrication and characterization of poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)/poly(styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT/PSS) electrodes coated with dopamine (DA) for controlled dopamine delivery. The electrodes were evaluated in vitro for their electrochemical properties, dopamine release profiles, and biocompatibility. In vivo studies were conducted to assess the electrodes' performance in delivering dopamine in a rat model. The PEDOT/PSS/DA-coated electrodes exhibited enhanced electrochemical stability, sustained dopamine release, and reduced inflammatory response compared to uncoated electrodes. These findings suggest that PEDOT/PSS/DA-coated electrodes hold potential for therapeutic applications requiring localized dopamine delivery.

title: Data-based prediction of soft tissue changes after orthognathic surgery: clinical assessment of new simulation software
author: Abe, N and Kuroda, S and Furutani, M and Tanaka, E
journal: International journal of oral and maxillofacial surgery
abstract: Accurate prediction of soft tissue changes after orthognathic surgery is essential for treatment planning and patient communication. This study aimed to clinically assess the accuracy of a new simulation software for predicting soft tissue changes following orthognathic surgery. Twenty patients undergoing bimaxillary surgery were included. Pre- and postoperative three-dimensional facial scans were obtained, and soft tissue changes were predicted using the software based on the planned skeletal movements. The predicted soft tissue outcomes were compared with the actual postoperative results using quantitative and qualitative analyses. The software demonstrated good accuracy in predicting soft tissue changes, particularly in the midface and lower face regions, with mean discrepancies within clinically acceptable limits. However, some limitations were noted in areas with complex soft tissue dynamics. The new simulation software shows promise as a valuable tool for surgical planning and patient education, though further refinement and validation are recommended.

title: Interobserver agreement and consensus over the esthetic evaluation of conservative treatment for breast cancer
author: Cardoso, Maria Joao and Cardoso, Jaime and Santos, Ana Cristina and Barros, Henrique and de Oliveira, Manuel Cardoso
abstract: Background: The esthetic outcome of breast-conserving treatment (BCT) is an important parameter in the evaluation of treatment results. However, the esthetic evaluation is subjective and may vary between observers. The aim of this study was to assess the interobserver agreement and consensus over the esthetic evaluation of BCT.  Methods: Thirty patients treated with BCT were evaluated by 10 observers (breast surgeons, radiation oncologists, and plastic surgeons). The esthetic outcome was scored on a 4-point scale (excellent, good, fair, poor) based on standardized photographs. Interobserver agreement was assessed using kappa statistics. Consensus was reached through a group discussion and re-evaluation.  Results: The overall interobserver agreement was moderate (kappa = 0.48). Agreement was higher among plastic surgeons (kappa = 0.56) compared to breast surgeons (kappa = 0.44) and radiation oncologists (kappa = 0.42). After consensus discussion, the agreement improved significantly (kappa = 0.68).  Conclusions: Esthetic evaluation of BCT shows moderate interobserver agreement, which can be improved by consensus discussions. Standardized evaluation protocols and training may enhance reliability in esthetic assessments.

title: Multi-kernel graph embedding for detection, Gleason grading of prostate cancer via MRI/MRS
author: Tiwari P.; Kurhanewicz J.; Madabhushi A.
abstract: Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men and the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) have shown promise for noninvasive detection and characterization of prostate cancer. However, the interpretation of MRI/MRS data is challenging due to the complex and heterogeneous nature of prostate cancer. In this paper, we propose a novel multi-kernel graph embedding (MKGE) framework for the detection and Gleason grading of prostate cancer using MRI/MRS data. The MKGE method integrates multiple kernels derived from different imaging modalities and incorporates the spatial relationships among voxels through graph embedding. This approach effectively captures the complementary information from MRI and MRS and the intrinsic geometric structure of the data. Experimental results on a clinical dataset demonstrate that the proposed MKGE method outperforms traditional single-kernel and feature-based methods in both cancer detection and Gleason grading, indicating its potential for improving prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment planning.

title: Reliability of a navigation system for intra-operative evaluation of antero-posterior knee joint laxity
author: Lopomo N.; Bignozzi S.; Martelli S.; Zaffagnini S.; Iacono F.; Visani A.; Marcacci M.
abstract: The evaluation of knee joint laxity is an important step in the diagnosis and treatment of knee injuries. The aim of this study was to assess the reliability of a navigation system for intra-operative evaluation of antero-posterior knee joint laxity. The system was tested on a knee phantom and on cadaveric knees. The intra- and inter-observer reliability was evaluated by measuring the anterior-posterior displacement under standardized loading conditions. The results showed high intra- and inter-observer reliability, with intraclass correlation coefficients above 0.9. The navigation system proved to be a reliable tool for intra-operative assessment of antero-posterior knee joint laxity, potentially aiding surgeons in decision-making during knee surgery.

title: Randomized trial evaluating intraoperative ultrasound guidance for palpable breast cancer excision

title: Differences in tibial rotation during walking in ACL reconstructed and healthy contralateral knees
author: Scanlan S.F.; Chaudhari A.M.W.; Dyrby C.O.; Andriacchi T.P.
abstract: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury is a common knee injury that often results in altered knee kinematics. This study aimed to investigate differences in tibial rotation during walking between ACL reconstructed knees and healthy contralateral knees. Using a three-dimensional motion analysis system, tibial rotation was measured in 20 subjects with unilateral ACL reconstruction during level walking. The results showed that the ACL reconstructed knees exhibited significantly greater internal tibial rotation during the stance phase of walking compared to the healthy contralateral knees. These findings suggest that ACL reconstruction may not fully restore normal tibial rotational kinematics during gait, which could have implications for joint loading and the development of osteoarthritis.

title: PtosisDiffusion: a training-free workflow for precisely predicting post-operative appearance in blepharoptosis patients based on diffusion models
author: Huang, Shenyu and Xie, Jiajun and Yang, Boyuan and Gao, Qi and Ye, Juan
journal: Frontiers in Cell and Developmental Biology
abstract: PtosisDiffusion is a training-free workflow designed to precisely predict post-operative appearance in blepharoptosis patients using diffusion models. This approach leverages the capabilities of diffusion models to generate high-fidelity images that simulate surgical outcomes without the need for extensive training data. By integrating clinical parameters and pre-operative images, PtosisDiffusion provides surgeons and patients with a reliable visualization tool to anticipate post-surgical results, thereby enhancing pre-operative planning and patient communication. The method demonstrates significant potential in improving surgical precision and patient satisfaction in blepharoptosis treatment.

title: In vivo evaluation of a new biphasic calcium phosphate bone substitute in rabbit femur defects model
author: Chen C.-H.; Chiang C.-J.; Rau G.; Huang M.-S.; Chan K.K.; Liao C.-J.; Kuo Y.-J.
journal: Biomedical Engineering - Applications, Basis and Communications
doi: World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte Ltd
abstract: The present study aimed to evaluate the in vivo performance of a new biphasic calcium phosphate (BCP) bone substitute composed of hydroxyapatite (HA) and β-tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP) in a rabbit femur defect model. Cylindrical defects were created in the femoral condyles of rabbits and filled with the BCP material. Histological and histomorphometric analyses were performed at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation to assess new bone formation and material resorption. The results demonstrated that the BCP bone substitute was biocompatible, osteoconductive, and gradually resorbed over time, allowing for new bone ingrowth. The balance between HA and β-TCP phases contributed to the material's stability and resorption rate, making it a promising candidate for clinical applications in bone regeneration.

title: Integrating AI into Breast Reconstruction Surgery: Exploring Opportunities, Applications, and Challenges
author: Gorgy, Andrew and Xu, Hong Hao and Hawary, Hassan El and Nepon, Hillary and Lee, James and Vorstenbosch, Joshua

title: Development and assessment of a Microsoft Kinect based system for imaging the breast in three dimensions
author: Wheat J.S.; Choppin S.; Goyal A.
abstract: Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Early detection is crucial for effective treatment and improved survival rates. Current imaging modalities such as mammography and ultrasound have limitations including discomfort, radiation exposure, and operator dependency. This study presents the development and assessment of a novel, low-cost, non-invasive system for three-dimensional (3D) imaging of the breast using the Microsoft Kinect sensor. The system captures depth data to reconstruct the breast surface in 3D, enabling volumetric measurements and shape analysis. Validation was performed using breast phantoms and clinical data from volunteers. Results demonstrate that the Kinect-based system provides accurate and reproducible 3D breast images, with potential applications in breast cancer screening, surgical planning, and monitoring of treatment response. The system offers a promising alternative to conventional imaging techniques, combining affordability, ease of use, and patient comfort.

title: Very deep convolutional networks for large-scale image recognition
author: Simonyan, Karen and Zisserman, Andrew
abstract: We investigate the effect of the convolutional network depth on its accuracy in the large-scale image recognition setting. Our main contribution is a thorough evaluation of networks of increasing depth using an architecture with very small (3×3) convolution filters, which shows that a significant improvement on the prior-art configurations can be achieved by pushing the depth to 16–19 weight layers. These findings were the basis of our ImageNet Challenge 2014 submission, where our team secured the first and the second places in the localisation and classification tracks respectively. We also show that our representations generalise well to other datasets, where they achieve state-of-the-art results.

title: A decade survey of content based image retrieval using deep learning
author: Dubey, Shiv Ram
journal: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Content-based image retrieval (CBIR) is a fundamental and challenging problem in computer vision and pattern recognition. With the rapid development of deep learning, CBIR has witnessed significant progress in recent years. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of deep learning-based CBIR methods over the past decade. We first introduce the background and motivation of CBIR and then review the representative deep learning architectures and techniques applied to CBIR, including convolutional neural networks, autoencoders, generative adversarial networks, and attention mechanisms. We also discuss various feature extraction, feature aggregation, and similarity measurement strategies. Furthermore, we analyze the strengths and limitations of existing methods and highlight several benchmark datasets and evaluation metrics commonly used in CBIR research. Finally, we identify open challenges and potential future research directions to inspire further advancements in deep learning-based CBIR.

title: Diaphragmatic muscle reconstruction with an aligned electrospun poly(ε-caprolactone)/collagen hybrid scaffold
author: Zhao W.; Ju Y.M.; Christ G.; Atala A.; Yoo J.J.; Lee S.J.
abstract: The diaphragm is a unique skeletal muscle that plays a vital role in respiration. Repair of diaphragmatic defects remains a clinical challenge due to the lack of suitable biomaterials that can mimic the native muscle structure and function. In this study, we developed an aligned electrospun poly(ε-caprolactone)/collagen (PCL/Col) hybrid scaffold to guide the regeneration of diaphragmatic muscle. The scaffold exhibited aligned fibrous architecture, suitable mechanical properties, and enhanced hydrophilicity. In vitro studies demonstrated that the aligned PCL/Col scaffold promoted the alignment, proliferation, and myogenic differentiation of C2C12 myoblasts compared to random PCL scaffolds. In vivo implantation in a rat diaphragmatic defect model showed that the aligned PCL/Col scaffold supported muscle regeneration with organized muscle fibers and improved functional recovery. These findings suggest that the aligned electrospun PCL/Col hybrid scaffold is a promising candidate for diaphragmatic muscle reconstruction.

title: Hair removal methods: A comparative study for dermoscopy images
author: Abbas Q.; Celebi M.E.; García I.F.
abstract: Hair removal is an important preprocessing step in dermoscopy image analysis. The presence of hair in dermoscopy images can significantly affect the performance of automated lesion segmentation and classification algorithms. In this paper, we present a comparative study of different hair removal methods applied to dermoscopy images. We evaluate the performance of these methods based on their ability to remove hair while preserving lesion details. The methods compared include DullRazor, morphological closing, and inpainting techniques. Our results show that inpainting methods provide better hair removal with less distortion of lesion features, which is crucial for accurate diagnosis. This study provides valuable insights for selecting appropriate hair removal techniques in dermoscopy image analysis.

title: Telemedicine applications in otolaryngology
author: Heneghan C.; Sclafani A.P.; Stern J.; Ginsburg J.
journal: IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Magazine

title: Biocompatibility studies of new multiblock poly(ester-ester)s composed of poly(butylene terephthalate) and dimerized fatty acid
author: Prowans P.; El Fray M.; Slonecki J.
abstract: Biocompatibility studies of new multiblock poly(ester-ester)s composed of poly(butylene terephthalate) and dimerized fatty acid were carried out. The materials were synthesized by polycondensation of poly(butylene terephthalate) diol and dimerized fatty acid diol with adipic acid. The in vitro cytotoxicity was evaluated by the agar diffusion test and the direct contact test using L929 mouse fibroblast cells. The in vivo biocompatibility was assessed by subcutaneous implantation in rats for 4 and 12 weeks. The results showed that the new multiblock poly(ester-ester)s exhibited no cytotoxicity and good tissue compatibility, indicating their potential for biomedical applications.

title: Development and evaluation of reconstruction methods for an in-house designed cone-beam micro-CT imaging system
author: Fu H.-M.; Chueh H.-S.; Tsai W.-K.; Chen J.-C.
journal: Biomedical Engineering - Applications, Basis and Communications
abstract: This paper presents the development and evaluation of reconstruction methods for an in-house designed cone-beam micro-CT imaging system. The system employs a micro-focus X-ray source and a flat-panel detector to acquire projection data. Reconstruction algorithms, including the Feldkamp-Davis-Kress (FDK) method and iterative reconstruction techniques, were implemented and assessed. The performance of these methods was evaluated using phantom studies to determine spatial resolution, contrast, and artifact levels. Results demonstrate that the developed reconstruction methods effectively produce high-quality volumetric images suitable for micro-CT applications, with iterative methods offering improved image quality at the expense of increased computational time. The study confirms the feasibility of the in-house system for detailed microstructural imaging and provides a foundation for further optimization of reconstruction algorithms.
reason_for_title_screening: Focus is on imaging tech, not surgery outcomes.

title: Transplantation of reconstructed corneal layer composed of corneal epithelium and fibroblasts on a lyophilized amniotic membrane to severely alkali-burned cornea
author: Jang I.-K.; Ahn J.-I.; Shin J.-S.; Kwon Y.-S.; Ryu Y.-H.; Lee J.-K.; Park J.-K.; Song K.-Y.; Yang E.-K.; Kim J.-C.
abstract: BACKGROUND: To evaluate the efficacy of transplantation of a reconstructed corneal layer composed of corneal epithelium and fibroblasts on a lyophilized amniotic membrane (LAM) to severely alkali-burned corneas. METHODS: Corneal fibroblasts were cultured on the stromal side of LAM, and corneal epithelial cells were cultured on the epithelial side. The reconstructed corneal layer was transplanted onto the corneal surface of rabbits with severe alkali burns. The corneal surface was evaluated by slit-lamp microscopy, histology, and immunohistochemistry. RESULTS: The reconstructed corneal layer adhered well to the corneal surface and survived for at least 4 weeks. The corneal surface showed improved transparency and epithelialization compared with controls. Histological examination revealed a multilayered epithelium and stromal-like tissue beneath the epithelium. Immunohistochemical analysis showed expression of keratin 3 in the epithelium and vimentin in the fibroblast layer. CONCLUSIONS: Transplantation of a reconstructed corneal layer composed of corneal epithelium and fibroblasts on LAM promotes corneal surface reconstruction and may be a useful treatment for severe alkali-burned corneas.

title: A novel bioabsorbable composite membrane of Polyactive® 70/30 and bioactive glass number 13-93 in repair of experimental maxillary alveolar cleft defects
author: Puumanen K.; Kellomäki M.; Ritsilä V.; Böhling T.; Törmälä P.; Waris T.; Ashammakhi N.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The repair of alveolar cleft defects is a challenging clinical problem. The aim of this study was to develop a novel bioabsorbable composite membrane of Polyactive® 70/30 and bioactive glass number 13-93 (BG 13-93) and to evaluate its efficacy in the repair of experimental maxillary alveolar cleft defects in a rabbit model. The composite membranes were fabricated by incorporating BG 13-93 particles into Polyactive® 70/30 matrix. The membranes were characterized by scanning electron microscopy, mechanical testing, and in vitro bioactivity assessment. The experimental alveolar cleft defects were created in rabbits and repaired using the composite membranes, with Polyactive® 70/30 membrane and no membrane as controls. Histological and micro-computed tomography analyses were performed at 4 and 8 weeks postoperatively to evaluate bone regeneration and membrane degradation. The composite membranes exhibited a porous structure with uniformly distributed BG 13-93 particles, enhanced mechanical properties, and excellent bioactivity. In vivo results demonstrated that the composite membranes significantly promoted new bone formation and accelerated membrane degradation compared to controls. These findings suggest that the novel bioabsorbable composite membrane of Polyactive® 70/30 and BG 13-93 is a promising candidate for alveolar cleft repair, providing both structural support and bioactive stimulation for bone regeneration.
reason_for_title_screening: Title targets bone repair, not surgery outcomes prediction.

title: A Computer-based Surgery Planning and Simulation for the Prediction of 3D Postoperative Facial Soft Tissue using Finite Element Analysis
author: Obaidellah, Unaizah Hanum and Selvanathan, N
abstract: This paper presents a computer-based surgery planning and simulation system for predicting three-dimensional (3D) postoperative facial soft tissue changes using finite element analysis (FEA). The system integrates patient-specific anatomical data obtained from medical imaging with biomechanical modeling to simulate the effects of surgical interventions on facial soft tissues. By constructing a finite element model of the facial soft tissue and underlying bone structures, the system allows surgeons to visualize and evaluate potential surgical outcomes preoperatively. The approach aims to improve surgical planning accuracy and patient communication by providing realistic predictions of postoperative facial appearance. Validation results demonstrate the system's capability to predict soft tissue deformations with clinically acceptable accuracy, highlighting its potential as a valuable tool in maxillofacial surgery.

title: Biological response to a new composite polymer augmentation device used for cruciate ligament reconstruction
author: Dürselen L.; Häfner M.; Ignatius A.; Kraft K.; Hollstein E.; Pokar S.; Dauner M.; Claes L.; Friemert B.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The biological response to a new composite polymer augmentation device (CPAD) used for cruciate ligament reconstruction was evaluated in a rabbit model. The CPAD is composed of a poly(L-lactide-co-D,L-lactide) (PLDLLA) braided tube filled with a polyglycolide (PGA) multifilament mesh. The device was implanted in the femoral tunnel of the rabbit knee, and the biological response was assessed at 2, 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation by histological and immunohistochemical analyses. Results showed that the CPAD was well tolerated, with a mild inflammatory response that decreased over time. Fibroblast infiltration and collagen deposition were observed within the device, indicating tissue integration. The PGA mesh degraded rapidly, while the PLDLLA tube maintained its structure during the study period. These findings suggest that the CPAD provides a favorable environment for tissue ingrowth and may serve as a suitable scaffold for ligament reconstruction.

title: In vivo evaluation of hydroxyapatite foams
author: Sepulveda P.; Bressiani A.H.; Bressiani J.C.; Meseguer L.; König B., Jr.
abstract: The in vivo behavior of hydroxyapatite (HA) foams was studied in a rabbit model. The foams were implanted into the femoral condyles and evaluated at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-implantation. Histological and histomorphometric analyses revealed good biocompatibility and osteoconductivity of the HA foams. New bone formation was observed within the pores of the foams, and the material showed progressive resorption and replacement by bone tissue over time. The results suggest that HA foams have potential as bone graft substitutes for the repair of bone defects.

title: Telemetry system for monitoring anterior cruciate ligament graft forces in vivo
author: McKee E.L.; Lindsey D.P.; Hull M.L.; Howell S.M.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: A telemetry system for monitoring anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) graft forces in vivo was developed and tested. The system consists of a force transducer integrated into the graft, a miniature transmitter, and an external receiver. The force transducer is a strain gauge-based device designed to measure tensile forces within the graft. The transmitter sends the force data wirelessly to the receiver, allowing real-time monitoring of graft forces during various activities. Calibration and in vitro testing demonstrated the system's accuracy and reliability. Preliminary in vivo experiments in animal models showed the feasibility of continuous graft force monitoring, providing valuable data for understanding graft biomechanics and improving surgical techniques. This telemetry system represents a significant advancement in orthopedic research and clinical practice by enabling direct measurement of ACL graft forces in living subjects.

title: Application of orthogonal neural network to craniomaxillary reconstruction
author: Hsu J.-H.; Tseng C.-S.
journal: Journal of Medical Engineering and Technology
abstract: This paper presents a new approach to craniomaxillary reconstruction using an orthogonal neural network (ONN). The ONN is employed to model the complex relationships between craniofacial landmarks and to predict missing or damaged bone structures. The method leverages the orthogonality property to improve learning efficiency and generalization capability. Experimental results demonstrate that the ONN can accurately reconstruct craniomaxillary defects, offering a promising tool for surgical planning and rehabilitation in maxillofacial surgery.

title: Glass reinforced hydroxyapatite for hard tissue surgery - Part II: In vitro evaluation of bone cell growth and function
author: Salih V.; Georgiou G.; Knowles J.C.; Olsen I.
abstract: Glass reinforced hydroxyapatite (GRHA) composites have been developed as potential materials for hard tissue surgery. This study evaluates the in vitro response of bone cells to GRHA in comparison with pure hydroxyapatite (HA). Bone cell attachment, proliferation, and differentiation were assessed using primary osteoblast cultures. The results demonstrated that GRHA supports bone cell growth and function, showing enhanced cell proliferation and alkaline phosphatase activity compared to pure HA. These findings suggest that GRHA composites may offer improved biological performance for bone repair applications.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on biomaterials, not on predicting aesthetic results—so off-topic.

author: Bao, J and Zhang, X and Xiang, S and Liu, H and Cheng, M and Yang, Y and Huang, X and Xiang, W and Cui, W and Lai, HC and others

title: Aristotle score predicts outcome in patients requiring extracorporeal circulatory support following repair of congenital heart disease
author: Derby C.D.; Kolcz J.; Kerins P.J.; Duncan D.R.; Quezada E.; Pizarro C.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The Aristotle score is a complexity-adjusted method of assessing risk in congenital heart surgery. We sought to determine whether the Aristotle score predicts outcome in patients requiring extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) following repair of congenital heart disease. METHODS: We reviewed 46 patients who required ECMO following repair of congenital heart disease. The Aristotle score was calculated for each patient. We analyzed the relationship between the Aristotle score and survival to hospital discharge. RESULTS: The mean Aristotle score was significantly higher in nonsurvivors (14.1 +/- 2.3) than in survivors (11.7 +/- 2.3, p = 0.002). Survival to hospital discharge was 55% in patients with an Aristotle score less than 12, 33% in patients with a score of 12 to 15, and 0% in patients with a score greater than 15 (p = 0.001). CONCLUSIONS: The Aristotle score predicts outcome in patients requiring ECMO following repair of congenital heart disease. This score may be useful in counseling families and in clinical decision making.

title: Measurement of adverse cosmesis in breast cancer: A deep learning approach
author: Saha, Ashirbani and Levine, Mark and Kong, Isaac and Parvez, Elena and Whelan, Timothy
abstract: This study proposes a novel deep learning-based approach for the objective measurement of adverse cosmesis in breast cancer patients following treatment. Traditional assessment methods rely heavily on subjective evaluations, which can lead to inconsistent and unreliable results. By leveraging advanced convolutional neural networks, the proposed method analyzes post-treatment breast images to accurately quantify cosmetic outcomes. The model was trained and validated on a comprehensive dataset, demonstrating superior performance compared to existing techniques. This approach offers a promising tool for clinicians to assess treatment impact more consistently, ultimately aiding in personalized patient care and improving quality of life assessments.

title: Aesthetics in breast conserving therapy: do objectively measured results match patients’ evaluations?
author: Heil, Joerg and Dahlkamp, Julia and Golatta, Michael and Rom, Joachim and Domschke, Christoph and Rauch, Geraldine and Cardoso, Maria Joao and Sohn, Christof
abstract: Background: The aim of this study was to compare patients’ subjective evaluations of aesthetic results after breast-conserving therapy (BCT) with objective measurements.  Methods: A total of 100 patients who underwent BCT were included. Patients rated their aesthetic outcome using a visual analog scale (VAS). Objective measurements were performed using a computer-based system analyzing breast symmetry, volume, and nipple position. Correlations between subjective and objective assessments were analyzed.  Results: The mean patient VAS score was 7.2 (range 2–10). Objective measurements showed varying degrees of asymmetry. There was a moderate correlation between patient evaluations and objective symmetry measurements (r = 0.45, p < 0.01). However, some patients with significant asymmetry rated their results highly, indicating a discrepancy between subjective satisfaction and objective findings.  Conclusions: While objective measurements provide valuable information on aesthetic outcomes after BCT, they do not fully capture patients’ subjective satisfaction. Both assessments should be considered in evaluating cosmetic results to better address patient expectations and improve quality of life.

title: Metacarpophalangeal collateral ligament reconstruction using small intestinal submucosa in an equine model
author: Bertone A.L.; Goin S.; Kamei S.J.; Mattoon J.S.; Litsky A.S.; Weisbrode S.E.; Clarke R.B.; Plouhar P.L.; Kaeding C.C.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part A
abstract: The collateral ligaments of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint are important stabilizers of the joint and are frequently injured in horses. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the use of small intestinal submucosa (SIS) as a scaffold for collateral ligament reconstruction in an equine model. Six adult horses underwent unilateral reconstruction of the MCP collateral ligament using SIS. Clinical, ultrasonographic, and histologic evaluations were performed over a 12-week period. All horses tolerated the procedure well, and no complications were observed. Ultrasonographic examination showed progressive integration of the SIS graft with surrounding tissues. Histologic analysis revealed cellular infiltration, neovascularization, and collagen deposition within the graft, indicating remodeling and ligamentization. These findings suggest that SIS is a promising biomaterial for collateral ligament reconstruction in horses, providing a scaffold that supports tissue regeneration and functional recovery. Further studies are warranted to assess long-term outcomes and biomechanical properties of the reconstructed ligaments.

title: Evaluation of hot-pressed hydroxyapatite/poly-L-lactide composite biomaterial characteristics
author: Ignjatovic N.; Suljovrujic E.; Budinski-Simendic J.; Krakovsky I.; Uskokovic D.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The hot-pressed hydroxyapatite (HA)/poly-L-lactide (PLLA) composite biomaterial was evaluated for its characteristics as a bone substitute. The composite was prepared by hot pressing a mixture of HA powder and PLLA powder at 180°C under a pressure of 25 MPa. The microstructure, mechanical properties, and in vitro bioactivity of the composite were investigated. Scanning electron microscopy revealed a uniform distribution of HA particles in the PLLA matrix. The composite exhibited improved mechanical properties compared to pure PLLA, with increased tensile strength and modulus. In vitro bioactivity tests in simulated body fluid showed the formation of apatite on the composite surface, indicating good bioactivity. These results suggest that the hot-pressed HA/PLLA composite has potential as a bone substitute material with favorable mechanical and biological properties.

title: Biocompatibility and degradation of collagen bone anchors in a rabbit model
author: Schroeder J.A.; Brown M.K.C.
abstract: The biocompatibility and degradation of collagen bone anchors were evaluated in a rabbit model. Collagen anchors were implanted into the tibiae of rabbits and examined histologically at 1, 3, and 6 months post-implantation. The results demonstrated that the collagen anchors were well tolerated, eliciting only a mild inflammatory response that diminished over time. Progressive degradation of the collagen material was observed, with substantial resorption by 6 months. New bone formation was noted around the implant sites, indicating good osteoconductivity. These findings suggest that collagen bone anchors are biocompatible and biodegradable, supporting their potential use in orthopedic applications.

title: Bioresorbable devices made of forged composites of hydroxyapatite (HA) particles and poly-L-lactide (PLLA): Part I. Basic characteristics
author: Shikinami Y.; Okuno M.
abstract: Bioresorbable composites of hydroxyapatite (HA) particles and poly-L-lactide (PLLA) were prepared by a forging process. The composites were characterized in terms of their mechanical properties, microstructure, and in vitro degradation behavior. The forging process resulted in a dense composite with improved mechanical properties compared to unfilled PLLA. The HA particles were well dispersed in the PLLA matrix, and the interface between HA and PLLA was strong. In vitro degradation tests showed that the composites degraded gradually, with the HA particles remaining as a porous scaffold after PLLA degradation. These results suggest that forged HA/PLLA composites have potential as bioresorbable devices for orthopedic applications.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on materials, not surgery or aesthetics.

title: Ovine anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction using a synthetic prosthesis and a collagen inductor
author: Huguet D.; Delecrin J.; Passuti N.; Daculsi G.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is one of the most frequently injured ligaments in the knee. Reconstruction of the ACL is often necessary to restore knee stability and function. This study evaluates the use of a synthetic prosthesis combined with a collagen inductor for ACL reconstruction in an ovine model. The synthetic prosthesis provides immediate mechanical stability, while the collagen inductor aims to promote tissue ingrowth and ligamentization. Histological and biomechanical assessments were performed to analyze the integration and functionality of the reconstructed ligament over time. Results indicate that the combined use of a synthetic prosthesis and collagen inductor supports ligament regeneration and improves the mechanical properties of the reconstructed ACL, suggesting a promising approach for ACL repair.
reason_for_title_screening: Focuses on sheep ACL surgery, not on aesthetic outcome prediction in plastic/oncological surgery.

title: Hair removal using the long-pulsed ruby laser in children
author: Morley S.; Gault D.
journal: Journal of Clinical Laser Medicine and Surgery
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hair removal in children is a common cosmetic concern. The long-pulsed ruby laser has been used effectively for hair removal in adults, but its safety and efficacy in children have not been well studied. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of the long-pulsed ruby laser for hair removal in children. METHODS: Twenty children aged 7 to 15 years with unwanted hair were treated with the long-pulsed ruby laser. Treatments were performed at 4- to 6-week intervals for a total of three to six sessions. Hair reduction was assessed by clinical examination and patient satisfaction. RESULTS: Significant hair reduction was observed in all patients, with minimal side effects. Transient erythema and mild discomfort were the most common adverse effects. No scarring or pigmentary changes were noted. CONCLUSION: The long-pulsed ruby laser is a safe and effective method for hair removal in children. It offers a promising option for pediatric patients seeking long-term hair reduction.

title: Five-year clinical investigation of one conventional composite and three microfilled resins in anterior teeth
author: Crumpler D.C.; Heymann H.O.; Shugars D.A.; Bayne S.C.; Leinfelder K.F.
abstract: The clinical performance of one conventional composite resin (Concise) and three microfilled resins (Silux Plus, Durafill, and Heliomolar) was evaluated in anterior teeth over a five-year period. A total of 120 restorations were placed in 30 patients and assessed at baseline and after 1, 2, 3, and 5 years using modified USPHS criteria. The results showed that all materials exhibited good clinical performance with no significant differences in retention rates. However, microfilled resins demonstrated superior surface texture and color match compared to the conventional composite. Marginal adaptation and anatomic form were maintained satisfactorily in all materials. The study concluded that microfilled resins are suitable for anterior restorations, offering esthetic advantages without compromising clinical durability over five years.

title: An artificial intelligence tool for image simulation in rhinoplasty
author: Chinski, Hernan and Lerch, Ricardo and Tournour, Dami{\'a}n and Chinski, Luis and Caruso, Diego
abstract: Background Rhinoplasty is one of the most challenging procedures in plastic surgery. The use of artificial intelligence (AI) tools in image simulation can help surgeons and patients to better understand the expected surgical outcomes. This study aimed to develop and evaluate an AI-based tool for image simulation in rhinoplasty.  Methods A convolutional neural network (CNN) was trained on a dataset of preoperative and postoperative rhinoplasty images to learn the transformation patterns. The model was then used to generate simulated postoperative images from new preoperative photographs. The quality and realism of the simulated images were assessed by a panel of experienced plastic surgeons.  Results The AI tool successfully generated realistic postoperative images that closely resembled actual surgical outcomes. The surgeons rated the simulations as highly accurate and useful for preoperative planning and patient counseling.  Conclusion The developed AI-based image simulation tool shows promise as an aid in rhinoplasty, enhancing communication between surgeons and patients and potentially improving surgical planning and satisfaction. Further studies with larger datasets are warranted to refine the model and validate its clinical utility.

title: Anchor-Net: Distance-Based Self-Supervised Learning Model for Facial Beauty Prediction
author: Bae, Jiho and Buu, Seok-Jun and Lee, Suwon
abstract: This paper proposes a novel self-supervised learning model, Anchor-Net, for facial beauty prediction. Unlike traditional supervised methods that rely heavily on labeled data, Anchor-Net leverages a distance-based approach to learn discriminative facial features without explicit beauty annotations. The model employs anchor points in the feature space to capture intrinsic beauty-related characteristics, enabling effective representation learning. Experimental results on benchmark facial beauty datasets demonstrate that Anchor-Net achieves competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art supervised methods, highlighting its potential for applications where labeled data is scarce or unavailable.

title: Reconstruction of resected mandibles using a hydroxyapatite veterinary bone graft
author: Abdel-Fattah W.I.; Osiris W.G.; Mohamed S.S.; Khalil M.R.

title: Prefabricated tracheal prosthesis with partial biodegradable materials: A surgical and tissue engineering evaluation in vivo
author: Acocella F.; Brizzola S.; Valtolina C.; Scanziani E.; Marchesi F.; Mantero S.; Garreau H.; Vert M.
journal: Journal of Biomaterials Science, Polymer Edition
abstract: The present study aimed to evaluate the in vivo performance of a prefabricated tracheal prosthesis composed of partial biodegradable materials. The prosthesis was designed to combine mechanical support with tissue engineering principles to promote regeneration of tracheal tissue. In a surgical model, the prosthesis was implanted and assessed for biocompatibility, integration with host tissue, and functional outcomes over a defined period. Histological and mechanical analyses demonstrated that the biodegradable components facilitated gradual tissue ingrowth and remodeling, while maintaining airway patency. The results suggest that this hybrid approach holds promise for tracheal reconstruction, offering a balance between structural integrity and biological integration. Further studies are warranted to optimize material composition and long-term outcomes.

title: Biodegradable material for bladder reconstruction
author: Agishi T.; Nakazono M.; Kiraly R.J.; Picha G.; Nosé Y.
abstract: Biodegradable materials have been investigated as scaffolds for bladder reconstruction to provide a temporary matrix that supports tissue regeneration and then degrades, eliminating the need for surgical removal. This study evaluates the use of a biodegradable polymer, poly(glycolic acid) (PGA), as a scaffold for bladder tissue engineering. PGA scaffolds were seeded with bladder smooth muscle cells and implanted in a rat model. Histological and functional assessments demonstrated that the PGA scaffold supported smooth muscle regeneration and urothelial coverage, with progressive scaffold degradation over time. These findings suggest that biodegradable PGA scaffolds may be a promising approach for bladder reconstruction, offering a potential alternative to traditional non-degradable materials.

title: Initial Results of Laser Angioplasty under Angioscopic Guidance for Salvage of an Ischemic Lower Limb: Preliminary Report

title: Deep edge detection methods for the automatic calculation of the breast contour
author: Freitas, Nuno and Silva, Daniel and Mavioso, Carlos and Cardoso, Maria J and Cardoso, Jaime S
abstract: Accurate breast contour detection is a crucial step in breast cancer diagnosis and treatment planning. Traditional edge detection methods often struggle with the complex and variable nature of breast images. This study proposes deep learning-based edge detection methods to automatically calculate the breast contour from medical images. We evaluate several deep edge detection architectures and compare their performance with classical methods. Our results demonstrate that deep learning approaches significantly improve the accuracy and robustness of breast contour detection, facilitating better clinical decision-making and personalized treatment strategies.

title: A novel incremental simulation of facial changes following orthognathic surgery using FEM with realistic lip sliding effect
author: Kim, Daeseung and Kuang, Tianshu and Rodrigues, Yriu L and Gateno, Jaime and Shen, Steve GF and Wang, Xudong and Stein, Kirhyn and Deng, Hannah H and Liebschner, Michael AK and Xia, James J
abstract: Orthognathic surgery is a common procedure to correct dentofacial deformities, which results in significant changes in facial appearance. Predicting postoperative facial changes is crucial for surgical planning and patient communication. This paper presents a novel incremental simulation method based on the finite element method (FEM) to predict facial soft tissue changes following orthognathic surgery, incorporating a realistic lip sliding effect. The proposed method models the lip sliding phenomenon by introducing a frictional contact algorithm between the upper and lower lips, which allows for more accurate simulation of lip movements and deformations. The incremental approach updates the simulation step-by-step, capturing the gradual changes in facial tissues during surgery. Experimental results on clinical cases demonstrate that the proposed method achieves improved accuracy in predicting postoperative facial appearance, especially in the lip region, compared to existing methods. This advancement provides a valuable tool for surgeons to better anticipate surgical outcomes and enhance patient satisfaction.

title: A fully automatic postoperative appearance prediction system for blepharoptosis surgery with image-based deep learning
author: Sun, Yiming and Huang, Xingru and Zhang, Qianni and Lee, Sang Yeul and Wang, Yaqi and Jin, Kai and Lou, Lixia and Ye, Juan
abstract: Purpose: To develop a fully automatic postoperative appearance prediction system for blepharoptosis surgery using image-based deep learning. Design: Retrospective case series. Participants: A total of 970 preoperative and postoperative facial images from 485 patients who underwent blepharoptosis surgery. Methods: A deep learning model was trained to predict postoperative appearance from preoperative images. The model was developed using a convolutional neural network architecture and was trained on paired preoperative and postoperative images. Main Outcome Measures: The accuracy of the predicted postoperative appearance was evaluated using quantitative metrics and qualitative assessments by ophthalmologists. Results: The deep learning model successfully generated postoperative appearance predictions that closely resembled actual postoperative images. Quantitative analysis showed high similarity scores between predicted and actual postoperative images. Qualitative assessments by ophthalmologists confirmed the clinical relevance and accuracy of the predictions. Conclusions: The developed deep learning-based system can automatically predict postoperative appearance after blepharoptosis surgery with high accuracy, potentially aiding surgical planning and patient counseling.

title: Assessment of viability and proliferation of in vivo silicone‐primed lymphocytes after in vitro re‐exposure to silicone
author: Ciapetti G.; Granchi D.; Stea S.; Cenni E.; Schiavon P.; Giuliani R.; Pizzoferrato A.
abstract: The viability and proliferation of lymphocytes obtained from silicone‐primed and control rats were assessed after in vitro re‐exposure to silicone. Lymphocytes were isolated from the lymph nodes of rats that had been implanted with silicone gel or sham operated. The cells were cultured in the presence or absence of silicone gel for 3 days. Cell viability was determined by trypan blue exclusion and proliferation was measured by [3H]thymidine incorporation. The results showed that lymphocytes from silicone‐primed rats had a significantly higher proliferation rate upon re‐exposure to silicone in vitro compared to controls, while cell viability remained unaffected. These findings suggest that silicone implantation primes lymphocytes to respond to silicone antigens, which may have implications for understanding silicone-related immune responses.

title: Advantage of rubber over plastic endotracheal tubes for rapid extubation in a laser fire

title: Evaluation of soft-tissue properties under controlled expansion for reconstructive surgical use
author: Duffy J.S.; Shuter M.
abstract: The mechanical properties of soft tissues are important in the design of tissue expanders for reconstructive surgery. This study presents a method for the controlled expansion of soft tissues and the evaluation of their mechanical properties under these conditions. Using a specially designed expansion device, the tissue was expanded in a controlled manner, and the resulting changes in tissue properties were measured. The results indicate that tissue expansion leads to significant changes in the mechanical behavior of the soft tissues, which has implications for the design and application of tissue expanders in reconstructive surgery.

title: Clinical evaluations of OSTEON® as a new alloplastic material in sinus bone grafting and its effect on bone healing
author: Kim Y.-K.; Yun P.-Y.; Lim S.-C.; Kim S.-G.; Lee H.-J.; Ong J.L.
journal: Journal of Biomedical Materials Research - Part B Applied Biomaterials
abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the clinical efficacy of OSTEON® as a new alloplastic material in sinus bone grafting and its effect on bone healing. Twenty patients requiring sinus bone grafting were enrolled and divided into two groups: the OSTEON® group and the control group using Bio-Oss®. Clinical and radiographic evaluations were performed at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively. Histological and histomorphometric analyses were conducted on bone biopsy specimens obtained during implant placement. The results showed that OSTEON® demonstrated comparable clinical performance to Bio-Oss® in terms of graft volume maintenance and implant stability. Histological analysis revealed new bone formation with good integration of OSTEON® particles, indicating its osteoconductive properties. The study concluded that OSTEON® is a promising alloplastic material for sinus bone grafting, promoting effective bone healing and providing a suitable environment for implant placement.

title: Preliminary assessment of the Con-Bio laser in vivo
author: Lanzafame R.J.; Naim J.O.; Blackman J.R.
journal: Journal of Clinical Laser Medicine and Surgery
abstract: The Con-Bio laser is a new, low-power, continuous wave, helium-neon laser that has been developed for clinical use. This preliminary study was designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the Con-Bio laser in vivo. Twenty healthy volunteers were treated with the laser on the skin of the forearm. The treatment consisted of a single 5-minute exposure at a power density of 5 mW/cm2. Clinical and histological evaluations were performed before and after treatment. No adverse effects were observed. Histological examination revealed no evidence of tissue damage or inflammation. These preliminary results suggest that the Con-Bio laser is safe for clinical use and may have potential therapeutic applications. Further studies are warranted to evaluate its efficacy in various clinical conditions.

title: Breast compliance: a new method for evaluation of cosmetic outcome after conservative treatment of early breast cancer
author: Tsouskas, LI and Fentiman, IS
abstract: Breast compliance, defined as the ratio of breast volume to breast projection, was evaluated as a new method for assessing cosmetic outcome after conservative treatment of early breast cancer. In a prospective study, 50 patients underwent breast-conserving surgery followed by radiotherapy. Breast volume and projection were measured using a three-dimensional laser scanner before treatment and at 6 and 12 months post-treatment. The breast compliance index was calculated and correlated with subjective cosmetic assessments by patients and clinicians. Results showed a significant decrease in breast compliance on the treated side compared to the untreated side, correlating with poorer cosmetic outcomes. Breast compliance measurement provides an objective, reproducible, and sensitive method for evaluating cosmetic results after breast-conserving therapy and may aid in treatment planning and patient counseling.

title: Poly(2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate) microspheres/liquid poly(dimethylsiloxane) composition for correction of small defects in face: Histological evaluation in animal experiment
author: Horák D.; Adamyan A.; Golubeva O.; Skuba N.; Vinokurova T.
journal: Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Medicine
abstract: Poly(2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate) (pHEMA) microspheres suspended in liquid poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) were evaluated as a filler material for correction of small defects in the face. The composition was injected subcutaneously into the backs of rabbits and histologically examined at 1, 3, and 6 months post-injection. The pHEMA microspheres were well tolerated, with minimal inflammatory response and no evidence of migration. The PDMS carrier provided a suitable vehicle for injection and maintained the microspheres at the injection site. The results suggest that pHEMA microspheres in liquid PDMS may be a promising material for soft tissue augmentation in facial reconstructive surgery.

title: Evaluation of cosmetic outcomes in breast reconstruction patients undergoing radiotherapy using an anomaly generative adversarial network model
author: Lee, Choong-Won and Shin, Kyung Hwan and Chang, Ji Hyun and Jang, Bum-Sup
abstract: Breast reconstruction patients undergoing radiotherapy often experience changes in cosmetic outcomes, which are challenging to evaluate objectively. This study proposes an anomaly generative adversarial network (AnoGAN) model to assess cosmetic outcomes in these patients. The model was trained on pre- and post-radiotherapy images to detect anomalies indicative of cosmetic changes. Our results demonstrate that the AnoGAN model effectively identifies subtle cosmetic alterations, providing a quantitative and objective tool for evaluating breast reconstruction outcomes post-radiotherapy. This approach has the potential to enhance clinical decision-making and patient counseling by offering precise assessments of cosmetic results.

title: Development of in vitro performance tests and evaluation of nonabsorbable monofilament sutures for cardiovascular surgery
author: Hong T.; King M.W.; Michielsen S.; Cheung L.W.K.; Mary C.; Guzman R.; Guidoin R.
abstract: The in vitro performance tests of nonabsorbable monofilament sutures for cardiovascular surgery were developed and evaluated. The tensile strength, knot security, and surface characteristics of polypropylene, nylon, and expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) sutures were examined. The results showed that polypropylene and nylon sutures had higher tensile strength and knot security compared to ePTFE sutures. Surface analysis revealed that ePTFE sutures had a unique microporous structure, which may influence tissue integration. These findings provide valuable information for selecting appropriate sutures in cardiovascular surgical procedures.
